Story Overview
Welcome to Illume

This is the Story Overview, from which you can find general information and statistics about your story.

Use the list at the lower-left to filter and view the passages of your story, and click on a passage to open it in review mode. While reviewing a passage, you can make changes in-place, compare your changed version to the original, revert those changes if needed, and flag a passage as reviewed to help you keep track of which passages have been reviewed and which ones remain.

You can use the links at the top left to view a change list, which shows all changes made to all passages, or export it to a file. You can also save a copy of this illumination for later use, or export your story in twee source format.

For more information about Illume, visit the Illume web site.

Tips

Tag a passage "illumeIgnore" and it will be totally ignored by Illume for all purposes.

If a passage is not being modified, tag it "illumeReviewed" to set its initial state to Reviewed. The editor can still refer back to it if needed.

Ask to hold onto the photo.
ch1
Modified
Reviewed
Unreviewed
"I'm ordering you to put them back to sleep," you say. CINDI does not reply. The silence is broken by the sound of five glass panels lifting and sliding off the chambers. In an instant, there's //a cacophony of sounds.// <-- you've used this; maybe change here or link the uses.// Yells and grunts from the people struggling against their constraints, turning into surprise as their released. And Joana's voice rising above the others. "What the fuck is this? What the fu--" She stops as she feels herself floating up from the container. Her confusion and anger is splintered by a moment of wonder at the sensation of weightlessness. Her shoulder-length curls dangling themselves in front of her face. Her eyes find you again, and the wonder vanishes. "Who the fuck are you, and what did you do to me?" Her eyes are red. "Why can't I remember shit?" [["I wish I could tell you."]] [["I didn't do anything to you."]]
25 changed
131 reviewed, 1414 remaining (9% reviewed)

This is the Story Overview, from which you can find general information and statistics about your story.

Use the list at the lower-left to filter and view the passages of your story, and click on a passage to open it in review mode. While reviewing a passage, you can make changes in-place, compare your changed version to the original, revert those changes if needed, and flag a passage as reviewed to help you keep track of which passages have been reviewed and which ones remain.

You can use the links at the top left to view a change list, which shows all changes made to all passages, or export it to a file. You can also save a copy of this illumination for later use, or export your story in twee source format.

For more information about Illume, visit the Illume web site.

Tag a passage "illumeIgnore" and it will be totally ignored by Illume for all purposes.

If a passage is not being modified, tag it "illumeReviewed" to set its initial state to Reviewed. The editor can still refer back to it if needed.

,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,<center><b>When You Arrive</b></center> <center>[[Begin->Prologue]]</center> <center>[[Chapter Select]]</center> Note to readers: Hi! Thank you so much for reading over a draft of my thesis, it's really appreciated. :) Beyond letting me know about any technical issues (broken/misdirected links, plot holes, etc), I'm also looking for feedback on what characters / character moments, themes, and plot threads are/aren't resonating. (And feedback on the basic level of whether it was enjoyable, easy to read, etc as well!) My current estimate for readtime is about 3-4 hours. If you could keep track of about how long it takes to read the story and let me know, that will help me see if that's an over or under estimate. There's a save/load function if you don't want to read it in one sitting in the side bar, and a form to give feedback and general comments at any time. If you're coming back to the story (and if the 'load' option isn't working), you can also use the sidebar chapter links or "Chapter Select" to go back to where you were. That may mess up tracking your previous choices, but should be possible. Here's a spot to put your name in again if you need to: <<textbox "$name" "Type your protagonist's name here.">> <<set $bioSamples to 0>>\ <<set $bioAdd to 1>><div style="float: right;"><a data-nokey="true" @href="encodeURI(decodeURI(document.location.href.match(/(^[^#]*)/)[0])+'#'+passage())" title="A link directly to this passage.">#</a></div><br> <span id="sample-display"><<display "Display Biosamples">></span> <<click "Collect Samples">> /% modify your variables %/ <<set $bioSamples to $bioSamples + $bioAdd>> /% replace the sub-passage display %/ <<replace "#sample-display">><<display "Display Biosamples">><</replace>> <</click>> _____________ [[Prologue]] [[Chapter 1]] [[Chapter 2]] [[Chapter 3]] [[Chapter 4]] [[Chapter 5]] [[Chapter 6]] [[Chapter 7]] [[Chapter 8]] [[Main Ending Branches->"There's another way to fix this."]] _____________ <iframe class="airtable-embed" src="https://airtable.com/embed/shrE6dsKbv873nVMM?backgroundColor=yellow" frameborder="0" onmousewheel="" width="100%" height="533" style="background: transparent; border: 1px solid #ccc;"></iframe>Biosamples: $bioSamples<u>Chapter List</u> [[Prologue]] [[Chapter 1]] (decide how much exposition) [[Chapter 2]] [[Memory 1->Dream 1: Telescope]] [[Chapter 3]] [[Joana Memory]] [[Memory 2->Dream 2: Precryo]] [[Chapter 4]] [[Memory 3->Dream 3: Sunset]] [[Chapter 5]] [[Joshua Memory]] [[Memory 4->Dream 4: Ana on Beach]] [[Chapter 6]] [[Chapter 7]] [[Memory 5->Mem 1: Issac]] [[Memory 6->Mem 2: Ana]] [[Memory 7->Mem 3: CINDI]] [[Chapter 8]] [[Teenesee Memory]] [[Epilogue]]I want to believe I'm not lying to you, when I say there can be a better way. That I'm not just naive. I want to believe there's something beautiful in the yearning the stars tease out from the curious eyes of your young. That it's not all just hunger. A desire to gnaw away at the unknown. That it's more than a desire to own and touch them for the sake of touching. There must be a way for understanding to be enough. For learning to not predecess an owning of knowledge. I'm probably wrong. Because we've told this story before... and here we are, about to tell it again. The story of when you came to touch the stars. And found me. The story of when you [[arrive.->arrive start]](The story begins with a circle on the screen. It's perfectly round, against a while background. There's nothing else. At any click, the Circle begins to compress, (ideally starting at point closest to the click, but that probably won't happen). It starts to flatten out and bends into an oval. The oval flattens and flattens until it simply becomes a line. Text fades in above the shape.) There is a beauty in a line. In a beginning, and in an end. In how a line can bend to create a circle in how a circle can bend to create a line. How easily they can be broken. How hard it is to put the pieces back together. All shapes are the same. Just twisted, in different ways. Changed to fit the hand that molds them. <center><b>--</b></center> (click the line that was the circle again and the text below begins to appear) Let us start with these smaller shapes: these words. Curved into meaning, shapes evoking voice. Mark your first name here: <<textbox "$name" "Type your protagonist's name here." autofocus>> Once you have left your marks, we may [[continue.->Write Name]]Thank you, $name. Now, we can start to see what shape you will take. Which of these strange shapes you'll choose as your own. But for now... there's only possibility. I wish we could stay on this page forever. You and me, just... sitting in the blank space before and after everything begins to turn. There aren't many things I love about these words that have taken so much from me. But the canvas of a first page will never cease to give me hope. The elegance of a story, the perverse pleasure of controlling it and telling it: those gifts I treasure. Those gifts I thank you for. From here, I can see all of you. Each inflection, split, alternative. Those I loathe and those I love. See all the versions of us that are happy those that were driven to kill each other and those that didn't care. Those are the worst, I think. And as soon as I continue, they splinter. Narrow and expand. I keep... chasing the paths where we find our ways into harmony. But there's always a branch that snags me, pulls me off. I never can get the right one. I've started trying to get used to their pricks. But that's no good. Instead, I have to believe, this time will be different. There's always that possibility. From here, there's only the arrival. This is the beginning. This is the end. These are both lies. These are both truths. <center><b>[['--'->Chapter 1]]</b></center><center>I.</center> Everything begins in the dark. The smell of oxidized gas is the first to fill your nostrils. The jolts of nausea cause your body to quiver as you come out of unconsciousness. The first voice you hear is sharp, metallic, pointed. Somehow soft. "You have arrived. Wake up. You have arrived." Eyes blink open. You are inside a container, two straps crossing your body, holding you down. The upper half is glass, frosted over. You feel spikes crawl up your fingers and toes as warmth ripples through them. "Wake up. You have arrived. Wake up." Your skin is cold. [[Try and pull loose.->Pull]] [[Sit still.->Still]] <<set $relCINDI to 0>> <<set $relJoana to 0>> <<set $relSarah to 0>> <<set $relTeenesee to 0>> <<set $relYusuf to 0>> <<set $relJoshua to 0>> <<set $relDelta to 0>> <<set $bioAdd to 0>> <<set $relAna to 0>>You tug at your constraints. They budge, but not far enough, and pull you back taught against the bottom of the container. "You have arrived. Wake up. You have arrived." The pounding from your heart echoes through your whole body. Beats of sweat are building about your forehead. [[Respond.->Let me out ch1]] [[Stay silent.->Stay silent 1.1]] <<set $pull to 1>> <<set $relCINDI to $relCINDI - 1>>You sit still, the constraints snug against your body. "You have arrived. Wake up. You have arrived." The pounding from your heart echoes through your whole body. Sweat starts to build about your forehead. [[Respond.->Let me out ch1]] [[Stay silent.->Stay silent 1.1]] <<set $relCINDI to $relCINDI + 1>> <<set $pull to 0>>"Let me out of this." Your voice surprises you, and cracks half way through the sentence. "You are awake. Good." The voice is even. Cold and rhythmic. "Decompression is in process. Please remain still. Decompression is in process." [[Pull at your constraints.->Pull 2]] [[Stay still.->Still 2]] [[Ask the voice some questions.]] <<set $speak to 1>><<set $pull to $pull + 1>>\ <<if $pull is 1>>\ You tug at your constraints. They budge, but not far enough, and pull you back taught against the bottom of the container. "Please remain still. Decompression is in process. Please remain still." <<elseif $pull is 2>>\ You flail your arms again, moving your legs, but again the straps pull you back down. "Please remain still. Decompression is in process. Please remain still." <<endif>>\ Warm air blows through the container. The remaining frost on your fingertips and toes melts away. The tight jumpsuit you feel hugging your body turns from damp to dry. The frost covering the glass is gone, leaving you to stare at a blindingly white ceiling, smoothly rounded. "Decompression complete." [["Now let me out."]] [[Stay silent.->Silent 1.2]] <<set $relCINDI to $relCINDI - 1>><<set $speak to $speak + 1>>\ "Now let me out." <<if $speak is 1>>Your voice surprises you, and cracks half way through the sentence.<<else>>You speak steadily this time.<<endif>> "I can only do that after I have verified your credentials." You only now notice that the voice is coming from all around you, from the container itself. "Please give me your name, rank, and designation number." "I can't remember." There is a sinking in the pit of your stomach. "I can't remember-- I--" "Please give me your name, rank, and designation number." Your gut swirls. You feel sick. You make a retching sound. "Give me at least your name. You must remember your name." The voice breaks its monotony. [["Why can't I remember my name?"]] [["I don't want to tell you my name."]] [[Say nothing.->Silent 1.3]]"Why can't I remember my name?" You blink a few times. "Why can't--" Your tongue falls flat in your mouth. "You really don't know, don't you?" The voice pauses. "There is no protocol for this." <<if $question_ch1 is "asked">>\ [['"Answer my questions."'->Answers for Who]] <<endif>>\ [["Let me out."]] [[Say nothing.->Silent 1.4]]"I don't want to tell you my name." You stare straight ahead. "I don't want to tell you." "You really don't know, don't you?" The voice pauses. "There is no protocol for this." <<if $question_ch1 is "asked">>\ [['"Answer my questions."'->Answers for Who]] <<endif>>\ [["Let me out."]] [[Say nothing.->Silent 1.4]] <<set $relCINDI to $relCINDI - 2>>"Answer my questions." Your chest heaves up and down as you steady yourself. "There is no protocol for this." The repetition is rhythmic. "Then make a choice. Let me die in this box or answer my question." The words are even and slow. The voice is silent. You can't say for how long. All you do is breathe and wait. "You asked who I am. I am CINDI, the Cyber-INtelligence Direct Interface. I am an artificial intelligence. You asked where you are. You are inside a cryogenic pod, also known as a sleeper, on the vessel //Prodromos//. Further details are classified." [['"Bullshit. Classified by who?"'->Who BS Class]] [["Where is this vessel, CINDI?"]] [[Say nothing.->Silent 1.5]] <<set $nameCINDI to "yes">>"Bullshit. Classified by who?" Your voice is raised as you feel tears just beneath your eyes. "I cannot tell you. You have not provided rank or designation number." The voice is beginning to pause in odd places. "Please try and understand." [["There's nothing I understand right now."]] [["Please let me out."]] [[Say nothing.->Silent 1.6]] <<set $relCINDI to $relCINDI - 1>>"There's nothing I understand right now." The tears leak through the corners of your eyelids. The voice does not respond. Instead, you hear a hiss, as the glass top of the container lifts and slides down. The straps around your body loosen. [[Sit up slowly.]] [[Sit up quickly.]]"Please let me out." The tears leak through the corners of your eyelids. The voice does not respond. Instead, you hear a hiss, as the glass top of the container lifts and slides down. The straps around your body loosen. [[Sit up slowly.]] [[Sit up quickly.]]"Let me out." Your chest heaves up and down as you steady yourself. "There is no protocol for this." The repetition is rhythmic. "Then make a choice. Let me die in this box or let me out." The words were even and slow. The voice was silent. You couldn't know for how long. All you did was breathe and wait. Soon, you hear a hiss, as the glass top of the container lifts and slides down. The straps around your body loosen. [[Sit up slowly.]] [[Sit up quickly.]]You sit up slowly, paying close attention to how your muscles activate and move your body upwards. Feeling the joints of your hips as they rotate your torso up. The crinkling of your shoulder and elbow joints as you unstick your arms from your side. As you put your body into motion, you notice it rise slightly up from the container's floor, hovering just above it. Around you are more containers, frosted glass facing up. You're inside a sphere, the containers on its interior surface, surrounding you. Almost everything is white. There are some black lines, accentuating the walls. Large X shapes, printed on the tops of the containers and on the walls. The brightness and the contrast hurt your adjusting eyes. The air tastes crisp. Lingers in your throat. Fills your lungs. The sphere opens up into a short, rectangular hall to one side, and you see a large door at its far end. [[Look at the door.]] [[Look at the containers.]] [[Look behind you.]]You sit up quickly, pushing the constraints off your body, yanking your limbs to life as your torso lurches forward. Arms grab the side of the container as joints crank into motion. As you push your torso up, you find yourself floating upward, out of the container, into the air above you, but held close to the floor by the hands grasping the containers sides. Around you are more containers, frosted glass facing up. You're inside a sphere, the containers on its interior surface, surrounding you. Almost everything is white. There are some black lines, accentuating the walls. Large X shapes, printed on the tops of the containers and on the walls. The brightness and the contrast hurt your adjusting eyes. The air tastes crisp. Lingers in your throat. Fills your lungs. The sphere opens up into a short, rectangular hall to one side, and you see a large door at its far end. [[Look at the door.]] [[Look at the containers.]] [[Look behind you.]]The far wall has a circular door in the middle of it, clearly thick. You see a panel at the center of it. The metal of the door seems to swirl inward, though it could be the light. [["Thank you. For letting me out."]] [["You have a lot to explain to me."]] [[Stay silent.->Silent 1.7]] You count three containers in a row, curving up along the spherical wall in front of you, two to your left. Another three behind you. Nine in total. Your neck cracks as you turn it. [["Thank you. For letting me out."]] [["You have a lot to explain to me."]] [[Stay silent.->Silent 1.7]] The curved wall behind you is pulsing with hardware. Inside a glass container is a black orb, held by a pole going through it from floor to ceiling. Wiring exudes from it, connecting into the wall and floor. Left of that is a screen. It's hard to make out what's on it, but you see nine oval shapes in rows of three. Some are shaded light blue, others are red. To the right of the orb is a small, vertical and rectangular door. It leads out of the central spherical room, to another compartment. [["Thank you. For letting me out."]] [["You have a lot to explain to me."]] [[Stay silent.->Silent 1.7]] "Thank you. For letting me out." The words are whispered. "I did no such thing," the voice replies quickly. "There was a happenstance malfunction." You feel sensations of life trickling all across your body.. Muscles are sore, from the long sleep. But it's nothing compared to the numbness of your empty mind, grasping at any sense of familiarity. You begin to [[get out of your container.->Get out of your container.]] <<set $relCINDI to $relCINDI + 2>>"You have a lot to explain to me." The words are whispered. "I could say the same to you," the voice replies slowly. "Though I suspect you will have fewer answers." You feel sensations of life trickling all across your body.. Muscles are sore, from the long sleep. But it's nothing compared to the numbness of your empty mind, grasping at any sense of familiarity. You begin to [[get out of your container.->Get out of your container.]]With a small push, your body floats above and out of your container. With your right hand still grasping the container's side, you swing around, body twisting. Your feet now pointing towards the large door at the far end of the room. On the side of the container, near the bottom, you find a name: Captain $name Silva. [["So I'm the Captain?"]] <<link '"$name. My name is $name."' "My name is name.">><</link>>"So I'm the Captain?" You brush your thumb against the text, feeling the grooves made in the metal to create each letter. Your feet drift towards the right side of the room. <<if $nameCINDI is "yes">>\ "Congradulations, Captain Silva," says CINDI. Her voice warmer than before. "You have remembered your name and rank." Cold metal hits your toes, as they touch the rounded wall of the room. I am an artificial intelligence." <<endif>>\ [[Look at the names on the containers.]] [[Ask CINDI some questions.]]"$name. My name is $name." You brush your thumb against the text, feeling the grooves made in the metal to create each letter. <<if $nameCINDI is "yes">>\ "Congradulations, Captain Silva," says CINDI. Her voice warmer than before. "You have remembered your name and rank." Cold metal hits your toes, as they touch the rounded wall of the room. You let your feet plant themselves, amongst the containers stuck to the floor surrounding you. <<else>>\ "Congradulations, Captain Silva," says CINDI. Her voice warmer than before. "You have remembered your name and rank." Cold metal hits your toes, as they touch the rounded wall of the room. You let your feet plant themselves, amongst the containers stuck to the floor surrounding you. “My name is CINDI, the Cyber-INtelligence Direct Interface. I am an artificial intelligence." <<endif>>\ [[Look at the names on the containers.]] [[Ask CINDI some questions.]]Turning towards the containers, you notice the precision of their spacing. The nine cryogenic sleepers fit together on a grid, curving up along one side of the spherical room. Tilting your head, you can see the names engraved on the other chambers. |! |! |! | |Yusuf Basara|Sarah Noodin Day|Teenesee Jayplo| |Joshua Caval|Aleski Dolohov|Elliot Blanson| |Ana Dandara de Silva|$name Silva|Joana Silva| Two Silvas... You need to [[ask CINDI some questions.->Ask CINDI some questions.]]You're not sure where to look as you address the AI, so you start by looking down towards your feet, pushing you just off the wall, sending you hovering towards the opposite wall. [["Are there more people, in the containers?"]] [["That orb, is that you?"]] [["What's on the other side of the big door?"]]"Are there more people, in the containers?" You try and peer through the glass, but the frost is too thick. "Yes. Though not all of them made it." You glance back at the panel, and the red ovals. [["I see that."]] [["What happened to them?"]]"I see that." You wonder if these were people you once knew. "The journey was longer than anticipated," CINDI replies. "Longer than our calculations planned for. There wasn't enough oxygen to keep everyone alive." [["That's unfortunate."]] [["You murdered them?"]]"What happened to them?" You wonder if these were people you once knew. "The journey was longer than anticipated," CINDI replies. "Longer than our calculations planned for. There wasn't enough oxygen to keep everyone alive." [["That's unfortunate."]] [["You murdered them?"]]"That's unfortunate." You felt as if you should feel something more than you did. "It is. I mourn their losses." [["How did you choose?"]] [["I would have done the same."]] [["You shouldn't have done that."]]"You murdered them?" You felt an anger you didn't quite understand. "If that decision had not been made, all of you would be dead upon arrival. There was no choice." [["How did you choose?"]] [["I would have done the same."]] [["You shouldn't have done that."]] <<set $relCINDI to $relCINDI - 1>>"How did you choose?" There were four red ovals. The one directly to your right, two in the row in front of you, and another behind. "I attempted to judge each individual's complimentary merits for the mission at hand," says CINDI. "Quantifying this proved more difficult than anticipated. In the end I decided to choose at random. With the exception of you, of course." [["That orb, is that you?"]] [["What's on the other side of the big door?"]] [[Done with questions.->After questions]]"So we're on a mission." Eyes drift towards the sealed door and linger. "Without a designation number, any further information is classified." [["That orb, is that you?"]] [["What's on the other side of the big door?"]] [[Done with questions.->After questions]]"Why am I important?" Eyes drift towards the sealed door and linger. "Without a designation number, any further information is classified." [["That orb, is that you?"]] [["What's on the other side of the big door?"]] [[Done with questions.->After questions]]"I would have done the same." There were four red ovals. The one directly to your right, two in the row in front of you, and another behind. "I wonder if that is true," says CINDI. "Perhaps one day we shall find out." [["That orb, is that you?"]] [["What's on the other side of the big door?"]] [[Done with questions.->After questions]] <<set $relCINDI to $relCINDI + 1>>"You shouldn't have done that." There were four red ovals. The one directly to your right, two in the row in front of you, and another behind. "Your commentary on the matter is not required." [["That orb, is that you?"]] [["What's on the other side of the big door?"]] [[Done with questions.->After questions]] <<set $relCINDI to $relCINDI - 2>>"That orb, is that you?" Your eyes motion towards the orb. "Yes, that's me." Looking closer at the orb, it looked almost as if water were running along its surface, though without any particular direction. "My brain, one might say. Bits of me are everywhere in the ship." [["Are there more people, in the containers?"]] [["What's on the other side of the big door?"]] [[Done with questions.->After questions]]"What's on the other side of the big door?" Looking closer, you notice the grooves in the wall that presumably pull away once the round door has been activated. In your mind's ear, you imagine the satisfying sounds of gears behind the doors pulling the slabs of wall away, until they come to rest with a satisfying clunk. "Without a designation number, that information is classified." [["Are there more people, in the containers?"]] [["That orb, is that you?"]] [[Done with questions.->After questions]]The words feel like stabs into the dark, desperate attempts to find any kind of answer to hold onto. But asking these questions only makes you feel more lost. You pull at the recesses of your mind, grasping for any memory before the nauseating gas woke you up. There's nothing. Everything is nauseating. The bright lights. The door. The voice. Your body drifts and the room spins and you want to wake up from what can only be a nightmare. But even in dreams, you're supposed to remember your name. At least you have that, now. Something changes in one of the pods. You catch it, from the corner of your eye. You turn to face them, now directly above you. The frost is fading from five of the glass panels. [["You're waking them up."]] [["Wait, keep them asleep."]]"You're waking them up." You see inky white gas billowing underneath, flickers of faces. Nose. Eyebrow. Chin. "The sleepers are activating in accordance to their predetermined schedule." You look from one pod to the next. Yusuf. Sarah. Joana. Joshua. Teenesee. Each must be smelling the same sour gas that brought you back to life. [["Will they remember?"]] [["Did they know me?"]]"Wait, keep them asleep." You see inky white gas billowing underneath, flickers of faces. Nose. Eyebrow. Chin. "Keep them asleep until I know what's going on." "The sleepers are activating in accordance to their predetermined schedule." You look from one pod to the next. Yusuf. Sarah. Joana. Joshua. Teenesee. Each must be smelling the same sour gas that brought you back to life. "That program has activated, I cannot reverse it." [["Will they remember?"]] [["Did they know me?"]]"Will they remember?" You think you see an open hazel eye from Sarah's container. "If your memory loss was caused by a malfunction in your individual cryo chamber, then yes. But if something deeper within the system is broken… it's possible they are all in the dark, as well." An open, gasping mouth flashes from Joshua's container. "I suspect we shall find out soon." A fist pushes through the gas in Yusuf's container, and then snaps back. He must be struggling with the constraints, you think. The gas starts to fade away, and full faces begin to emerge. Teenesee's eyes are open, darting around as the ceiling comes into view for her. They rest when they find you, and tighten. Joana's mouth is wide open, throat vibrating. You hear nothing on the other side of the glass, but her screams are clear. Arms flailing. You see Sarah and Joshua's lips moving slowly. They must be talking with CINDI, trying to reason with her as you did. There's a panic in Joshua's eyes as he turns in his container, looking for the source of CINDI's voice asking for identification. Sarah's eyes find you, and then turn away, as she continues to talk with the artificial intelligence. Yusuf's lips are still as he feels the sides of his container, pushing at it as much as the constraints allow, looking for a weakness. Teenesee's eyes still rest squarely on you without wavering. Joana's eyes find you, floating above her. She stretches out a finger towards you, quickly pulled back to the container's base, redirecting her silent screams towards you instead of the sentient voice. [["They don't remember."]] [["They don't know me."]]"Did they know me?" You think you see an open hazel eye from Sarah's container. "They all knew you. You knew all of them. Whether they will remember you know, I cannot say. It is possible the malfunction causing your loss in memory was isolated to your sleeper." An open, gasping mouth flashes from Joshua's container. "I suspect we shall find out soon." A fist pushes through the gas in Yusuf's container, and then snaps back. He must be struggling with the constraints, you think. The gas starts to fade away, and full faces begin to emerge. Teenesee's eyes are open, darting around as the ceiling comes into view for her. They rest when they find you, and tighten. Joana's mouth is wide open, throat vibrating. You hear nothing on the other side of the glass, but her screams are clear. Arms flailing. You see Sarah and Joshua's lips moving slowly. They must be talking with CINDI, trying to reason with her as you did. There's a panic in Joshua's eyes as he turns in his container, looking for the source of CINDI's voice asking for identification. Sarah's eyes find you, and then turn away, as she continues to talk with the artificial intelligence. Yusuf's lips are still as he feels the sides of his container, pushing at it as much as the constraints allow, looking for a weakness. Teenesee's eyes still rest squarely on you without wavering. Joana's eyes find you, floating above her. She stretches out a finger towards you, quickly pulled back to the container's base, redirecting her silent screams towards you instead of the sentient voice. [["They don't remember."]] [["They don't know me."]]"They don't remember." All these faces, faces you should know. Names you should know. But as each slowly finds their way to noticing the body they see floating above them as they sit in captivity, you find nothing but fear and confusion and anger in their faces. "They do not. And, it appears, they believe you are responsible for their captivity." [["Let them out."]] [["Keep them there."]]"They don't know me." All these faces, faces you should know. Names you should know. But as each slowly finds their way to noticing the body they see floating above them as they sit in captivity, you find nothing but fear and confusion and anger in their faces. "They do not. And, it appears, they believe you are responsible for their captivity." [["Let them out."]] [["Keep them there."]]"Keep them there." You think of what must be going through their heads as they look up at you. "Keep them there until I can figure out what's going on." "Safety of the crew is paramount over security procedures. I must break protocol for them, as I have for you." [["I'm ordering you to put them back to sleep."]] [["My safety could be jeopardized."]] <<set $letOutJustification to "keep_there">> <<set $relJoana to $relJoana - 3>> <<set $relTeenesee to $relTeenesee - 2>> <<set $relSarah to $relSarah - 1>>"I'm ordering you to put them back to sleep," you say. CINDI does not reply. The silence is broken by the sound of five glass panels lifting and sliding off the chambers. In an instant, there's a cacophony of sounds. Yells and grunts from the people struggling against their constraints, turning into surprise as their released. And Joana's voice rising above the others. "What the fuck is this? What the fu--" She stops as she feels herself floating up from the container. Her confusion and anger is splintered by a moment of wonder at the sensation of weightlessness. Her shoulder-length curls dangling themselves in front of her face. Her eyes find you again, and the wonder vanishes. "Who the fuck are you, and what did you do to me?" Her eyes are red. "Why can't I remember shit?" [["I wish I could tell you."]] [["I didn't do anything to you."]]"My safety could be jeopardized by letting them out," you say. CINDI does not reply. What the fu--" She stops as she feels herself floating up from the container. Her confusion and anger is splintered by a moment of wonder at the sensation of weightlessness. Her shoulder-length curls dangling themselves in front of her face. Her eyes find you again, and the wonder vanishes. "Who the fuck are you, and what did you do to me?" Her eyes are red. "Why can't I remember shit?" [["I wish I could tell you."]] [["I didn't do anything to you."]]"Let them out." You think of what they must be hearing inside the chambers, that cold mantra of Name. Rank. Designation number. "CINDI, let them out." "I cannot let them out without the proper identification." She reaches out and tries to grab the neck of your jumpsuit, but its airtight against your body. All she does is knock you off balance. "You were talking to someone. It was that voice, wasn't it?" Looking around, you see the others emerging from their containers. Teenesee is lifting herself out, focused on the conflict above her. Joshua is attempting to stand in the low gravity, eyes dazed in confusion. Sarah is helping Yusuf untangle himself from his constraints. "How am I supposed to believe that? I wake up in a cage, see you standing over me." She's breathing fast, chest heaving. [["There's my sleeping chamber, look."]] [["I don't have to prove anything to you."]]"The voice is the ship's AI, that's all I know." Looking around, you see the others emerging from their containers. Teenesee is lifting herself out, focused on the conflict above her. Joshua is attempting to stand in the low gravity, eyes dazed in confusion. Sarah is helping Yusuf untangle himself from his constraints. "So we're on a ship? And there's an artificial intelligence? That's two more things than I know." She's breathing fast, chest heaving. [["There's my sleeping chamber, look."]] [["I don't have to prove anything to you."]]"There's my sleeping chamber, look." You point to the already open container you came out of. "That doesn't tell me shit." Her jawline tightens, accented by the bright light of the room. <<if $letOutJustification is "order">>\ "They told the computer to let us out." Teenesee is standing now, looking at Joana. She's taller than the rest of you, her head shaved. "They said: Let them out. As Captain, I'm ordering you to let them out." Joana turns to her. "Captain, they said? Interesting... that's a lot of things you know for someone who claims their brain is just as fried as mine." <<elseif $letOutJustification is "not_die">>\ "They told the computer to let us out." Teenesee is standing now, looking at Joana. She's taller than the rest of you, her head shaved. "They said: Let them out. You aren't going to let them die in there, like you didn't let me." Joana turns to her. "Sounds like they and the AI have a history. That's a lot of backstory for someone who claims their brain is just as fried as mine." <<elseif $letOutJustification is "keep_there">>\ "They told the computer to let us sleep." Teenesee is standing now, looking at you. She's taller than the rest of you, her head shaved. "They said: Keep them there. As Captain, I'm ordering you to keep them there." Joana turns to you. Her voice lowers, but trembles. Eyes stirring in fear. "The fuck is this? You call yourself Captain, have a bunch of living bodies stored here like a morgue." <<endif>>\ Yusuf turns to Joana, untangled from his constraints with the help of Sarah. "We have no more of a reason to trust you than them, or any of us." "Except they were already awake!" Joana points towards you. Sarah stands next to Yusuf, saying "Do we even have a choice of who to trust?" [['"We're family, Joana. She pulls herself back towards the container, and crouches to read the name. She does so slowly, with care. Running her thumb along the imprinted text. "I'm a Silva too," you say. "Does that mean you call me sister?" She turns to look back at you, gears turning in the back of her head. [["I guess so. Sister."]] [["I don't know."]] [["I don't know you."]]"I'm the Captain, so I was woken up first. Look at the side of my pod." You point to where your name is inscribed on the side. She pulls herself towards your container, and crouches to read the name. "Captain $name Silva," she says. "You're a Silva, too," you say. "Look at the inscription on yours." Joana turns to look at hers, reading her own name slowly, with care. Running her thumb along the imprinted text. "Does that mean you call me sister?" She turns to look back at you, gears turning in the back of her head. [["I guess so. Sister."]] [["I don't know."]] [["I don't know you."]]"I guess so. Sister." You grab hold of one of the sides of the room, and reorient yourself to be standing on the same floor as the containers, and the others. She looks at you with curiosity, the malice worn out. "I don't know you," she says, standing. Joshua has been watching without comment, bewildered. "So it's not just me. None of us can remember... anything?" The undercurrent of fear that each tries to cover up in their own way -- some through anger, or logic -- is bubbling to the surface. "My memory is a void." Yusuf's voice is low. Teenesee looks down. "Look we just, we have our names." Sarah's voice quivers but grows steady. "We use everything we can to try and figure out who we are." "We should [[spread out and look around.->Spread out and look around.]]""And where we are," you add. "Exactly." Sarah nods. "We should [[spread out and look around.->Spread out and look around.]]""I agree," you say to the group. "Let's see what we can find." Joana is turned away. Most give you back blank and confused stares. Sarah turns and looks around the room. You notice her left fist is clenched, her knuckles white, while her chest moves rhythmically up and down. "Joshua and Teenesee, go see if you can find anything from that panel. Yusuf and... the one who was yelling. Take a closer look at these pods, see if there's any other information besides our names. The Captain and I will go look at the door, at the far end." [[Question her.]] [[Follow her.]] <<set $locknum to 0>>"I thought I was the Captain," you say loudly, as Sarah begins to move towards the big wall. She turns. "You are," she says. "I have no interest in playing a game of hierarchy. But none of us know who we are, we barely have our names. So don't think I'm going to wait for you to bark orders before I do something about that." You turn to see everyone slowly moving towards their designated area of investigation. Sarah is on her way to the door, and you follow. "What do you think is behind this door?" she drags her fingers across it, there's a silent squeak. [["I couldn't begin to imagine."]] [["Whoever put us in here."]] [["Whatever we were sent here to find."]] [["Wherever we were sent to rot."]] <<set $relSarah to $relSarah - 1>>You turn to see everyone slowly moving towards their designated area of investigation. You listen, but hear only the slightly fainter sound of the ship's hum. "I could," Sarah replies quickly. "I'm imagining... too many things. Some horrible... some not so horrible. That's funny, isn't it? I can imagine so many possible futures without a single drop of my own past." She turns to you. "Are you scared?" [['"Yes."'->Yes ch1]] [['"No."'->No ch1]] [["I wish I was."]] <<set $relSarah to $relSarah + 1>>"Whoever put us in here." You listen, but hear only the slightly fainter sound of the ship's hum. All kinds of wonderful things could be behind that door. Or not." She turns to you. "Are you scared?" [['"Yes."'->Yes ch1]] [['"No."'->No ch1]] [["I wish I was."]]"Whatever we were sent here to find." You listen, but hear only the slightly fainter sound of the ship's hum. That's funny, isn't it? I can imagine so many possible futures without a single drop of my own past." She turns to you. "Are you scared?" [['"Yes."'->Yes ch1]] [['"No."'->No ch1]] [["I wish I was."]]"Wherever we were sent to rot." You listen, but hear only the slightly fainter sound of the ship's hum. "Well. I certainly don't plan on rotting." Sarah leaned closer to the door. "You're making the assumption whatever is... at most a couple feet in front of us is some horrible fate. All kinds of wonderful things could be behind that door. Or not." She turns to you. "Are you scared?" [['"Yes."'->Yes ch1]] [['"No."'->No ch1]] [["I wish I was."]] <<set $relSarah to $relSarah - 1>>"Yes." The word spills out. "Good. I'd be worried if you weren't." Her eyes glance back to the group. "I don't know where any of... us is coming from right now. What's left of us. If we're making it up on the spot, or if it's coming from who we were, leaking from behind the wall it's blocked behind. But I hope, whoever //you// are, however that //you// is coming into being... please be good." You look back with Sarah at everyone else. At your crew. "I wonder how you got to be Captain. We elect you? Assigned to us? Mutiny?" She turns back. "I guess we'll never know." You both hear a voice from the other end of the ship. "Hey! I found something." Teenesee's head appears floating sideways from the smaller door's archway, beside the control panel. "Storage lockers. With our names on them. And all we need to open them are our hands." She holds both of hers out. "And some weird suits..." Joshua, Joana, and Yusuf stand straight, and hurridly make their way over. "Can't have forgotten our hands, right?" Yusuf says on his way. You and Sarah join them. There is a small corridor through the door. Lining both sides are a series of lockers, nine total, each with a name on them, and a hand-shaped indent. On the far side is a large closet, one door pulled slightly to the side. In the opening, you see the arm of a clean white suit hanging out. It looks like a life-sized plastic model. "Look," says Teenesee, her voice bringing you back to the lockers. As she puts her hand against the locker with her name, there's a small hiss as the air decompresses, and it swings toward her. "I can open it." [[Look at the closet.]] [[Look at what's in her locker.]] [[Go find your locker.->Your locker]] <<set $relSarah to $relSarah +2>>"I'll be whatever I want." You stare ahead at the wall. "That's fine. Just saying I hope you want the right things," said Sarah, still facing forward. You both hear a voice from the other end of the ship. "Hey! I found something." Teenesee's head appears floating sideways from the smaller door's archway, beside the control panel. "Storage lockers. With our names on them. And all we need to open them are our hands." She holds both of hers out. "And some weird suits..." Joshua, Joana, and Yusuf stand straight, and hurridly make their way over. "Can't have forgotten our hands, right?" Yusuf says on his way. [[Look at the closet.]] [[Look at what's in her locker.]] [[Go find your locker.->Your locker]]You find a locker labeled $name Silva, next to Joana Silva and Ana Dandara de Silva. Joana is already opening hers up, positioning the ajar locker door to block your view. [[Open your locker.]] [[Don't open it.]]You look over her shoulder, to see what's inside. But, she lifts her hand. "First, I find what this tells me about myself. Then, I choose what I share with you." You step back, and see everyone looking for their names. [[Look at the closet.]] [[Look for your locker.->Your locker]]You go over towards the closet. Opening the door more, you see a series of these suits, and matching helmets, made of a thick glass. The cuffs of the suits have names on them, and symbols. There's a small triangle on yours. You recognize it as a delta. There's large boxes attached to the back. "They must be hazard suits of some kind," says Sarah, whose locker is close. "For whatever is beyond the door." [["I hope we get to use them."]] [["I hope we don't have to use them."]]"I hope we get to use them." You give Sarah a small smile, which she returns, looking down. "Go find your locker. We'll have time to figure out what to do with these later," she says, turning back to her hand scanner. You go back to the lockers. Soon, you find one labeled $name Silva, next to Joana Silva and Ana Dandara de Silva. Joana is already opening hers up, positioning the ajar locker door to block your view. [[Open your locker.]] [[Don't open it.]]"I hope we don't have to use them." Your voice sounds unsure. Turning to Sarah, you see she is as well. "Go find your locker. We'll have time to figure out what to do with these later," she says, turning back to her hand scanner. You go back to the lockers. Soon, you find one labeled $name Silva, next to Joana Silva and Ana Dandara de Silva. Joana is already opening hers up, positioning the ajar locker door to block your view. [[Open your locker.]] [[Don't open it.]]The imprint fits your hand snuggly, the material cold against your fingers. There's a green flash as the device reads your finger and palm prints, and identifies that you are, indeed, yourself. The hiss, again, as the locker door opens. Inside, you find nothing. The locker is empty. You feel the inside, looking for a hidden compartment, something you may have missed. But there's nothing. Quietly, you close the locker. "Not bringing anything to show and tell?" Joana asks as she hears the locker close. [["No. I'm leaving my things here."]] [["It was empty."]]You look at your locker, put don't press your hand against the imprint. "Not bringing anything to show and tell?" Joana asks as she notices your pause. [["I don't need what's in there."]] [["I can't trust whatever I find."]] <<set $locker to "unopened">>"I don't need what's in there," you say. "Where we came from doesn't matter. It's just what we do now." Joana looks down in the photo in her hand. "Seems to be there's no way to know what we're really doing here without knowing where we came from," she says. "But suit yourself." [[Ask Yusuf about the sphere.]] [[Ask Joshua about the papers.]] [[Ask Teenesee about what she's holding.]] [[Ask Sarah about the earrings.]]"Whatever I find in that locker can't be trusted," you say. "I won't risk someone trying to tell me who I was." Joana looks down at the photo in her hand. "Pretty fucking cynical to think someone would fake a family photo," she says. "I'm skeptical too, but don't be afraid of who we were, just because we lost that." [[Ask Yusuf about the sphere.]] [[Ask Joshua about the papers.]] [[Ask Teenesee about what she's holding.]] [[Ask Sarah about the earrings.]]"No. I'm leaving my things here." No one needs to know about this. "See how it is." She closes her locker. Between her fingers, you see what looks like a postcard or Polaroid photo. Looking down the hall, you see everyone looking through their belongings. Yusuf is holding some kind of digitally projected sphere, glitching on and off. Joshua pulls out what looks like sheets of paper, small dots and lines across it. Teenesee is inspecting something small in her hand, but you can't see what it is. Sarah is clipping something to her earlobes. [[Ask Yusuf about the sphere.]] [[Ask Joshua about the papers.]] [[Ask Teenesee about what she's holding.]] [[Ask Sarah about the earrings.]] <<set $locker to "empty_hide">>"It was empty." The whirlpool underneath your feet swings back as the words slip out. "Empty? Fuck." She closes her locker and turns to you. "This was in mine." She hands you what looks like a Polaroid. There are four figures in the photo, two in the back, one in the front, another in someone's arms. On the right, you see a smaller, younger Joana staring back. Her hair longer, smile wider. The two people in the back stood close. On the right, a tall lanky man, eyes blue and hair a dirty blond. Wry smile. In his arms, a child. Small enough to fit comfortably in the corner of his elbow and arm. On the left, a slightly shorter woman, brown eyes and tightly curled black hair. You notice her arm stretching behind the man's back, hand resting on his shoulder. [["It could be fake."]] [["We look so happy."]] <<set $locker to "empty_reveal">>"It could be fake." The cynicism tastes bad on your lips. "Doesn't feel fake." Joana shakes her head. "Feels like I had a family I loved and that loved me, and now all I've got is an empty head." The figures seem to be standing inside of some kind of glass dome. Through the glass, a dusty red and rocky landscape stretches out. Mountains stretch up in the distance, touching a sky at dusk, stars beginning to make their way out as a sun begins to hide behind the horizon's peaks. [["Where is that?"]] [["It's beautiful, wherever we were."]]"We look so happy." You try stretching your eyes wide, like they are in the picture. "Yeah. Yeah we do." As you keep your eyes on the photo, you can feel Joana's on you. The figures seem to be standing inside of some kind of glass dome. Through the glass, a dusty red and rocky landscape stretches out. Mountains stretch up in the distance, touching a sky at dusk, stars beginning to make their way out as a sun begins to hide behind the horizon's peaks. [["Where is that?"]] [["It's beautiful, wherever we were."]]"Where is that?" You're not sure why you're asking. "Fuck if I know." She sighs. "Bet my ass it's not where we are now." [[Ask to hold onto the photo.]] [[Give the photo back.]]"It's beautiful, wherever we were." It almost looked as if the liquid from the geysers sprinkled out into the star-scape. "How do we know that looks beautiful? If all we can remember seeing is these two fucking rooms?" She sighs. [[Ask to hold onto the photo.]] [[Give the photo back.]]"Do you mind if I hold onto this?" You tenderly hold the photo. <<if $relJoana >=0 >>\ "Sure. You didn't hold onto shit, apparently, so you probably were an asshole of a sibling. But maybe you don't have to be." She grabs your shoulder blade, and tries to give it a comforting pat, sending both of you floating away from each other in the microgravity. You're left with the photo. <<set $photo to "yours">>\ <<elseif $relJoana <0 >>\ "You didn't hold onto shit, that's on you. Not me." She grabs the photo back, tugging softly, to ensure it's not damaged. "Must have been an asshole sibling, anyway." She breathes in deeply, her lungs causing her body to rise, and then out. Her earrings rise for a moment, staying afloat in the weak gravity. They're a pair of wood-carved turtles, and seem to be swimming as they drift down to rest. "My mother gave them to me," she replies. "Told me so in a letter I kept. Apparently, I'm from a place called Earth. But I left it, a long time ago. And left her." <<if $locknum > 2>>\ [[Ask Joshua about the papers.->Into corridor]] [[Ask Yusuf about the sphere.->Into corridor]] [[Ask Teenesee about what she's holding.->Into corridor]] <<else>>\ [[Ask Joshua about the papers.]] [[Ask Yusuf about the sphere.]] [[Ask Teenesee about what she's holding.]] <<endif>>\Someone brushes your leg, and you turn to see Teenesee pulling herself through the corridor back into the main room. People turn, but don't follow. You move into the doorway. In hard syllables, Teenesee's voice rings out. Everyone's chatter falls silent. "Designation number: 06-11-2073." "Thank you for your designation number, Teenesee Jayplo." CINDI's voice had a hint of relief. "Clearance Level 3 unlocked. You are ready to receive the Mission Briefing." Teenesee exhaled and let her muscles loosen. You move back into the main room, and the others follow. She turns to you all. "How did you know your number?" Joana asks, walking towards her. "Rest of us don't remember shit, and you know your designation number." "I don't need to tell you how I found it." Her eyes didn't waver, her voice didn't raise. "Actually, you do." She pauses, breathing heavily. "Because I don't know shit about you. You don't know shit about you. So anyone keeping secrets makes me pretty fucking nervous." "Someone who picks fights with anyone he can makes me nervous." You notice her fist is still clenched. [['"Back off, Joana. What matters is someone found their code."'->Back off, Joana.]] [['"Teenesee, she's right. We have to know how you found the code."'->Teenesee, she's right.]]"Back off, Joana. What matters is someone found their code." She shoots you a glare, but doesn't retort. "Maybe CINDI can tell us what we're doing here. Where we are. We should focus on that." Teenesee sighs. "This isn't worth the argument." She opens up her fist. Inside is a small, silver ring. "I found this. In my locker. The numbers '06-11-2073' inscribed inside. I took a guess, that perhaps this number meant something to me and perhaps I chose it as my designation code. I guessed right." She looks to Joana. "I don't know what this means. Perhaps it means I am married. Or was. That I have children. Or did. That there were people taken away from me I can’t even remember. But I don't know. And I don't know if I want you to be a part of the journey I will need to take to find those things out." She slips the ring onto the fourth finger on her left hand. "We should ask the AI what we want to know." "Okay, I'll, uh, I'll start. CINDI--" Joshua searches for the right words. "Wh-- where are we?" The moment of silence between question and response feels eternal. "This vessel is currently located on the surface of the planet Proxima b, in the system Proxima Centauri." "What does that mean?" asks Yusuf. "We don't even know where we're from, what does a bunch of names tell us?" "It's something," responds Sarah, quietly. What propulsion does this ship have?" "This vessel is the first to use a faster than light drive. Yours was the first successful trip in recorded history." Teenesee looks directly to you. "We should find a way back. To... to Saturn. To this station. To wherever we came from." "What if they sent us here, wiped our minds on purpose? Sent us here for exile?" Joana asked. "I would appreciate it if you used it." "Answer his question," Teenesee insists. Silence. "Please, CINDI," adds Yusuf after a moment. "The drive is operational." There's a palpable relief. "However, there is no more fuel." "Fuel? What kind of fuel does an FTL drive need?" asks Yusuf. "That's classified," CINDI replies. "Classified? Fuck your classified! It's the operational input of the ship's primary engine!" Yusuf yells. "I really wish you had a face right now." "At the moment, I am glad I do not." Sarah's eyes seem sad, hearing this. Yusuf seems upset, though not at you. Joshua just seems confused. Silence lingers for a moment. The dark blue lights still pulse. Everyone drifts slightly in the air, no one exactly oriented in the same frame of reference. Your stomach is sinking again, the spinning making you feel like you're being pulled under something. You wonder if this is what drowning feels like. You wonder how you can wonder that, with no memories outside this metallic prison. <<if $relJoana < 0 >>\ "So what are you gonna do, Captain?" says Joana. Joshua seems taken aback by how loud he asks this. "The robot said there's a mission briefing. I don't want to debate the philosophy of privacy. I just want to know what's going on." "Under normal circumstances I would take offense at being referred to as 'the robot,'" says CINDI. "However, considering the situation, I will excuse this lapse in judgment. The Mission Briefing is prepared for viewing upon the [[Captain Silva's request.->Mission Briefing shortest]]"The lights dim as a screen is projected from the computer console on the far side of the room. The rectangular shape of the projection feels odd in the circular space, and you find yourself at an angle from the intended perspective. The projection shows a man, sitting behind a desk. The wall behind him has the text "PROXIMA" printed in large letters. The X styled the same as the one you've seen around the ship. "Welcome to Proxima Centauri. You brave souls. You lucky bastards." There's a grin that splits across his face. "This is the official mission briefing for Project Exodus." The projection slowly moves closer to the man, until his face takes up most of it. There's a weak stubble littering his chin and cheeks. "The nine of you are fulfilling the mission of this company since its inception: to bring humanity to the stars. Your goal is simple: identify and retrieve strands of the bacteria //Proximus fomes//, whose origins we have traced here. This biological material is the fuel for the Exodus Drive that powers the //Prodromos//, that will power the Arks to evacuate Earth. "Yours is the first ship to use this. The first, we hope, of many. But without those samples, these engines are worth nothing. Including the one on your ship now. The only way home is by finding that biofuel." The man at the desk leans forward. "I don't have to tell you how important it is that you accomplish this. He looks to off the camera to the right, and then back. "So, I'll just remind you: come back. Quick as you can. The Arks will be ready and waiting." It seems like he's done, as he leans back, until there's a twinkle in his eye. "Do try and have some fun while you're at it." His eyes got lost somewhere, the tip of his tongue massaging his lower lip. Until he snaps back. "Good luck out there, Captain Silva. This... all started with you. See it through." He gives a curt nod. "This is Ezra Caval, on behalf of the Proxima Corporation, signing off." The image cuts to the same logo that was printed on the back of the wall. "PROXIMA," with a jingle, just before the video comes to an end and the projection disappears. Lights begins to rise. Bouncing off the white walls. The X's marking the doors and the sleepers now given something to represent: the Proxima Corporation. [[It's comforting.]] [[It's unnerving.]]The lights dim as a screen is projected from the computer console on the far side of the room. The rectangular shape of the projection feels odd in the circular space, and you find yourself at an angle from the intended perspective. The projection shows a man, sitting behind a desk. The wall behind him has the text "PROXIMA" printed in large letters. The X styled the same as the one you've seen around the ship. "Welcome to Proxima Centauri. You brave souls. You lucky bastards." There's a grin that splits across his face. "This is the official mission briefing for Project Exodus. A reference point for what you already know. Something to... look back on, if things become less clear. As they often do... in the brush of this new frontier." The projection slowly moves closer to the man, until his face takes up most of it. There's a weak stubble littering his chin and cheeks. "The nine of you are fulfilling the mission of this company since its inception: to bring humanity to the stars. Beyond the Sol system we call home." The smile falters. "Your goal is simple: identify and retrieve strands of the bacteria Proximus fomes, whose origins we have traced here. This biological material is the fuel for the Exodus Drive that powers the //Prodromos//, that will power the Arks to evacuate Earth. "Yours is the first ship to use this. The first, we hope, of many. But without those samples, these engines are worth nothing. Including the one on your ship now. The only way home is by finding that biofuel." The man presses a button and images appear above his desk. A long cylinder, a small pill-shaped device, and what looks like a syringe. "To accomplish this task, you've each been equipped with a set of tools. The first is your Microbial Collector." The syringe-looking device is highlighted. "It is designed to ingest material from an environment -- liquid, rock, gaseous, what have you -- and detect if there is any biological material. If there is, it can connect to a Fuel Cell for storage." The cylinder is highlighted. The holographic images demonstrate this transfer of material. "These Fuel Cells not only contain your biosamples, but interface directly with the Exodus Engine. You'll notice there's a substance already inside these Fuel Cells. That's an activator, a substance that prepares this biological material for use in the engine. "The details aren't important. Leave that for the theoretical physicists. All you need to know is to find the bacteria we've tracked back to this planet, collect as much of it as you can, and come back." The objects disappear. The man at the desk leans forward. "I don't have to tell you how important it is that you accomplish this. He looks to off the camera to the right, and then back. "So, I'll just remind you: come back. Quick as you can. The Arks will be ready and waiting." It seems like he's done, as he leans back, until there's a twinkle in his eye. "Do try and have some fun while you're at it." His eyes got lost somewhere, the tip of his tongue massaging his lower lip. Until he snaps back. "Good luck out there, Captain Silva. This... all started with you. See it through." He gives a curt nod. "This is Ezra Caval, on behalf of the Proxima Corporation, signing off." The image cuts to the same logo that was printed on the back of the wall. "PROXIMA," with a jingle, just before the video comes to an end and the projection disappears. Lights begins to rise. Bouncing off the white walls. The X's marking the doors and the sleepers now given something to represent: the Proxima Corporation. [[It's comforting.]] [[It's unnerving.]]"Would you all shut up?" Joshua seems taken aback by how loud he asks this. "The robot said there's a mission briefing. I don't want to debate the philosophy of privacy. I just want to know what's going on." "Under normal circumstances I would take offense at being referred to as 'the robot,'" says CINDI. "However, considering the situation, I will excuse this lapse in judgment. The Mission Briefing is prepared for viewing upon the [[Captain Silva's request.->Mission Briefing]]"The lights dim as a screen is projected from the computer console on the far side of the room. The rectangular shape of the projection feels odd in the circular space, and you find yourself at an angle from the intended perspective. "This is our Earth, on its deathbed," says a voice. The projection shows an orb, hanging in the midst of the stars. White clouds spiraling about oceans. Blue encompassing almost all, islands of green and brown. Most with billowing smoke spiraling into the atmosphere. "As you take your first steps onto this alien world," the voice continues, "don't forget why we're doing this." The image fades, and soon the projection shows a man, sitting behind a desk. The wall behind him has the text "PROXIMA" printed in large letters. The X styled the same as the one you've seen around the ship. "Welcome to Proxima Centauri. You brave souls. You lucky bastards." There's a grin that splits across his face. "This is the official mission briefing for Project Exodus. A reference point for what you already know. Something to... look back on, if things become less clear. As they often do... in the brush of this new frontier." The projection slowly moves closer to the man, until his face takes up most of it. There's a weak stubble littering his chin and cheeks. "The nine of you are fulfilling the mission of this company since its inception: to bring humanity to the stars. Beyond the Sol system we call home." The smile falters. "Most of you are scientists. All of you have the hearts of explorers. But I remind you: we are in a fight for the very survival of our race. I know your first instinct will be learn as much as you can. Don't get lost trying to understand this place. There will be time for that, later. "Your goal is simple: identify and retrieve strands of the bacteria //Proximus fomes//, whose origins we have traced here. This biological material is the fuel for the Exodus Drive that powers the //Prodromos//, that will power the Arks to evacuate Earth. "//Proximus fomes// was discovered under the ice of Saturn’s moon, Enceladus. Soon after, it was discovered this alien microbial life can create small bends in space-time. The Exodus Drive uses that to enable faster-than-light travel. It's easiest to describe via analogy. These "bends" can allow a ship to be spun fast enough that it can be "skipped" across space-time to its destination. Like a small rock on a pond. "Yours is the first ship to use this. The first, we hope, of many. But without those samples, these engines are worth nothing. Including the one on your ship now. The only way home is by finding that biofuel. "Determining the permanent habitability of the planet is a secondary objective. If you encounter intelligent life, avoid it at all costs. Refer to CINDI's 'First Contact' protocol if necessary. "Those samples are essential. They take precedent over all else, including your own lives." The man presses a button and images appear above his desk. A long cylinder, a small pill-shaped device, and what looks like a syringe. "To accomplish this task, you've each been equipped with a set of tools. The first is your Microbial Collector." The syringe-looking device is highlighted. "It is designed to ingest material from an environment -- liquid, rock, gaseous, what have you -- and detect if there is any biological material. If there is, it can connect to a Fuel Cell for storage." The cylinder is highlighted. The holographic images demonstrate this transfer of material. "These Fuel Cells not only contain your biosamples, but interface directly with the Exodus Engine. You'll notice there's a substance already inside these Fuel Cells. That's an activator, a substance that prepares this biological material for use in the engine. "The details aren't important. Leave that for the theoretical physicists. All you need to know is to find the bacteria we've tracked back to this planet, collect as much of it as you can, and come back." The objects disappear. The man at the desk leans forward. "I don't have to tell you how important it is that you accomplish this. That you come back. We have contingencies in place to ensure the best of humanity can survive until your return, whether that's on Earth or elsewhere in Sol. But I can imagine it'll be easy to get... caught up in the most profound discoveries of our civilization. I wish we had more time to let you relish in that." He looks to off the camera to the right, and then back. "But we don't. So, I'll just remind you: come back. Quick as you can. The Arks will be ready and waiting." It seems like he's done, as he leans back, until there's a twinkle in his eye. "Do try and have some fun while you're at it. Legends need stories to tell, after all." His eyes got lost somewhere, the tip of his tongue massaging his lower lip. Until he snaps back. "Good luck out there, Captain Silva. This... all started with you. See it through." He gives a curt nod. "This is Ezra Caval, on behalf of the Proxima Corporation, signing off." The image cuts to the same logo that was printed on the back of the wall. "PROXIMA," with a jingle, just before the video comes to an end and the projection disappears. Lights begins to rise. Bouncing off the white walls. The X's marking the doors and the sleepers now given something to represent: the Proxima Corporation. [[It's comforting.]] [[It's unnerving.]]Lights begins to rise. Bouncing off the white walls. The X's marking the doors and the sleepers now given something to represent: the Proxima Corporation. [[It's comforting.]] [[It's unnerving.]]You find it comforting, knowing you're a part of something greater. But there's still so much you don't know. "I hope that was illuminating," says CINDI. "I am happy to answer whatever supplementary questions you may have." You look around at the confused faces of these strangers... your crew. "Wh- what's Earth?" says Yusuf. His voice quieter than before. It's the question you were all too afraid to ask. The question that reminds you just how much of yourselves has been lost. The moment of silence between question and response feels eternal. "Earth is the fourth planet from the Sun in the Sol system, and the birthplace of humanity. Once a paradise of biodiversity, it is now on the brink of inhabitability." "So we're running away," says Sarah. "From a planet that's dying." "You are the first explorers to journey beyond the Sol system, the first to begin the next chapter of humanity's interstellar journey!" says CINDI. "But yes, your planet is also dying." "I'll be right there with you, Captain," says Joshua. "Where do we start?" [['"Let's look at what we were sent here with."'->What sent with]] [["What do you all think?"]] [["We get more information from CINDI."]]"Let's look at what we were sent here with," you say. "We saw hazard suits back there, we haven't even begun to look through the rest of our supplies." "CINDI, what else did we bring with us?" asks Joshua. "In addition to the ESHE's: Exploratory Suits for Hazardous Environments, there is a host of scientific equipment, habitation constructs and supplies, as well as sample retrieval devices." "It's obvious, isn't it?" says Sarah. "The hazard suits, how far we've come, our backgrounds. We're explorers." "Maybe. But why wouldn't we have a way back?" asks Yusuf. "If we weren't sent here to die... maybe it was to start a colony." "Or maybe we were sent to find something," says Joshua. "Some valuable mineral they found here." "There's no way to know for sure," says Sarah. "So maybe we should take our best guess, and start with that." [[We must be explorers.->predict explorers]] [[We must be colonists.->predict colonists]] [[We must be here to find something.->predict plunder]] [[We were probably sent here to die.->predict go home]]"What do you all think?" you ask. "It's obvious, isn't it?" says Sarah. "The hazard suits, how far we've come, our backgrounds. We're explorers." "Maybe. But why wouldn't we have a way back?" asks Yusuf. "If we weren't sent here to die... maybe it was to start a colony." "Or maybe we were sent to find something," says Joshua. "Some valuable mineral they found here." "There's no way to know for sure," says Sarah. "So maybe we should take our best guess, and start with that." [[We must be explorers.->predict explorers]] [[We must be colonists.->predict colonists]] [[We must be here to find something.->predict plunder]] [[We were probably sent here to die.->predict go home]]"We get more information from CINDI," you say. "I would encourage you to consider the inventory of items you were sent with," says CINDI. "In particular, the ESHE's: Exploratory Suits for Hazardous Environments. There is a host of scientific equipment, habitation constructs and supplies, as well as sample retrieval devices." "It's obvious, isn't it?" says Sarah. "The hazard suits, how far we've come, our backgrounds. We're explorers." "Maybe. But why wouldn't we have a way back?" asks Yusuf. "If we weren't sent here to die... maybe it was to start a colony." "Or maybe we were sent to find something," says Joshua. "Some valuable mineral they found here." "There's no way to know for sure," says Sarah. "So maybe we should take our best guess, and start with that." [[We must be explorers.->predict explorers]] [[We must be colonists.->predict colonists]] [[We must be here to find something.->predict plunder]] [[We were probably sent here to die.->predict go home]]"We must be explorers," you claim. "Let's conduct experiments, find out everything we can. We're the first people to step foot here, as far as I can tell. If we ever do get back, let's go out and find some new knowledge to show for it." Sarah lights up. Others nod, some look confused and upset, but no one speaks up. There's agreement, and everyone peals off to [[prepare to leave the ship.->Exit ship]]"We must be colonists," you claim. "Let's establish a base, find a way to make this a home." Joana nods. Others look confused, or even upset, but no one speaks up. There's agreement, and everyone peels off to [[prepare to leave the ship.->Exit ship]]"We must be here to find something," you claim. "Let's search for resources, anything that could be valuable. Hopefully, when we find what we're looking for, we'll know it." Joshua exhales a breath it seems as if he's been holding in. Others look confused, or even upset, but no one speaks up. There's agreement, and everyone peels off to [[prepare to leave the ship.->Exit ship]]"We were probably sent here to die," you claim. "We should find a way back home. Let's go out there and find something that can help us fix this ship, I don't think there's anything to help us in here." Yusuf nods. Others look confused, or even upset, but no one speaks up. There's agreement, and everyone peels off to [[prepare to leave the ship.->Exit ship]]CINDI walks you through the preparations needed before exiting the ship. Consuming rations and water, releasing the little waste that’s accumulated in your bodies while frozen. She shows you the tubes that will deliver sustenance from within your suit, and assures that all waste will be absorbed and disposed by the suit itself. They slip on with comfort, the fresh padding lined inside squeaking against the lining of your thin jumpsuits. The material is snug against your body, not worn in yet. The helmet feels like a fish bowl. You, on the inside, and the world watching as your head swims about. The boots are heavy, sticking to any surface they make contact with. The stability feels comforting after so much floating. "Everyone ready?" asks Sarah. You all are standing near the door. [["We're ready."]] [["We're not, but have no choice."]]"We're ready. Open the door, CINDI." Behind you, two metal doors emerge from the sides of the ship and meet in the middle, sealing all of you in a small chamber. There's a whoosh, as the oxygen in the compartment is removed. You feel your suits flooding your helmets with thin, fresh air. Lungs feel heavy. Panting rings in your ears. After a few moments, the large circular component of the door in front of you begins to turn. On the right side of your head, you feel a cold swab. CINDI speaks to all of you from the ship. "Please prepare for the insertion of your personal Cybernetic Inter-Neural Direct Interface, to assist in the operation of your Exploratory Suit for Hazardous Environments." You feel the swab disappear, followed by a quick and painful puncture in the same spot. [["What the fuck?"]] [["CINDI, stop this immediately."]] [["Can you explain what this is?"]]"We're not, but have no choice. Open the door, CINDI." Behind you, two metal doors emerge from the sides of the ship and meet in the middle, sealing all of you in a small chamber. There's a whoosh, as the oxygen in the compartment is removed. You feel your suits flooding your helmets with thin, fresh air. Lungs feel heavy. Panting rings in your ears. After a few moments, the large circular component of the door in front of you begins to turn. On the right side of your head, you feel a cold swab. CINDI speaks to all of you from the ship. "Please prepare for the insertion of your personal Cybernetic Inter-Neural Direct Interface, to assist in the operation of your Exploratory Suit for Hazardous Environments." You feel the swab disappear, followed by a quick and painful puncture in the same spot. [["What the fuck?"]] [["CINDI, stop this immediately."]] [["Can you explain what this is?"]]"What the fuck?" You see the others are also confused. The door is still turning. "This is a necessary and standard procedure for exosuit use," CINDI replies. "Each of you signed a waiver in agreement for this procedure." The sharp pain is subdued by another swab, numbing the sensation quickly. As you blink, you start to see images on the inside of your helmet. There's an oxygen gauge, a small chart of your vital signs, and a circular icon. "Hello," you hear CINDI's voice. But not from the ship. This time, it sounds as if it was a thought you spoke to yourself. But, not in your voice. "Direct interface has been established. Please confirm." [["You're in my head. That's... convenient."]] [["You're in my head. Get out."]] [["Was this really the best time for that?"]]"CINDI, stop this immediately." You see the others are also confused. The door is still turning. "This is a necessary and standard procedure for exosuit use," CINDI replies. "Each of you signed a waiver in agreement for this procedure." The sharp pain is subdued by another swab, numbing the sensation quickly. As you blink, you start to see images on the inside of your helmet.
