It was only something I felt should be said," says CINDI. "Try and rest easy." <<endif>>\ The darkness and the quiet hollows you. The only sound is the waves as sleep envelops. <center>[[--->Dream 3: Sunset]]</center>(FIX TENSE) <center><img src="https://dl.airtable.com/GLMzDWVS8GX1XbkuRvJT_full_sunset_mars.jpg" width="473" height="380"></center>\ Issac wondered what sunsets on Earth felt like. He had seen what they looked like, in films and poetry. Like a squeezed orange drizzled down the atmosphere, he had once read. But that wasn't the same. "I want you to remember this," he whispers to the infant in his arms as the sun on the red planet begins to set. It was your last dusk on Mars and your 754th day outside of your mother's womb, and your father held you in his arms. [["I want you to listen."]] [["I want you to watch."]]"I want you to listen," he said as he tapped the side of his helmet with a spare arm. "How quiet it is." Looking down at your tiny body, held safe inside a specialized suit, Issac knew you wouldn't remember. So he listened for you. He listened to the rhythm of his lungs taking in air and taking out air, of his suit filtering out the used up air and putting oxygen back in. He listened to the crinkle the rock made between his heavy boots, and the special kind of quiet the blue haze made as it whispered its way down closer and closer to the horizon. The quiet seemed to sit all around him, even the rhythm of his breath slipping away as the sky slipped into the hum of twilight, and soon silence. "There it goes..." Issac says as the last afterglow of the sun fades away. He hears you start to cry through the intercom connecting your two suits. "Shh... shh... this is the best part." The stars had found their way through the sky's inky blackness, punctures of white in the void that somehow always made their nightly appearance. As of late, Issac had taken to viewing the spectacle as a map, like Earth's navigators of old. "That's where we're going," he pointed up to a dot with an orange haze. "To meet our neighbors." It felt unreal, even saying it now. But the data was confirmed: microbial life found in a stream of liquid, jettisoned from an underground ocean on one of Saturn's moons. Alien life was now fact. "You and me, and your mom. We're the ones who get to go say hello." Issac's words swelled with wonder. You gurgled. "There you are." She steps up from behind the both of you. "Thought you might be out here. Ana Dandara stands beside Issac, clunkyly putting her arm around him. Both your parents stand with you, in the dark of the Martian night. All wallowing in the quiet and the starlight. "Did you ever... hate your mother, for taking you here? Away from Earth?" asks Issac. "I did," says Ana. "But... I understood. I'd seen enough to know I couldn't stay." [["I always imagined Earth as this perfect place."]] [["I always imagined Earth as this desolate wreck."]]"I want you to watch," he said as he pointed from his eyes out to the view. "How beautiful it is." Looking down at your tiny body, held safe inside a specialized suit, Issac knew you wouldn't remember. So he watched for you. He watched as a haze of blue and gray blanketed the sky and the mountains and the dust. This was the last time he would see this site, he knew. This image only lasting in the canals of memory, easily tarnished. Easily replaced. He watched as the landscape soaked up all the light of day, as it was dipped in twilight, where it would sit and sog for some time before drowning into night. Soon, there was darkness. "There it goes..." Issac says as the last afterglow of the sun fades away. The wisps of red dirt and brown rock around them had all turned equally inky gray. The silhouettes of the distant mountains clawed up towards the heavenly sky. He hears you start to cry through the intercom connecting your two suits. "Shh... shh... this is the best part." The stars had found their way through the sky's inky blackness, punctures of white in the void that somehow always made their nightly appearance. As of late, Issac had taken to viewing the spectacle as a map, like Earth's navigators of old. "That's where we're going," he pointed up to a dot with an orange haze. "To meet our neighbors." It felt unreal, even saying it now. But the data was confirmed: microbial life found in a stream of liquid, jettisoned from an underground ocean on one of Saturn's moons. Alien life was now fact. "You and me, and your mom. We're the ones who get to go say hello." Issac's words swelled with wonder. You gurgled. "There you are." She steps up from behind the both of you. "Thought you might be out here. Ana Dandara stands beside Issac, clunkyly putting her arm around him. Both your parents stand with you, in the dark of the Martian night. All wallowing in the quiet and the starlight. "Did you ever... hate your mother, for taking you here? Away from Earth?" asks Issac. "I did," says Ana. "But... I understood. I'd seen enough to know I couldn't stay." [["I always imagined Earth as this perfect place."]] [["I always imagined Earth as this desolate wreck."]]Issac looks down at you. "Earth was always this... perfect place, in my mind. Even though I knew what had become of it. I couldn't stand living in a cave." "Now, you won't," she says. "And neither will our child." Night had fully settled into itself. The temperature was dropping rapidly. The suits would keep them warm, but nevertheless, they would need their rest for the coming day. "We should head back inside," said Ana. "You go on ahead, I'll join after a moment." Issac handed you over to Ana, and she took you back towards their habitat, up a short set of stairs hewn into the side of a basin. Issac remained, to savor his last evening on the planet. In the quiet and in the dark, Issac sunk himself into time, lodging himself into this particular moment. The wisps of red dirt and brown rock all equally inky gray. The silhouettes of the distant mountains clawing up towards the heavenly sky. And the stars. Piercing through some thin fabric to rain and speckle and shine among us, just for a time. Issac knew he would soon know those stars very well. "Hello, Issac." He knows that voice. But not like this. Not here, not yet. "Ezra," he says. There's a hand that falls on his shoulder, as the sand and rock kicked into the air by the wind seems to freeze. He remembers that voice. "Already?" "I'm afraid so," he says. Voice heavy. It all comes back to Issac, as he turn to face him. "How far have you gone?" asks Issac. His eyes notice the stars don't seem to be twinkling. "Far enough, I think." It seems as if he might say more, but he holds back. Issac looks down. Unable to bring his eyes to Ezra's. "Why are you here?" he asks. "To ask you a question." He lifts Issac's chin, forcing their eyes to meet. Ezra's not wearing a suit, only a Proxima uniform. He breathes the air without fear. There's a rare vulnerability in his eyes, his words. "I wanted to come here, before it all begins. Before you arrive." "Ask your question." The hand on Issac's chin slides to his cheek. "Will you forgive me?" There's complete silence, as the words hang on the still air. No sounds from Issac's suit. From the underground habitats nearby. There's only the knowing of what he has done. And the question. [['"Yes."'->Yes forgive]] [['"No."'->No forgive]]Issac looks down at you. "Earth was always this... desolate wreck, in my mind. I couldn't imagine what it must have been like before. This, here, is the closest I've ever gotten to living in the open air." "Soon, you will," she says. "And so will our child." Night had fully settled into itself. The temperature was dropping rapidly. The suits would keep them warm, but nevertheless, they would need their rest for the coming day. "We should head back inside," said Ana. "You go on ahead, I'll join after a moment." Issac handed you over to Ana, and she took you back towards their habitat, up a short set of stairs hewn into the side of a basin. Issac remained, to savor his last evening on the planet. In the quiet and in the dark, Issac sunk himself into time, lodging himself into this particular moment. The wisps of red dirt and brown rock all equally inky gray. The silhouettes of the distant mountains clawing up towards the heavenly sky. And the stars. Piercing through some thin fabric to rain and speckle and shine among us, just for a time. Issac knew he would soon know those stars very well. "Hello, Issac." He knows that voice. But not like this. Not here, not yet. "Ezra," he says. There's a hand that falls on his shoulder, as the sand and rock kicked into the air by the wind seems to freeze. He remembers that voice. "Already?" "I'm afraid so," he says. Voice heavy. It all comes back to Issac, as he turn to face him. "How far have you gone?" asks Issac. His eyes notice the stars don't seem to be twinkling. "Far enough, I think." It seems as if he might say more, but he holds back. Issac looks down. Unable to bring his eyes to Ezra's. "Why are you here?" he asks. "To ask you a question." He lifts Issac's chin, forcing their eyes to meet. Ezra's not wearing a suit, only a Proxima uniform. He breathes the air without fear. There's a rare vulnerability in his eyes, his words. "I wanted to come here, before it all begins. Before you arrive." "Ask your question." The hand on Issac's chin slides to his cheek. "Will you forgive me?" There's complete silence, as the words hang on the still air. No sounds from Issac's suit. From the underground habitats nearby. There's only the knowing of what he has done. And the question. [['"Yes."'->Yes forgive]] [['"No."'->No forgive]]"Yes," says Issac, scared. He puts his hand on Ezra's, pulling it down from his cheek. "I know your heart. It's up there, like mine." Ezra puts his own hand above Issac's. "Good." He nods to himself. The stars begin to stutter into sparkling, again. Ezra looks up, even as he seems to be fading. Issac can't stop his gaze from following. "Soon, it won't just be our hearts, Issac. I've made sure of it." "I know." There's a thirst and a terror in his eyes as he looks up. The stars like diamonds. Sharp. Shining far to bright. "Ezra--" But he's gone. Night has descended, there's only shadows. All Issac remembers are whispers. <center>[[--->Chapter 5]]</center>"No," says Issac, slowly. He puts his hand on Ezra's, pulling it down from his cheek. "I love you. But I cannot forgive you for this." Ezra puts his own hand above Issac's. "Okay." He nods to himself. Slowly, he lets Issac's hand fall. The stars begin to stutter into sparkling, again. Ezra looks up, even as he seems to be fading. Issac can't stop his gaze from following. "We'll get there, Issac. I've made sure of it." "I know." There's a terror in his eyes as he looks up. The stars like diamonds. Sharp. Shining far to bright. "Ezra--" But he's gone. Night has descended, there's only shadows. All Issac remembers are whispers. <center><b>[[--->Chapter 5]]</b></center><center>V.</center> The billowing of your habitat brings you out of your sleep. The sound, first. The wind's whistle, far stronger than you'd felt it the day before. And the cloth, turbulent even from the inside. Your suit thrown about as you open your eyes. The habitat's constraints holding you to one side. [[Unstrap yourself.->Unstrap yourself ch5]] [[Grab your suit pieces.->get suit on ch5]]You unhook yourself from the constraints of your bed. The shell of your helmet is thrown at you in the chaos, hitting your forehead. You wince, vision blurs, then steadies. You grab hold of the helmet, to ensure it doesn't hit you again, and begin to put on your suit. As you clamber into it, you can't help but notice the stench of it. A mix of sweat and stale air. [[Ignore it.->Ignore it ch5]] [[Complain.->Complain ch5]]You first locate the various pieces of your suit. The shell of your helmet is thrown at you in the chaos, but you manage to stop it from hitting you. After getting a hold of the other pieces of your suit, you unhook yourself from the constraints of your bed, and begin to put on your suit. As you clamber into it, you can't help but notice the stench of it. A mix of sweat and stale air. [[Ignore it.->Ignore it ch5]] [[Complain.->Complain ch5]]You ignore it, sliding your legs into the suit's pants. They're skinny, shaking. Thin. It's hard for you to remember the last time you've eaten. But you must have. It's difficult, wriggling on your gloves, securing your helmet as the habitat is thrown to one side. But you manage. [[Go outside.->Go outside. ch5]]"Oh god," you whisper under your breath, as you slide your legs into the suit's pants. They're skinny, shaking. Thin. It's hard for you to remember the last time you've eaten. But you must have. It's difficult, wriggling on your gloves, securing your helmet as the habitat is thrown to one side. But you manage. [[Go outside.->Go outside. ch5]]The cold bites you as soon as you unzip the habitat. It takes a moment for your suit to adjust its temperature modulation systems accordingly. There's a crunch as your foot steps down on solid ice. Your boots need to dig into it slightly to stay secured to the floor. The landscape is recognizable, but barely. There's still a shoreline. Thicker chunks of rock are mixed in with the sand. Some chunks of ice. The anchors of your habitats, placed close to the water's shore, are now partly frozen into the ground. At first glance, there's no trace of the forest, only lifeless tundra. Soft particles of a frozen liquid hang in the air, buffeted by the wind toward the inland. The frozen water stretches out before climbing to larger formations. The ice cliff-faces appear to be simple glaciers at first glance, but the longer you stare, you notice intricate and ornate structures. It's impossible to tell exactly what with the wind and alien snow. "Good morning, Captain," she says. "How were your dreams?" [["The environment changed, again."]] [["More memories, I think."]] [["It's not your business."]] <<set $bioAdd to 5>>"The environment changed, again. Ice can't just... appear." But there it is, beneath your feet. "Based on the changes over previous evenings, these vast changes should no longer be surprising," says CINDI. "But your dreams. Was there any pertinent new information revealed?" [["Ezra was in it."]] [["I saw Mars."]] [["Just nonsense."]]"More memories, I think." "Ah, that is what I hoped to hear," says CINDI. "Any pertinent new information?" [["Ezra was in it."]] [["I saw Mars."]] [["Just nonsense."]]"It's not your business." "Your wellbeing and mission success is, however," says CINDI. "Was there any pertinent new information?" [["Ezra was in it."]] [["I saw Mars."]] [["Just nonsense."]]"Ezra was in it," you say. "Talking with my dad... he wanted forgiveness for something." "That isn't right," says CINDI. "Ezra Caval never lived on Mars. He grew up on Earth, left to be one of the first to settle the Outer Colonies. He only met your father once he arrived at Cassini Station." [['"I know what I saw."'->know what I saw ch5]] [['"Then they're just dreams."'->just dreams ch5]]"I know what I saw," you say. "He was there, on Mars, with my dad." Turning around, you see the other habitats nearby along the shore. You think it's odd the others were able to sleep through this wind. [[Call out.->Call out ch5]] [[Feel for bodies in the habs.->feel for bodies]]"Then they're just dreams," you say. "Distorted reflections of memories... not the real thing." Turning around, you see the other habitats nearby along the shore. You think it's odd the others were able to sleep through this wind. [[Call out.->Call out ch5]] [[Feel for bodies in the habs.->feel for bodies]]"I saw a sunset on Mars," you say. "I think it was the last night we were there." "Yes. Your father often enjoyed those moments just before dark," says CINDI. "The doctors hated him for it. Always worried he'd take on too much radiation on the surface. But, he always took the risk." You raise your voice, hoping it'll carry through to their comms systems. You reach out, softly try and grab it, and all you feel is fabric. [[Ask CINDI where they are.]] [[Call out.->Call out ch5]]"CINDI, can you tell me where they are?" The device clicks as he keeps fiddling with it, the direction on the holographic globe coming in and out of focus. Spinning. It's hard to see, and though the suits keep you warm enough, the cold is still very much present. At the tips of your gloves. The ice at the edges of your helmet. Everyone is silent, following Yusuf as he looks for the markings on the ice floor. The only sound the crunching of the ice. Hours pass. The glacial formations in the distance grow closer. It's not one solid glacier, you start to see gaps. The ice shifts and reflects. You keep walking toward it. The sound of the crunches beneath your feet begin to change, reaching a higher pitch. It's not one solid glacier, you start to see gaps. The ice shifts and reflects. You keep walking toward it. The sound of the crunches beneath your feet begin to change, reaching a higher pitch. [[Look down.->Look down ch5]] [[Listen closely.->Listen closely ch5]]"Our mission takes priority. We have to go back to the ship." "My only mission is to get home," says Yusuf. "Joshua's footprints lead back in the same direction of the ship," says Sarah. "I need to go back there, anyways. To use the ship's computer to analyze the samples we've collected." "My goal is to find Joshua," says Yusuf. "But, these tracks lead in the same direction of the ship. We'll go together." Yusuf sets off quickly, walking to the side of the footprints he's discovered. You follow, with Teenesee and Sarah joining from behind. <<if $stateJoana is "alive">> Joana follows last, leg dragging.<<endif>> The patterns of your footsteps fall offbeat, each crunch adding a note to the chaos. It's hard to see, and though the suits keep you warm enough, the cold is still very much present. At the tips of your gloves. The ice at the edges of your helmet. Everyone is silent, following Yusuf as he looks for the markings on the ice floor. The only sound the crunching of the ice. Hours pass. The glacial formations in the distance grow closer. It's not one solid glacier, you start to see gaps. The ice shifts and reflects. You keep walking toward it. The sound of the crunches beneath your feet begin to change, reaching a higher pitch. [[Look down.->Look down ch5]] [[Listen closely.->Listen closely ch5]] <<set $relYusuf to $relYusuf - 1>>There's a mix of gravel and snow and ice under your feet as you try and retrace your steps, to where the forest used to be. Sarah occasionally will take a sample of the soil. Once you reach what was once the edge of the forest, there's the occasional fossilized sign of a tree. Circular branches etched into rock, preserved by snow and ice. Ringlets of what now seems ancient, and yet was yesterday. "These remains... they should be millions of years old," says Sarah. "The samples of bark we took yesterday were... thousands at most." [["Our instruments are useless."]] [["Another sign of accelerated evolution."]] [["Do you think it's possible we've... been here that long?"]]"Our instruments are useless." You walk on. "There's no sign of damage to our tools. It's just... they weren't designed to look at anything like this. Everything's different, down to the molecular level. I don't even know what to look for." More of these fossilized remains appear the further you go into the forest. They're not all branches, some are the imprints of leaves. You and Sarah spread out, walking among the mummified corpses of the trees. [["Maybe she left something, to tell us where she went."]] [["We're not going to find her, are we?"]]"Another sign of accelerated evolution." You walk on. "Maybe. But... we'd see the changes with our own eyes, then. Instead, we just see these shifts after every night of sleep. I don't even know if our dating is correct. Everything's different here, down to the molecular level. I don't even know what to look for." More of these fossilized remains appear the further you go into the forest. They're not all branches, some are the imprints of leaves. You and Sarah spread out, walking among the mummified corpses of the trees. [["Maybe she left something, to tell us where she went."]] [["We're not going to find her, are we?"]]"Do you think it's possible we've... been here that long?" You walk on. "I don't think so. We'd see changes in our bodies we wouldn't be able to explain, but... it seems silly to rule anything out. I don't even know if our dating is correct. Everything's different here, down to the molecular level. I don't even know what to look for." More of these fossilized remains appear the further you go into the forest. They're not all branches, some are the imprints of leaves. You and Sarah spread out, walking among the mummified corpses of the trees. [["Maybe she left something, to tell us where she went."]] [["We're not going to find her, are we?"]]"Maybe she left something, to tell us where she went." "It's possible." Sarah stops, looking around at the flat ice and rock stretching out. "You shouldn't have left her." [['"You're right."'->ch6 Joana right]] [["She could have put us in danger."]]"We're not going to find her, are we?" "I don't know, $name." Sarah stops, looking around at the flat ice and rock stretching out. "You shouldn't have left her." [['"You're right."'->ch6 Joana right]] [["She could have put us in danger."]]"You're right." You stop as well. "I made the wrong call." "We don't leave each other behind," says Sarah. "We have nothing else." [["We should go back."]] [["We should keep looking."]]"She could have put us in danger." "We're all in danger," says Sarah. "There's no way to stop that." [["We should go back."]] [["We should keep looking."]]"We should go back. She's gone." You look at Sarah, and she nods. You both turn back towards the shore. You hear a gasp. "Oh god." Sarah's stopped, staring at something in the ground. She brushes away some snow. "$name, don't-- you don't need to see this." [["She's gone?"]] [["I think I do."]]"We should keep looking." You continue ahead, scouring the ground for anything of Joana's. Sarah does the same. You hear a gasp. "Oh god." Sarah's stopped, staring at something in the ground. She brushes away some snow. "$name, don't-- you don't need to see this." [["She's gone?"]] [["I think I do."]]"She's gone?" You don't look back. "Yeah. She's gone." "That's all I need to know." Images creep into your mind, of what could have happened to her, but you push that away. As you start to walk away, Sarah joins you. Together, you travel [[back to the shore.]]"I think I do." You walk over. Sarah is leaning over what at first looks like another one of the fossilized trees. It takes a moment before you notice the lines in the rock resemble a face, certain crevices the edge of a cheek, a knot round like an eye. Jagged teeth lodged inside. You see the components, but their no longer shaped the right way. They rotate about each other, as if someone had spun a face around and around and around until it was a soup, and then frozen it in rock. There's a moment when you don't recognize the shapes as that of your sister where you think it might be beautiful. The moment passes and only the nausea remains. [[Cover it back up with snow.]] [[Walk away.]]You lean down, and push the snow around the area over the fossil. Sarah helps as well. Soon, there's nothing but peaceful snow. Sarah stands, hand on your shoulder, and helps you up. Together, you turn [[back to the shore.]]Sarah stands, hand on your shoulder, and helps you up. Together, you turn [[back to the shore.]]It's a quick walk back, and when you arrive, Yusuf and Teenesee are already gone. Their footprints follow Joshua's onto the ice. You [[follow.]]The patterns of your footsteps fall just out of sync with Sarah's, each crunch cascading after the other. It's hard to see, and though the suits keep you warm enough, the cold is still very much present. At the tips of your gloves. The ice at the edges of your helmet. You're both silent, following the markings on the ice floor. The only sound the crunching of the ice. Hours pass. The glacial formations in the distance grow closer. It's not one solid glacier, you start to see gaps. The ice shifts and reflects. You keep walking toward it. Soon, you see the figures of Yusuf and Teenesee on the horizon. Sarah calls out, and they wait for you. They ask if you found Joana, already knowing the answer. Sarah replies so you don't have to. The walking begins again. The sound of the crunches beneath your feet begin to change, reaching a higher pitch. [[Look down.->Look down ch5]] [[Listen closely.->Listen closely ch5]]Looking down, you notice the ice looks brighter, more hints of blue than before. The next step you take breaks through the ice. Your boot pulls you down, searching for something to hold onto, dragging your leg under the ice before the magnetic locks deactivate, finding nothing. <<if $Joana is "alive">>\ Joana notices first. "There could be biosamples in the water." [["We don't have time, let's move on."]] [["Okay, let's collect some water samples. Quickly."]]"Okay, lets collect some samples from the water," you say. "Quickly." Sarah smiles. "And I suppose you want to use my drone?" says Yusuf, with a scowl. "It's technically not your drone, just because you're carrying it," says Sarah. Yusuf pulls out a small disk shape from his pack, places it carefully into the air. There's a semi-circular strip he pulls off of one end, which snaps into a control mechanism. Yusuf swerves his arms, and the drone follows. Leaning his hands forward, the drone moves towards the opening. He opens a visual feed, projected between the two controls in his hand, showing the view from the drone. You watch over Yusuf's shoulder. He lowers his arms, directing the drone down into the water. You watch as the barren landscape of the surface transforms into a dazzling cascade of lights, shining through the light into the water below. It's beautiful, even though the light is dim. "Let's collect these samples and move on," says Yusuf. "Go deeper," says Sarah. "If there's a floor not to far, we're much more likely to find biological material there." Yusuf sighs and directs the drone lower into the water. There's less light, the further the drone goes down, but not many other changes. But the view begins to shake the deeper the drone goes, making it nearly impossible to see anything clearly. "Why are you moving it like that?" she asks. "I'm-- I'm not!" Yusuf replies. "It's the current, it's--" The screen freezes and then goes black. "We have lost connection to the drone," says CINDI. "Perfect. Great idea for a detour. I'm going to find Joshua." Yusuf's already forging ahead, and the rest follow. There are more holes, but you avoid them this time. They grow smaller, thinner as you approach the structures in the distance. Soon, they're gone altogether, and the ice is flat. It seems bluer than before, thinner perhaps. Teenesee takes a step, and leaves a crack in the ice. After that, everyone walks more carefully. Joshua must have as well, the prints became more and more faint. But Yusuf still manages to hold onto the trail. The structures rise, large and rounded pillars. Once you reach the base of the first, they grow even stranger. Each is slightly different than the other. The first are small, but soon grow larger and more complex. Some are rough, others perfectly smooth. Some with a base, others lodged into the ground. But they all hold an eerily familiar oval shape, like a stretched out skipping stone. The structures are all concentrating to one spot, circling out from there. As you get closer, it looks as if what is at that central point is just another one of the pillars. But beneath the ice, there's a silver shine. Long legs stretch out from it to keep it stable. It's your ship, coated in ice, but clearly there. [["It's still there."]] [["A piece of home."]] [["We can still go home."]]"We don't have time, let's move on." Yusuf looks appreciative as he turns back to the path ahead. Yusuf's already forging ahead, and the rest follow. There are more holes, but you avoid them this time. They grow smaller, thinner as you approach the structures in the distance. Soon, they're gone altogether, and the ice is flat. It seems bluer than before, thinner perhaps. Teenesee takes a step, and leaves a crack in the ice. After that, everyone walks more carefully. Joshua must have as well, the prints became more and more faint. But Yusuf still manages to hold onto the trail. The structures rise, large and rounded pillars. Once you reach the base of the first, they grow even stranger. Each is slightly different than the other. The first are small, but soon grow larger and more complex. But beneath the ice, there's a silver shine. Long legs stretch out from it to keep it stable. It's your ship, coated in ice, but clearly there. [["It's still there."]] [["A piece of home."]] [["We can still go home."]]"It's still there," you say, relieved. "The steps don't go there." Yusuf's still following the tracks, which veer away from the ship. "Oh, Yusuf." Sarah stops to glare at him. "It's right there, we can look for him after we get the data we need." "You can do what you want, I'm not stopping." He continues to walk, and Sarah looks to you. Teenesee shrugs and follows him. [[Go to the ship.]] [[Continue to look for Joshua.]]"I'm going to the ship," you say. "Yusuf and Teenesee, we'll find you later." Sarah nods, and the two of you make your way towards the ship. As you approach the ship, you think back to that first night, the shallow water, the twin moons. Looking up, clouds obscure most of the sky. "CINDI, open the airlock." There's a roar as the ship's gears shift, breaking away the ice coating the underbelly of the ship. The doors open directly above you, and you [[jump onto the ship.->Jump onto the ship.]]You push up from the ground, detaching, and fly up into the airlock. As soon as you pass the threshold, you feel warmer and more at ease, even as you crash into the closed blast doors on the opposite side of the airlock. Soon, you grab hold of the handle there and steady yourself. Looking to the side, you see Sarah's done the same. "We're in, CINDI," she says. You hear the rumble again, as the doors close. You reorient yourself, placing your feet on solid ground to face the doors. The compartment is flooded with breathable air, decompressing gas, and toxins to preserve the environment within the ship. Soon, the inward doors open, and you're inside once more. It's the same as you left it. The pods, still there, either empty or filled with corpses. The stale beauty of "brand new" after drifting through space time. Sarah rushes over to the computers, already looking for the data you need. [[Walk over to your mother's cryo chamber.]] [[Walk over to the computer where Sarah is.]]You walk over to the cryo chambers, seeing yours, Joana's. Your mother. Less than a dozen other names you're only just starting to recognize. But you linger on hers, looking down. The frost on the glass is almost all melted, and beneath you can quietly watch your mother. She looks calm, rested. So different from the face you've seen in your memories. Her hair cut down close to her scalp. Eyelids gently folded down. Lips relaxed, her neck sinking into the padding of the cryo chamber. [[Open the sleeper.]] [[Leave the sleeper alone.]]You put your hand on the glass, it's scanned briefly. CINDI's voice asks if you want to open the container, and you say yes. There's a hiss as the decompression begins. You think back to just days ago, when that gas filled your lungs. That fear. Confusion. Nothing crossed her face. Still serene. The glass opens, and a stale smell wafts up. You see her arms tucked in at her side, strapped down inside the chamber. It's strange, how still she is. Bodies are never that still. [[Tell Sarah you want a burial.]] [[Close the sleeper.]]You leave her there, and decide to move on. [[Walk over to the computer where Sarah is.]] [[Leave to look for Joshua.->Continue to look for Joshua.]]In silence, you reactivate the sleeper, and the glass slides back over her. [[Walk over to the computer where Sarah is.]] [[Leave to look for Joshua.->Continue to look for Joshua.]]"We should bury her." Your words drift to Sarah on dead air. "When we get back home, we will." She stays at her computer. [["We should have one here."]] [['"Okay."'->Okay close sleeper]]"Okay." You slump down, as you reactivate the sleeper, and the glass slides back over her. [[Walk over to the computer where Sarah is.]] [[Leave to look for Joshua.->Continue to look for Joshua.]]"We should have one here." You stand a bit taller. "On the planet?" Sarah turns. "There are so many reasons we can't do that." [["For all of them, not just her."]] [["None of our rules make sense here."]]"For all of them, not just her." You turn to look at her. "They all came here for one reason, or left for another. We should respect that, and let them rest here." "Human corpses are infested with contaminants." Sarah is aghast. "We cannot allow those variables to enter into this environment that already is so volatile." [["Trust me, we should do this."]] [["I'm Captain, I say we're doing this."]] [["You're right, this is a bad idea."]] <<set $funeral to "everyone">>"None of our rules make sense here." [[Walk over to the computer where Sarah is.]] [[Leave to look for Joshua.->Continue to look for Joshua.]]<<if $funeral is "everyone">>\ It's not easy, to pull each body out of their sleepers and into the thin body bags. Limbs floating in the low gravity, as if arms and legs are reaching for something even in death but it's just dead flesh adrift, and you pull them back and stuff them into the bags. It's easier, then, to pull the bags down from the ship and out onto the ice. Your beam emitter melts through a thinner section of ice. The body bags float on the water, side by side.. [[Walk over to the computer where Sarah is.]] [[Leave to look for Joshua.->Continue to look for Joshua.]]You walk over to Sarah by the computer console. "Finding what we need?" "Some of it," she says. "We've collected $bioSamples samples, filling about $canNum of our cannisters. But... what we found, on Enceladus, what we built our engine around was just one specific microbe. Here, we've picked up... thousands of different species, in each of our samples. It's hard to know what will and won't work with our engine." The console is large, with dozens of windows open alongside each other. Most displaying complex molecular structures, others topographic data from the drones and schematics of the //Prodromos// and Exodus Drive. "This planet can look desolate, but it's... teeming with life, in its soil and water and air. It'll take years... lifetimes to properly research everything we've found." [["We don't have years."]] [["Soon, we'll have the time."]]"We don't have years," you say. "All that matters is we know enough to use them for the Exodus Drive." Sarah looks down at the panel, comparing molecular structures. To you, it all looks like nonsense. "I think the best course forward is to find the microbial species that's closest to what we designed the drive for. And... hope that's enough. It's just... each day, the samples we collect mutate, despite having similar traits." [[Ask about the different species.]] [[Ask about the mutations.]] [[Ask about the environmental shifts.]]"Soon, we'll have the time," you say. "But first we need to learn enough to properly fuel the Exodus Drive." Sarah looks down at the panel, comparing molecular structures. To you, it all looks like nonsense. "I think the best course forward is to find the microbial species that's closest to what we designed the drive for. And... hope that's enough. It's just... each day, the samples we collect mutate, despite having similar traits." [[Ask about the different species.]] [[Ask about the mutations.]] [[Ask about the environmental shifts.]]"Tell me more about how these different species interact," you say. "That's one way they seem to be similar to microbiology as it should be," she says. "Or... how I think it should be. The different species can use quorum sensing to communicate, fight for resources and even attack each other. That activity was seen early on when samples were put into our cannisters. But the activating agent within seems to be subduing them." [[Ask about the mutations.]] [[Ask about the environmental shifts.]] [[Done with questions.->Done bio questions]]"Tell me more about the mutations," you say. "Well, it's complicated," says Sarah. She pulls up half a dozen sets of molecular structures. "There's the obvious differences between microbial species... separate protein structures, organelles, some are bacteria, others are fungi -- there's a lot going on." She picks one of these structures, and expands it, while hiding the others. With a brush of her hand, a line of repeating structures expands out. "But let's take a look at one of these species. This is data collected from samples over the last few days that clearly are a part of the same species. But, their mutations make no sense." You start to notice small aberrations from one image to the next. "There's the obvious, that none of this should be able to happen this fast, on the scale of days. But even if we ignore that... everything's out of order. Mutation and evolution has to build and change what came before. "We have four days of data, including today. Which isn't enough to make conclusive statements, but I'll conjecture with what we have. Samples from our first night on this planet show a host of functions not even hinted at in any day since-- the ability to survive with little to no light or energy, have complex communications, survive independently or co-dependently. "But the samples from the next day seemed to revert, containing almost none of these traits, despite having the same originating structure. There's a more natural progression to the third day's samples, from the forest biome, but look at this." She highlights the examples from the second and third days. "In the forest biome, this microbial species was able to biologically link with the environments fauna, as if they were living symbolically. That's normal. Life at all scales on Earth evolves to be codependent. Here, the microbe has enzymes that allow it to share energy with the plant structures. But now, look back to our Day 2 samples." She points back to the analysis on the left. "That enzyme -- and others -- aren't developed yet, but its structure is already making space for them. Before there was any sign of plantlife. It's like the mutation was... anticipatory. I've never seen anything like that." All the biochemistry is over your head, but you can see the spaces in the webbing of the microbial structure from the image on the left seems to be filled on the right. And the spaces seem specific, carved out among the microscopic patterns of the single-celled-organism's structure. [["It's a coincidence."]] [["It knew what it would evolve into."]] [["What about the samples from today?"]]"What about the samples from today?" you ask. "It's all gone," she says. "There's even less complexity and structure than from our Day 2 samples. But still... there's the shapes of what was there the day before. In the same way the Day 2 samples showed the shapes of what was to come." [["It's a coincidence."]] [["It knew what it would evolve into."]]"It's a coincidence," you say. "I'm sure our evolutionary history has many flukes that allowed us to survive." "It could be," she says. "Especially with such little data, all of this could be an anomaly... that's the most likely answer. But I've never seen any organism... prepare itself for genetic mutation like this. Evolution happens because of trial and error. Not foresight." [[Ask about the different species.]] [[Ask about the environmental shifts.]] [[Done with questions.->Done bio questions]]"It knew what it would evolve into," you say. "Somehow, it could anticipate its future needs." "But that's impossible," she says. "There's no way for any organism, much less a microorganism, to both predict its future biological environment so accurately and genetically modify itself in anticipation for that. Evolution happens because of trial and error. Not foresight." [[Ask about the different species.]] [[Ask about the environmental shifts.]] [[Done with questions.->Done bio questions]]"Does this tell us anything about the rapid changes in the environment?" you ask. "No, not really," says Sarah. "On the molecular level, the active changes we're observing seem to be at a regular pace. But overnight, not only does the geographic environment transform, so does the microbial one. Our new samples are mutated from what we've seen without explanation, but the ones we've already collected don't. They stay as they were." [[Ask about the different species.]] [[Ask about the mutations.]] [[Done with questions.->Done bio questions]]The barrage of data is overwhelming. Sarah notices your reaction, and dims the computer screen. "Beyond all the jargon, what it all means is that we're on the deep end of something we couldn't begin to understand," she says. "And, we're blind... bumbling about without more than a video clip to tell us why we're here." [["It sounded so simple."]] [["It's what I expected."]]"It sounded so simple," you say. "Collect these samples, and go home." "Life is never simple. And I don't trust anyone who pretends like it is." Sarah's eyes move past you, towards one of the enormous "X"'s adorning the walls. CINDI interjects. "Moving forward, I have adapted your sample collection interface to do a live analysis of its biological structure, categorizing it in proximity to our samples found in Sol. This should help you identify how many collected samples are compatible with the Exodus Drive." "Thanks, CINDI," says Sarah. "At least that'll help us get home." [[Walk over to your mother's cryo chamber.]] [[Leave to look for Joshua.->Continue to look for Joshua.]]"It's what I expected," you say. "The instructions we were given sounded far too simple." "Life is never simple. And I don't trust anyone who pretends like it is." Sarah's eyes move past you, towards one of the enormous "X"'s adorning the walls. CINDI interjects. "Moving forward, I have adapted your sample collection interface to do a live analysis of its biological structure, categorizing it in proximity to our samples found in Sol. This should help you identify how many collected samples are compatible with the Exodus Drive." "Thanks, CINDI," says Sarah. "At least that'll help us get home." [[Walk over to your mother's cryo chamber.]] [[Leave to look for Joshua.->Continue to look for Joshua.]]"I'm going to keep looking for Joshua," you say. "We'll come back with him to the ship." Sarah nods, and continues towards the ship. You run after Yusuf and Teenesee. The footprints weave through the forest of ice formations, leading you away from the ship. As you walk close to them, you notice entrances at the base of some of the ice structures. Some are sizable holes at its base, others doors or windows several feet up. "Here," says Yusuf, coming to a stop. "The tracks stop here, and point towards that." He points at a nearby ice structure. It's particularly round on the outside, with an opening close to the ground. Inside, you see hints of ornate patterns, corridors, and open spaces. "Joshua must be inside." <<if $stateJoana is "looped">>\ "More than him," says Joana. "There are others." <<elseif $stateJoana is "bulbed">>\ "There's something with him," says Joana. <<endif>>\ Yusuf walks directly below it, under the opening, and jumps up towards it. He tries to grab an edge of the opening, but can't hold onto the ice. "Shit," he says, as he moves towards the ceiling. "Idiot," says Teenesee. She follows, but activates the spikes of her gloves, allowing her to easily grab hold of the ice and carefully pull herself inside the structure. [[Use the spikes.]] [[Don't use the spikes.]]The footprints weave through the forest of ice formations, leading you away from the ship. As you walk close to them, you notice entrances at the base of some of the ice structures. Some are sizable holes at its base, others doors or windows several feet up. "Here," says Yusuf, coming to a stop. "The tracks stop here, and point towards that." He points at a nearby ice structure. It's particularly round on the outside, with an opening close to the ground. Inside, you see hints of ornate patterns, corridors, and open spaces. "Joshua must be inside." <<if $stateJoana is "looped">>\ "More than him," says Joana. "There are others." <<elseif $stateJoana is "bulbed">>\ "There's something with him," says Joana. <<endif>>\ Yusuf walks directly below it, under the opening, and jumps up towards it. He tries to grab an edge of the opening, but can't hold onto the ice. "Shit," he says, as he moves towards the ceiling. "Idiot," says Teenesee. She follows, but activates the spikes of her gloves, allowing her to easily grab hold of the ice and carefully pull herself inside the structure. [[Use the spikes.]] [[Don't use the spikes.]]You follow Teenesee's example, jumping up and using the spikes to maneuver yourself into the structure. Once you're inside, it's surprising how easily you're able to navigate the interior. It all feels oddly natural. Round corridors that open up into larger spaces. It's not that there was a clear pattern, if anything, the structure was objectively a maze. But it was one you had an intuition for, Yusuf especially. But his concentration didn't waver to admire the ice sculpture's architecture. Instead, he was looking for any sign of a dent in the smooth ice, a sign someone else had traveled through the space in a Proxima suit. But before anyone sees him, there's his voice. "I'm sad for you," Joshua tells someone. It's not from the comms, so you know he must be close. It's hard to tell where, the sound must be bouncing off the tunnels of ice. Yusuf looks up, and your eyes follow. There's what looks like a shadow hovering on the other side of the ice above you, four spots. Two sets of footprints. "He's there." Yusuf moves down the corridor, looking for a way up there. "You did all this... for your own loneliness." There's a sneer to his voice. Then it screams. "Say something!" Yusuf finds an opening leading up and begins to ascend. You [[follow.->follow ch5]]You follow Yusuf's example, jumping up and trying to fumble your way to stability. As you flail inside the structure's opening, Teenesee grabs your arm and pulls you into the interior. Once you're inside, it's surprising how easily you're able to navigate the interior. It all feels oddly natural. Round corridors that open up into larger spaces. It's not that there was a clear pattern, if anything, the structure was objectively a maze. But it was one you had an intuition for, Yusuf especially. But his concentration didn't waver to admire the ice sculpture's architecture. Instead, he was looking for any sign of a dent in the smooth ice, a sign someone else had traveled through the space in a Proxima suit. But before anyone sees him, there's his voice. "I'm sad for you," Joshua tells someone. It's not from the comms, so you know he must be close. It's hard to tell where, the sound must be bouncing off the tunnels of ice. Yusuf looks up, and your eyes follow. There's what looks like a shadow hovering on the other side of the ice above you, four spots. Two sets of footprints. "He's there." Yusuf moves down the corridor, looking for a way up there. "You did all this... for your own loneliness." There's a sneer to his voice. Then it screams. "Say something!" Yusuf finds an opening leading up and begins to ascend. You [[follow.->follow ch5]]The vertical corridor is thin, but easy to slide up through in the low gravity. "This would be the engine room," says Yusuf, above you. "If this really is a replica of the //Prodromos.//" Yusuf reaches the room's entrance, and pulls you and the others up after. Joshua is at the other side of what is large spherical space, one opening you and your crew came through, and another at the other end. There's another in the ceiling. Other than that, the surface is perfectly smooth. Joshua's back is to you, facing the shadow you saw from below. It's the same silhouette you saw in the desert. In this closed space, it looks strangely less imposing. The shape vaguely human, as before, still shifting. It looks more like an oddly shaped storm cloud than anything. It seems like its two arms are on Joshua's shoulders. "Please," he says. Quiet, now. "Don't let these things be true." [[Interrupt.->Interrupt ch5]] [[Say nothing.->Say nothing ch5]]"Let what be true?" you ask. Yusuf gives you a sharp look, before Joshua turns. "You... all of you found me," he says. "Just step away from... that thing," says Yusuf, moving forward slowly. The figure seems to fold into itself, and once it folds out, it appears as Ana Dandara. [["Mom, is that you?"]] [["You're not my mother."]] <<if $Joana is "dead">>[["Is Joana with you?"]]<<endif>>"Joshua, it's okay," says Yusuf, stepping forward. "We're here." Joshua turns, slowly. "You... all of you found me," he says. "Just step away from... that thing," says Yusuf. The figure seems to fold into itself, and once it folds out, it appears as Ana Dandara. [["Mom, is that you?"]] [["You're not my mother."]] <<if $Joana is "dead">>[["Is Joana with you?"]]<<endif>>"Mom, is that you?" The figures eyes meet yours. Curious. <<if $Joana is "alive">>Joana walks forward. "Uncle Amarizio..."<<endif>> "That's... it's my dad." Yusuf turns to you. Teenesee's face is frozen, eyes more reflective as they take on light tears, fists clenched but still shaking. All you see is the face of your mother, just as she sat in cryo. Frozen, motionless. This replica not even breathing. "It's... not him, is it?" says Joshua. "Not really." There's a strange mix of relief and pain on his face. Joshua puts his feet down, and turns to face all of you. "Doesn't matter if it's not them," he says. "Only matters if what they say is true." Joshua steps forward, passing through the shimmering figure. It reforms around him. Yusuf stands as well, confused. Joshua reaches an edge of the sphere. You know that thing isn't Ezra, or Elliot or anyone." Joshua puts his feet down, and turns to face all of you. "Doesn't matter if it's not them," he says. "Only matters if what they say is true." Joshua steps forward, passing through the shimmering figure. It reforms around him. Yusuf stands as well, confused. Joshua reaches an edge of the sphere. He leans his head back, and thrusts it forward against the wall of ice. A crack reverberates through the room as his helmet makes contact with the ice. You see the adhesive that patched the breach from his fall splintering. [[Try and stop him.->stop him ch5]] [[Do nothing.]]You lunge at Joshua, trying to pull him back. Yusuf does as well. But it's too late. Another bang against the wall is all it takes to shatter the helmet's glass completely. You hear Joshua gagging on the air for a moment or two. But then it goes silent, and he turns. No heaving chest. No struggling breaths. Just still. "I have lungs," says Joshua, plainly. "But I don't need them." From within the shattered remains of his helmet, he looks around, stretching out his arms. "It's odd... to remember you're not human. That it's something you can forget." "No," says Yusuf, his face blank. "It's that-- thing! It's a trick!" He draws his beam emitter and fires it at the figure behind Joshua. The shadow explodes in an instant. Slicing through the air and lodging itself throughout the ice of the structure. Black paint spiraling and oozing inside the ice. You think some strikes Joshua, but you're not sure. <<if $Joana is "alive">>\ Joana lunges her arm up, beam emitter in hand, pointing it at Joshua. Her movements sharp. [["Joshua doesn't need to be human to be a person."]] [["Yusuf's right, this is a trick."]] [[Say nothing.->Say nothing end ch5]]"Joshua doesn't need to be human to be a person," you say. "He's a part of this crew, like CINDI, like each of us." "But he's //not// like CINDI," says Yusuf. "Don't you see? They're trying to use these lies to split us apart. Stop us from doing what we came here to do." "We can't do what we came here to do." Joshua's voice is firm, moreso than you've ever heard before. "It doesn't make a difference, what I am. That's not what's important." He walks back from Yusuf. "We can't leave this planet. We can't let him win." "Joshua, stop this," says Yusuf. "Let who win?" His lip trembles. Mouth opens and closes. He can't find the words for all he's seen. "What you saw is only a drop in an ocean. But we have proven it true, so the rest must be as well. There's... a colossal shape we're a part of. I see that now." <<if $Joana is "alive">>\ "I... see that, too," says Joana. <<endif>>\ [["If we stay here, we break?"]] [["You're delusional."]] <<set $relJoshua to $relJoshua - 1>>"We don't need to break anything," you say. I see that now." <<if $Joana is "alive">>\ "I... see that, too," says Joana. <<endif>>\ [["If we stay here, we break?"]] [["You're delusional."]]"And if we stay here, we... break?" you ask. "If we stay, it all breaks," says Joshua. "We stay, we die, we don't go back. Doesn't matter if it's a day or decades from now. It must be done." "Don't give us this bullshit," says Yusuf. "I know you're hurting. I know you're reeling from this loss you've just uncovered, but you don't need to make all this up. We can help you." The strange confidence Joshua had breaks. Without his helmet, you see water pooling about his eyes. Frost dusting his cheeks. "I feel anger because I know there's so much more I haven't recovered. Moments I'll never have back. Pieces of us, of him.... And even know, with the shards I have... I want... I don't know what I want. I want to stay here. I want him to be here, I... I..." The tears freeze at the corners of his eye. "I can't go back, Yusuf. I just can't. I don't have the words to explain..." His voice trails. "Ezra built me for a purpose. I don't understand it, fully. But I know I must refuse it. And... somehow, this place is giving us back what we've lost. For me, it's giving back Elliot. I don't think that'll happen when we get back on our ship. Go home. I don't want to miss a morsel of him, so... I'm not leaving." [["We don't know if we're welcome here."]] [["It's okay, I understand."]] [["I want to stay too."]] <<set $relJoshua to $relJoshua + 1>>"You're delusional," you say. "And if we return home, we will only expand the sickness that brought us here. We must stay here, die here, and not go back. Doesn't matter if it's a day or decades from now. It must be done." "Don't give us this bullshit," says Yusuf. "I know you're hurting. I know you're reeling from this loss you've just uncovered, but you don't need to make all this up. We can help you." The strange confidence Joshua had breaks. Without his helmet, you see water pooling about his eyes. Frost dusting his cheeks. "I feel anger because I know there's so much more I haven't recovered. But I know I must refuse it. And... somehow, this place is giving us back what we've lost. For me, it's giving back Elliot. I don't think that'll happen when we get back on our ship. Go home. I don't want to miss a morsel of him, so... I'm not leaving." [["We don't know if we're welcome here."]] [["It's okay, I understand."]] [["I want to stay too."]] <<set $relJoshua to $relJoshua - 2>>"We don't know if we're welcome here," you say. "We may not be," he says. "But if we go back, they'll bring more. Here, elsewhere. It'll be worse." Yusuf's face looks empty. "What are you saying? You'll die if you stay here. Don't be stupid. Don't pretend you can do this. You could barely make it off the ship on your own. You're coming back. You wouldn't survive a day. I'm going to take you back." Joshua looks down, shaking his head. "You're not going to." "CINDI, release a toxin into Joshua's suit to knock him unconscious," says Yusuf. "I... am not authorized to do that, Yusuf. I cannot harm one of you." Yusuf begins to move towards Joshua, but he's already pulled out his beam emitter as Yusuf starts to move forward. "I know you've got some trick up your sleeve. You built these things, with some mechanism to lock them in place. Render me unconscious. But CINDI won't do your dirty work. You'll have to come over here to get it." Yusuf slowly takes another step forward. Joshua doesn't budge. "Problem is, take one more step, and I ignite the oxygen pumping through your suit." "You won't," says Yusuf. "You can't. I'm your brother." "I already told you. I don't have a brother." [["Oxygen doesn't ignite, Joshua."]] [["You'd kill all of us."]] [["Yusuf, back off."]] [[Draw on Joshua.]]"It's okay," you say. "I understand." "Thanks, but you don't," says Joshua. "I barely understand. How could you? Don't say you do when you don't." Yusuf's face looks empty. "What are you saying? You'll die if you stay here. Don't be stupid. Don't pretend you can do this. You could barely make it off the ship on your own. You're coming back. You wouldn't survive a day. I'm going to take you back." Joshua looks down, shaking his head. "You're not going to." "CINDI, release a toxin into Joshua's suit to knock him unconscious," says Yusuf. "I... am not authorized to do that, Yusuf. I cannot harm one of you." Yusuf begins to move towards Joshua, but he's already pulled out his beam emitter as Yusuf starts to move forward. "I know you've got some trick up your sleeve. You built these things, with some mechanism to lock them in place. Render me unconscious. But CINDI won't do your dirty work. You'll have to come over here to get it." Yusuf slowly takes another step forward. Joshua doesn't budge. "Problem is, take one more step, and I ignite the oxygen pumping through your suit." "You won't," says Yusuf. "You can't. I'm your brother." "I already told you. I don't have a brother." [["Oxygen doesn't ignite, Joshua."]] [["You'd kill all of us."]] [["Yusuf, back off."]] [[Draw on Joshua.]]"I want to stay too." "Really?" Joshua's face brightens in confusion. "But... why?" [['"That... shape cannot come to pass."'->idk ch5]] [["We have nothing in Sol."]] [["This is humanity's next home."]]"That... colossal shape you spoke about," you say. "It can't come to pass." Joshua smiles. "Then... it's settled. We won't go back." Yusuf's face looks empty. "What are you saying? You'll die if you stay here. Don't be stupid. Don't pretend you can do this. You could barely make it off the ship on your own, you piece of shit. You're coming back. You wouldn't survive a day. I'm going to take you back." Joshua looks down, shaking his head. "You're not going to." "CINDI, release a toxin into Joshua's suit to knock him unconscious." "I... am not authorized to do that, Yusuf. I cannot harm one of you." Joshua's already pulled out his beam emitter as Yusuf starts to move forward. "I know you've got some trick up your sleeve. You built these things, with some mechanism to lock them in place. Render me unconscious. But CINDI won't do your dirty work. You'll have to come over here to get it." Yusuf slowly takes another step forward. Joshua doesn't budge. "Problem is, take one more step, and I ignite the oxygen pumping through your suit." [["Oxygen doesn't ignite, Joshua."]] [["You'd kill all of us."]] [["Yusuf, back off."]] [[Draw on Joshua.]]"We have nothing in Sol," you say. "Barely any memories. This is where we build a new life." Joshua smiles. "Then... it's settled. We won't go back." Yusuf's face looks empty. "What are you saying? You'll die if you stay here. Don't be stupid. Don't pretend you can do this. You could barely make it off the ship on your own, you piece of shit. You're coming back. You wouldn't survive a day. I'm going to take you back." Joshua looks down, shaking his head. "You're not going to." "CINDI, release a toxin into Joshua's suit to knock him unconscious." "I... am not authorized to do that, Yusuf. I cannot harm one of you." Joshua's already pulled out his beam emitter as Yusuf starts to move forward. "I know you've got some trick up your sleeve. You built these things, with some mechanism to lock them in place. Render me unconscious. But CINDI won't do your dirty work. You'll have to come over here to get it." Yusuf slowly takes another step forward. Joshua doesn't budge. "Problem is, take one more step, and I ignite the oxygen pumping through your suit." [["Oxygen doesn't ignite, Joshua."]] [["You'd kill all of us."]] [["Yusuf, back off."]] [[Draw on Joshua.]]"This is humanity's next home," you say. "And we're the start of it. Sol is done." Joshua smiles. "Then... it's settled. We won't go back." Yusuf's face looks empty. "What are you saying? You'll die if you stay here. Don't be stupid. Don't pretend you can do this. You could barely make it off the ship on your own, you piece of shit. You're coming back. You wouldn't survive a day. I'm going to take you back." Joshua looks down, shaking his head. "You're not going to." "CINDI, release a toxin into Joshua's suit to knock him unconscious." "I... am not authorized to do that, Yusuf. I cannot harm one of you." Joshua's already pulled out his beam emitter as Yusuf starts to move forward. "I know you've got some trick up your sleeve. You built these things, with some mechanism to lock them in place. Render me unconscious. But CINDI won't do your dirty work. You'll have to come over here to get it." Yusuf slowly takes another step forward. Joshua doesn't budge. "Problem is, take one more step, and I ignite the oxygen pumping through your suit." [["Oxygen doesn't ignite, Joshua."]] [["You'd kill all of us."]] [["Yusuf, back off."]] [[Draw on Joshua.]]"Oxygen doesn't ignite, Joshua." "No. But the plastics of the air tank will. The fabric of your suit. All fanned on by the oxygen that will spilling out of his suit." Yusuf's body is tense. One leg is still forward. His breath is heavy, you see it fogging up his helmet. You can almost feel his mind racing through the possibilities, permutations of what happens next. Searching for the version that takes him home, with his brother. Joshua stands calm, finger on the trigger, completely in control. You notice Yusuf's hand slip into a pocket, and he pulls out the old compass, the quibla he found on the beach. Slowly, he watches as the hand steadies. Waiting for it to settle. You know it does because there's a change. He smiles, puts the quibla down. And steps forward, arms raised. [[Run at Joshua.]] [[Yell at Joshua.]] [[Draw and fire your weapon.]]"You'd kill all of us." "I'm acutely aware of that, $name. As Yusuf pointed out, staying on this planet is essentially suicide. I'm prepared for that." Yusuf's body is tense. One leg is still forward. His breath is heavy, you see it fogging up his helmet. You can almost feel his mind racing through the possibilities, permutations of what happens next. Searching for the version that takes him home, with his brother. Joshua stands calm, finger on the trigger, completely in control. You notice Yusuf's hand slip into a pocket, and he pulls out the old compass, the quibla he found on the beach. Slowly, he watches as the hand steadies. Waiting for it to settle. You know it does because there's a change. He smiles, puts the quibla down. And steps forward, arms raised. [[Run at Joshua.]] [[Yell at Joshua.]] [[Draw and fire your weapon.]]"Yusuf, back off." "Listen to him," says Joshua. "He knows when to let go." Yusuf's body is tense. One leg is still forward. His breath is heavy, you see it fogging up his helmet. You can almost feel his mind racing through the possibilities, permutations of what happens next. Searching for the version that takes him home, with his brother. Joshua stands calm, finger on the trigger, completely in control. You notice Yusuf's hand slip into a pocket, and he pulls out the old compass, the quibla he found on the beach. Slowly, he watches as the hand steadies. Waiting for it to settle. You know it does because there's a change. He smiles, puts the quibla down. And steps forward, arms raised. [[Run at Joshua.]] [[Yell at Joshua.]] [[Draw and fire your weapon.]]You pull out your beam emitter, pointing it at Joshua. "That doesn't scare me, $name. You should know that." Yusuf's body is tense. One leg is still forward. His breath is heavy, you see it fogging up his helmet. You can almost feel his mind racing through the possibilities, permutations of what happens next. Searching for the version that takes him home, with his brother. Joshua stands calm, finger on the trigger, completely in control. You notice Yusuf's hand slip into a pocket, and he pulls out the old compass, the quibla he found on the beach. Slowly, he watches as the hand steadies. Waiting for it to settle. You know it does because there's a change. He smiles, puts the quibla down. And steps forward, arms raised. [[Run at Joshua.]] [[Yell at Joshua.]] [[Fire your weapon.]]You run at Joshua, but it's too late. There's a click, as his finger pushes down and a beam of light pulses across the small space to precisely hit the air tank of Yusuf's suit. More fire than you've ever seen. More orange and red than you ever cared to feel. The suit you're wearing floods you with cold to compensate for the fire as you're buffeted back, hitting a side of the room, cracking the ice behind you. The entire structure is destroyed. Ice splinters and tongues of flames and you're careening towards the ground, gray sky and blue ice all you see as you spin on your way down. The spinning doesn't stop, even as you try and steady yourself. You're oriented enough to tell you're heading towards a blue layer of ice. Vague memories of physics simulations and free body diagrams come and go as you try and grasp what might happen when you make contact with the ground. Will you bounce up into the sky? Slide across the surface? Will the force be strong enough to break your bones? The answer comes to you in shards, as you break through the ice surface and find yourself plunged into freezing water just underneath. A million fires light up your body at contact with the surface. Cold devours you, even as the suit attempts to flood you with heat. Your speed has decreased, but even under the water you're still sinking. The crack in your helmet splintering at the increased pressure of the water. A stream of water is beginning to leak through, floating in your helmet in globs. [[Swim up.]] [[Fix your suit.]] <<set $Yusuf to "dead">>"Joshua, don't!" you yell, but it's too late. There's a click, as his finger pushes down and a beam of light pulses across the small space to precisely hit the air tank of Yusuf's suit. More fire than you've ever seen. More orange and red than you ever cared to feel. [[Swim up.]] [[Fix your suit.]] <<set $Yusuf to "alive">>There's a click, as your finger pushes down and a beam of light pulses across the room towards Joshua. He seems bewildered as he's hit by it, grazing his suit and opening up a wound. Toxic air immediately rushes in. Joshua's pulse still fires, hitting the ice near Yusuf's feat. The structure begins to shake as there's increasingly strained breathing. Joshua lifts from the floor, floating and fighting to keep a straight face as his lungs gasp for oxygen, filling themselves with the air of this alien world. But there's little pain, other than that. The occasional smile pushes through and, once the gasping is done, that's all that remains. "What... did you do." His voice is lower than you heard it before. He stands. Eyes lock in at you. "What did you..." He's running at you as fast as the suit can take him. [[Defend yourself non-leathally.]] [[Defend yourself leathally.]]Yusuf hurls a fist at you, which you evade by swerving to the side. In return, you knee him in the gut while he's off balance, pushing him into the air. He tries to tick or push the air with his hands, with no luck. After a moment, he pulls out his own beam emitter, and starts firing at random, hitting the ice all around you. The entire structure begins to destabilize. Chunks flying out from the edge. Ice splinters and the walls crack and you're knocked to one side of the room as it splits apart, the gray sky beginning to break through. You're both floating amongst these chunks of ice, the walls that were around you starting to crumble. [[Use your beam emitter->Use your gun.]] [[Talk it out.]]Yusuf hurls a fist at you, and you shoot another beam towards him. He manages to dodge it, and then grabs the hand holding it. You struggle for the device, pulses going off and hitting the ice all around you. The entire structure begins to destabilize. Chunks flying out from the edge. Ice splinters and the walls crack and you're knocked to one side of the room as it splits apart, the gray sky beginning to break through. You're both floating amongst these chunks of ice, the walls that were around you starting to crumble. [[Use your beam emitter->Use your gun.]] [[Talk it out.]]You pull out your beam emitter, and take aim. Yusuf's eyes meet yours. There's a rage and fear and sadness all there as you press the trigger. You watch, as he closes his eyes, turns, his air tank facing the beam as it makes contact. More fire than you've ever seen. More orange and red than you ever cared to feel. The suit you're wearing floods you with cold to compensate for the fire as you're buffeted back, now careening towards the ground. The spinning doesn't stop, even as you try and steady yourself. You're oriented enough to tell you're heading towards a blue layer of ice. Vague memories of physics simulations and free body diagrams come and go as you try and grasp what might happen when you make contact with the ground. Will you bounce up into the sky? Slide across the surface? Will the force be strong enough to break your bones? The answer comes to you in shards, as you break through the ice surface and find yourself plunged into freezing water just underneath. A million fires light up your body at contact with the surface. Cold devours you, even as the suit attempts to flood you with heat. Your speed has decreased, but even under the water you're still sinking. The crack in your helmet splintering at the increased pressure of the water. A stream of water is beginning to leak through, floating in your helmet in globs. [[Swim up.]] [[Fix your suit.]] <<set $Yusuf to "dead">>"Stop this! I just saved your life." "You killed my brother." Yusuf grabs a nearby chunk of rock and hurls it at you. It makes contact, causing a crack in your helmet. The glass holds, barely, but you find yourself careening towards the ground. Yusuf's propelled in the other direction, but steadies himself with a piece of the collapsing structure. The spinning doesn't stop, even as you try and steady yourself.
