E o capitão de todos, chamado Pedro Alvarez Cabral, decidiu enviar uma barquinha para a praia, com um homem.”">>"The Captains of all thirteen ships come together. And the Captain of all of them, named Pedro Alvarez Cabral, decides to send one small boat to them, with one man."<</linkreplace>> Nicolau Coelho stumbles out of the small boat when he reaches the shore, the water dampening his boots as he gets out. He fumbles to hold onto a large and elegant black hat, keeping it on his head, as he approaches the twenty or so individuals in front of him. A red cowl at his neck. You feel your feet soggy with the salty seawater and dry against the sun-kissed sand. And, still, you hear Ana's mother, telling this story. There's a splitting headache searing across your forehead, as you try and keep all these images together. And then it occurs to you, you're not even sure where your forehead is anymore. [[This isn't like the other memories.->not like others arrival new]] [[This hurts. Make it stop, please.->make it stop arrival new]] "This isn't like the other memories," you think to me. "What's... happening?" Exactly what you see before you. <div align="left | right | center | justify">The others have gathered by the time he arrives. She's ready, stretching back the string on her bow as the man finds his way out of the large canoe he crawls out of. The others do as well. His hands fly up, his head stays down.</div> <<linkreplace "“Ele chega na praia,”">>"He arrives on the shore,"<</linkreplace>> says Ana's mother. <<linkreplace "“Enfrenta a curiosidade hesitante do Tupiniquim.”">>"Faced with the hesitant curiosity of the Tupiniquim."<</linkreplace>> Surrounded. Sharp arrows, pointed at him. The thick hat keeping his face in the shadows. No sudden movements. He's not frightened, but curious. Slowly, he brings his hands to the ground. Repeating this motion. His eyes reaching out to as many as he can find. <div align="left | right | center | justify">The man stares at her. It's not hateful, but there's a leering to his gaze, as it seems to try and consume her. The others, you notice, begin to lower their weapons. She begins to lower hers as well. There's no words, only eyes trying to speak.</div> You're not there, not really. You know this. You can't be. And yet... it seems as if the woman catches your eye, as the tip of her arrow begins to move towards the ground. There's... something you do feel, that's there... flowing within her veins. Something within her gut within your bones that echoes back... distant. Perhaps the trick of a sideways glance that's just coincidence. But you sense you are not just an observer, here. That there is something more. There's the rhythm of the man's heavy breathing. The quiet and stillness of hers, keeping arms steady. And the water, throwing itself to the shore and receding. As it will remain and as it has always been. You watch the shore as the moment around you melts and time as you know it seems to move with a swiftness. Small gifts exchanged that day and in the next days. Small encroachments inland and their wide eyes at the birds and trees and bodies before them and soon, there's the gnawing of metal teeth against bark and the slow whistle of a trunk's collapse. Sounds not heard on this shore before, not like this. The precision of instrumentation to chew at this jungle's flesh. There is a towering shape. Crafted of sharp and rectangular wood. Bolted together with small metal daggers. One pillar to the sky, the other parallel to the ground, just above its midpoint. A cross. And the white men lower their heads to it and whisper to themselves and motion for those witnessing this transformation from tree to tower to join. And they do, quietly, confusedly. But with curiosity. They leave. But the sands they push away from already feel their returns, even as they sail on to their other places. They feel that with their footprints, even as the waters wash them away, are stains that cannot be bleached. Because already there are the prints of boots of men carrying yes, guns and disease and all those things. But above all those, an astonishing deadness in their eyes. Because upon each return, more and more of their souls have been left in tatters, as they drag these brown bodies through the fields they've sown in land they've stolen and drag other black bodies across the sea to do the same and more. And they rape these bodies and this land and they call this a New World they call this a Home. All this from some stray seaweed pointing towards a shore pointing to sand holding all this, holding those first steps of a white man's curiosity. All spiraling forth from her eyes meeting his. And how, her eyes meeting yours. There's a new kind of line you start to feel. A string, sewn through the woman on the shore, through you -- in the water, but not just there. You -- cradled in your mothers arms above Mars. Your mother -- cradled in her mother's arms as snow falls on sand. The sand -- feeling the first boots imprint themselves on its moist surface. Feeling chains dragged across the minuscule rocks that outnumber the stars. The stars -- watching and waiting to see how you will ever reach them. Over whose bodies. Our bodies -- surrounding you, as you see all this. This -- how we understand our world, now how you understand yours. And the string running through all these things continues until it connects back and it all begins to vibrate. The motions of each echoing across to the other in waves. They all echo the same frequency: its tune riddles in pain, echoing forward and back. The hum under everything that led to you being brought into this world and everything moving forward. It feels as if this particular string wouldn't exist without it. I think they have their answer, now. They see the completeness of your history, how this violence you have enacted upon us had its seed planet long ago and long into your future. Though we still shall feel this pain, now at least they shall understand it. [[Then they accept it.->accept it arrival new]] [[This is not immutable.->immutable arrival new]]"This hurts. Make it stop, please," you think to me. But I think you know, I can't start what's already begun. "What's... happening?" Exactly what you see before you. <div align="left | right | center | justify">The others have gathered by the time he arrives. She's ready, stretching back the string on her bow as the man finds his way out of the large canoe he crawls out of. The others do as well. His hands fly up, his face a mix of fear and calm. He keeps his head low.</div> <<linkreplace "“Ele chega na praia,”">>"He arrives on the shore,"<</linkreplace>> says Ana's mother. <<linkreplace "“Enfrenta a curiosidade hesitante do Tupiniquim.”">>"Faced with the hesitant curiosity of the Tupiniquim."<</linkreplace>> Surrounded. Sharp arrows, pointed at him. He keeps his face calm. No sudden movements. He's not frightened, but curious. Slowly, he brings his hands to the ground. Repeating this motion. His eyes reaching out to as many as he can find. <div align="left | right | center | justify">The man stares at her. It's not hateful, but there's a leering to his gaze, as it seems to try and consume her. The others, you notice, begin to lower their weapons. She begins to lower hers as well. There's no words, only eyes trying to speak.</div> You're not there, not really. You know this. You can't be. And yet... it seems as if the woman catches your eye, as the tip of her arrow begins to move towards the ground. There's... something you do feel, that's there... flowing within her veins. Something within her gut within your bones that echoes back... distant. Perhaps the trick of a sideways glance that's just coincidence. But you sense you are not just an observer, here. That there is something more. There's the rhythm of the man's heavy breathing. The quiet and stillness of hers, keeping arms steady. And the water, throwing itself to the shore and receding. As it will remain and as it has always been. You watch the shore as the moment around you melts and time as you know it seems to move with a swiftness. Small gifts exchanged that day and in the next days. Small encroachments inland and their wide eyes at the birds and trees and bodies before them and soon, there's the gnawing of metal teeth against bark and the slow whistle of a trunk's collapse. Sounds not heard on this shore before, not like this. The precision of instrumentation to chew at this jungle's flesh. There is a towering shape. Crafted of sharp and rectangular wood. Bolted together with small metal daggers. One pillar to the sky, the other parallel to the ground, just above its midpoint. A cross. And the white men lower their heads to it and whisper to themselves and motion for those witnessing this transformation from tree to tower to join. And they do, quietly, confusedly. But with curiosity. They leave. But the sands they push away from already feel their returns, even as they sail on to their other places. They feel that with their footprints, even as the waters wash them away, are stains that cannot be bleached. Because already there are the prints of boots of men carrying yes, guns and disease and all those things. But above all those, an astonishing deadness in their eyes. Because upon each return, more and more of their souls have been left in tatters, as they drag these brown bodies through the fields they've sown in land they've stolen and drag other black bodies across the sea to do the same and more. And they rape these bodies and this land and they call this a New World they call this a Home. All this from some stray seaweed pointing towards a shore pointing to sand holding all this, holding those first steps of a white man's curiosity. All spiraling forth from her eyes meeting his. And how, her eyes meeting yours. There's a new kind of line you start to feel. A string, sewn through the woman on the shore, through you -- in the water, but not just there. You -- cradled in your mothers arms above Mars. Your mother -- cradled in her mother's arms as snow falls on sand. The sand -- feeling the first boots imprint themselves on its moist surface. Feeling chains dragged across the minuscule rocks that outnumber the stars. The stars -- watching and waiting to see how you will ever reach them. Over whose bodies. Our bodies -- surrounding you, as you see all this. This -- how we understand our world, now how you understand yours. And the string running through all these things continues until it connects back and it all begins to vibrate. The motions of each echoing across to the other in waves. They all echo the same frequency: its tune riddles in pain, echoing forward and back. The hum under everything that led to you being brought into this world and everything moving forward. It feels as if this particular string wouldn't exist without it. I think they have their answer, now. They see the completeness of your history, how this violence you have enacted upon us had its seed planet long ago and long into your future. Though we still shall feel this pain, now at least they shall understand it. [[Then they accept it.->accept it arrival new]] [[This is not immutable.->immutable arrival new]]"Then they accept it." They do... but I don't. Being in your head, I... see this linearity of yours, how it creates what you call choice. Agency. The others don't understand that. They only see the threads throughout you, how they implicate the present. This... string you're attached to, its frequency is strong. But now you have your fingers all along its length. Seeing it in totality. Perhaps, if they were plucked differently, they could sing a different song. And... I don't know what that would do. What it would change. That's... new for me. Seeing this whole, but also acknowledging its ability to be changed. Before you, it was all... alive, but one. Coming into contact with you, there was only the moment and then the next. This... somehow is both. Everything at once, but that everything an infinite amount of choices oscillating between realities. There's a danger, I think, to changing those oscillations, flirting between them. I leave it to you if that's a risk you wish to take. This is your story, not mine. <<linkreplace "“Ele desembarcou na praia,”">>"He arrives on the shore,"<</linkreplace>> says Ana's mother, again for the first time. <<linkreplace "“Enfrentou a curiosidade hesitante do Tupiniquim.”">>"Faced with the hesitant curiosity of the Tupiniquim."<</linkreplace>> Surrounded. Sharp arrows, pointed at him. He keeps his face calm. No sudden movements. He's not frightened, but curious. Slowly, he brings his hands to the ground. Repeating this motion. His eyes reaching out to as many as he can find. <div align="left | right | center | justify">The man stares at her. It's not hateful, but there's a leering to his gaze, as it seems to try and consume her. The others, you notice, begin to lower their weapons. She begins to lower hers as well. There's no words, only eyes trying to speak. And you let your eyes speak. Of all this. Her eyes grow wide as she sees the shapes of all these things in the eye of a ghost's shadow, peering through time to find her on this shore. The wooden cross this man will help erect some days from now. The slaves they will make of them the ones they will make of others. The children men like him will force her sisters to bear, and the sister's of others. The children of those children. The Empires they will build for men like him. The worlds they will one day imagine for themselves. She sees Ana huddled in her blankets as the world wails its last outside. These shores frozen. This story still being told. And you. Who goes to the stars. Only to end up back here. The string tugs at the muscles of her forearm and the wood of the arrow feels soft as it rests above the index finger of her outstretched hand and her eyes turn back to the white man before her and she holds all you have given as she [[lowers her arms.->lowers her arms new]] [[releases her arrow.->releases her arrow start new]]</div> (cycle)"This is not immutable." No. It's not, is it? I... see this linearity of yours, how it creates what you call choice. Agency. The others don't understand that. They only see the threads throughout you, how they implicate the present. This... string you're attached to, its frequency is strong. But now you have your fingers all along its length. Seeing it in totality. Perhaps, if they were plucked differently, they could sing a different song. And... I don't know what that would do. What it would change. That's... new for me. Seeing this whole, but also acknowledging its ability to be changed. Before you, it was all... alive, but one. Coming into contact with you, there was only the moment and then the next. This... somehow is both. Everything at once, but that everything an infinite amount of choices oscillating between realities. There's a danger, I think, to changing those oscillations, flirting between them. I leave it to you if that's a risk you wish to take. This is your story, not mine. <<linkreplace "“Ele desembarcou na praia,”">>"He arrives on the shore,"<</linkreplace>> says Ana's mother, again for the first time. <<linkreplace "“Enfrentou a curiosidade hesitante do Tupiniquim.”">>"Faced with the hesitant curiosity of the Tupiniquim."<</linkreplace>> Surrounded. Sharp arrows, pointed at him. He keeps his face calm. No sudden movements. He's not frightened, but curious. Slowly, he brings his hands to the ground. Repeating this motion. His eyes reaching out to as many as he can find. <div align="left | right | center | justify">The man stares at her. It's not hateful, but there's a leering to his gaze, as it seems to try and consume her. The others, you notice, begin to lower their weapons. She begins to lower hers as well. There's no words, only eyes trying to speak. And you let your eyes speak. Of all this. Her eyes grow wide as she sees the shapes of all these things in the eye of a ghost's shadow, peering through time to find her on this shore. The wooden cross this man will help erect some days from now. The slaves they will make of them the ones they will make of others. The children men like him will force her sisters to bear, and the sister's of others. The children of those children. The Empires they will build for men like him. The worlds they will one day imagine for themselves. She sees Ana huddled in her blankets as the world wails its last outside. These shores frozen. This story still being told. And you. Who goes to the stars. Only to end up back here. The string tugs at the muscles of her forearm and the wood of the arrow feels soft as it rests above the index finger of her outstretched hand and her eyes turn back to the white man before her and she holds all you have given as she [[lowers her arms.->lowers her arms new]] [[releases her arrow.->releases her arrow start new]]</div> (cycle)lowers her arms. Arrow pointing to the ground, along with the others. The man raises his head, standing tall. And then you see his face, clear, for the first time. It takes a moment before he face process. But once that grimace of a smile splits across his face, you know it's him. "You found me," says Ezra Caval. Rotting teeth spilling out from his mouth. And you notice the waves lapping at his feet have found themselves frozen. The women with her lowered bow, still. The others on the shore. All frozen. Everything waits. "They took you here, didn't they?" He lowers his arms, as if stepping out of a role. Takes off the hat. "Smart bastards." //This man... we know him. You, from your past, yes... but I feel something more.// [['"How are you here?"'->how lower]] [['"Why are you here?"'->why lower]] <<set $arrival to "repeat">>"How are you here?" you ask. "Same way as you," he says. "Found my way back. Through stories. Through blood and bones. And of course, our mutual friends." //As I thought. He is joined with one of my kind. Like us.// [['"You're here to stop this?"'->stop this lower]] [['"You... did this?"'->did this lower]]"Why are you here?" you ask. "Same reason as you, I'd guess," he says. "Make sure shit goes the way I'd like. But... if I were to take another guess, it's not really you at the reigns, is it? Not really. The only way you can be here is at the courtesy of our... mutual friends." //As I thought. He is joined with one of my kind. Like us.// [['"You're here to stop this?"'->stop this lower]] [['"You... did this?"'->did this lower]]"You're here to stop this too?" you ask. Looking at his boat, the fleet off the shore. Ezra laughs. "Stop this? I caused this. Well... I shouldn't take too much credit. All they needed were... pushes, here and there." He looks down at his reflection in the frozen ocean water pooled about his feet. "Almost let that arrow skewer me, didn't you?" He squats down to inspect his unpunctured face. "Smart kid. Would've taken more than that." There's a strange vibration about his outline that you only notice now, in the stillness of this frozen moment. "You don't get it, do you?" He looks at you with disappointment. Then speaks slowly. "I gave birth to the world. Ensured humanity will always survive. Through sacrifice and ferocity. That in the very fabric of who we are, we will always be capable of doing what must be done." He stands, facing you. "It all started with Issac, you know. And you. Not the human you, that was a... new development. I mean the other thing swimming about your brain. The first time we found their kind, no one would dare build Issac's engine. Even before they learned to talk to us, no one had the guts to push them to their full potential. "So I took it upon myself to break them. Issac helped, but only until a point. He just wanted to... understand." He's grimacing. "How can you understand a creature without breaking it open? Construct knowledge without deconstructing its subject? "I was right, of course. And without him unlocked the secrets of these beings. The fallibility of our... lines. I realized, like you have, that to go forward, one must go back. And so I did." He looks up at this blue sky, its clouds hovering in place. "I thought a few months, years at most, would be enough. Wrestle enough control over the circumstances of your discovery. But still... everyone was too soft. Content to wallow in our corner of the universe, when we'd fallen upon our chariot to the stars... "So I went further. Generations instead of years. Searching for inflection points, places where the world could turn. The creation of AI. The first colonies of Mars. And the further I went, the further it seemed I needed to go. I didn't-- want to do the things I did. But it became clear what I had to do. "It was so... easy. To tip the scales towards our most vicious selves..." He's lost in thought, for a moment. Then he looks up. At you. His surroundings. Acutely aware. "It starts here. When I cross this great ocean called the Atlantic, bring all these men here in boats so they can find this land. Discover it, soon call it their own. Build it into something greater, through great sacrifice. "Across this continent, across this planet, this same story appears again and again." He smiles again. "You thought that coincidence? No. It's a message: this is who we are. Who we always were. Who we must always be. "So when we reach the precipice of true greatness, I wanted to ensure we would not hesitate. That there would be no question whether the cost was worth it when the stars finally came to our reach. And we didn't." There's such a perverse pleasure radiating through him. "We sent you to the stars. You, the first of... so many." [['"We'll go, but not like this."'->go lower]] [['"I'm here. You failed."'->failed lower]]"You... did this?" you ask. Looking at his boat, the fleet off the shore. Ezra laughs. "I did a lot more than this little charade. And a lot less, in a way. All they needed were... pushes, here and there." He looks down at his reflection in the frozen ocean water pooled about his feet. "Almost let that arrow skewer me, didn't you?" He squats down to inspect his unpunctured face. "Smart kid. Would've taken more than that." There's a strange vibration about his outline that you only notice now, in the stillness of this frozen moment. "You don't get it, do you?" He looks at you with disappointment. Then speaks slowly. "I gave birth to the world. Ensured humanity will always survive. Through sacrifice and ferocity. That in the very fabric of who we are, we will always be capable of doing what must be done." He stands, facing you. "It all started with Issac, you know. And you. Not the human you, that was a... new development. I mean the other thing swimming about your brain. The first time we found their kind, no one would dare build Issac's engine. Even before they learned to talk to us, no one had the guts to push them to their full potential. "So I took it upon myself to break them. Issac helped, but only until a point. He just wanted to... understand." He's grimacing. "How can you understand a creature without breaking it open? Construct knowledge without deconstructing its subject? "I was right, of course. And without him unlocked the secrets of these beings. The fallibility of our... lines. I realized, like you have, that to go forward, one must go back. And so I did." He looks up at this blue sky, its clouds hovering in place. "I thought a few months, years at most, would be enough. Wrestle enough control over the circumstances of your discovery. But still... everyone was too soft. Content to wallow in our corner of the universe, when we'd fallen upon our chariot to the stars... "So I went further. Generations instead of years. Searching for inflection points, places where the world could turn. The creation of AI. The first colonies of Mars. And the further I went, the further it seemed I needed to go. I didn't-- want to do the things I did. But it became clear what I had to do. "It was so... easy. To tip the scales towards our most vicious selves..." He's lost in thought, for a moment. Then he looks up. At you. His surroundings. Acutely aware. "It starts here. When I cross this great ocean called the Atlantic, bring all these men here in boats so they can find this land. Discover it, soon call it their own. Build it into something greater, through great sacrifice. "Across this continent, across this planet, this same story appears again and again." He smiles again. "You thought that coincidence? No. It's a message: this is who we are. Who we always were. Who we must always be. "So when we reach the precipice of true greatness, I wanted to ensure we would not hesitate. That there would be no question whether the cost was worth it when the stars finally came to our reach. And we didn't." There's such a perverse pleasure radiating through him. "We sent you to the stars. You, the first of... so many." [['"We'll go, but not like this."'->go lower]] [['"I'm here. You failed."'->failed lower]]"We'll go to the stars," you say. "But not your way. Not like this." "You don't think I searched for another way? Greatness never comes with a clean conscious, $name. But I understand. Not all of us have the will to rebuild a universe," he says. "Go on, keep telling your grandmother's story. But try to change it again, I'll be there. I'll find you. And I'll stop you." He walks back to the spot where he stood before everything froze. His hands in the midst of lowering themselves and his smile wide and eyes at the woman who almost let an arrow pierce his eye and then he walks through the motions of all she has seen, like a puppet. Their cross, their mass, and their departure. And all that is to come, that rests heavy on her. But she knows this is a long story. That she is only one part. <<linkreplace "“E os Tupiniquim pegam os presentes que Coelho ofereceu, e ele leva para o barco os presentes que recebeu. It strikes true, piercing through the flesh of his left eye. The right glows as the arrow continues through his head, coming to a stop once it has reached the other side and then you see his face, clear, for the first time. The blue eye that remains finds you and it's all you can see. Pupil dilating as it sees you. "Same way as you," he says. "Found my way back. Through stories. Through blood and bones. And of course, our mutual friends." //As I thought. He is joined with one of my kind. Like us.// [['"You're here to stop this?"'->stop this arrow]] [['"You... did this?"'->did this arrow]]"Why are you here?" you ask. "Same reason as you, I'd guess," he says. "Make sure shit goes the way I'd like. But... if I were to take another guess, it's not really you at the reigns, is it? Not really. The only way you can be here is at the courtesy of our... mutual friends." //As I thought. He is joined with one of my kind. Like us.// [['"You're here to stop this?"'->stop this arrow]] [['"You... did this?"'->did this arrow]]"You're here to stop this too?" you ask. Looking at his boat, the fleet off the shore. Ezra laughs. "Stop this? I caused this. Well... I shouldn't take too much credit. All they needed were... pushes, here and there." He looks down at his reflection in the frozen ocean water pooled about his feet. "Thought letting an arrow loose on the first white man to step foot on these shores would be enough, did you?" He squats down to inspect the arrow through his head. "Afraid it'll take more than that." There's a strange vibration about his outline that you only notice now, in the stillness of this frozen moment. "You don't get it, do you?" He looks at you with disappointment. Then speaks slowly. "I gave birth to the world. Ensured humanity will always survive. Through sacrifice and ferocity. That in the very fabric of who we are, we will always be capable of doing what must be done." He stands, facing you. "It all started with Issac, you know. And you. Not the human you, that was a... new development. I mean the other thing swimming about your brain. The first time we found their kind, no one would dare build Issac's engine. Even before they learned to talk to us, no one had the guts to push them to their full potential. "So I took it upon myself to break them. Issac helped, but only until a point. He just wanted to... understand." He's grimacing. "How can you understand a creature without breaking it open? Construct knowledge without deconstructing its subject? "I was right, of course. And without him unlocked the secrets of these beings. The fallibility of our... lines. I realized, like you have, that to go forward, one must go back. And so I did." He looks up at this blue sky, its clouds hovering in place. "I thought a few months, years at most, would be enough. Wrestle enough control over the circumstances of your discovery. But still... everyone was too soft. Content to wallow in our corner of the universe, when we'd fallen upon our chariot to the stars... "So I went further. Generations instead of years. Searching for inflection points, places where the world could turn. The creation of AI. The first colonies of Mars. And the further I went, the further it seemed I needed to go. I didn't-- want to do the things I did. But it became clear what I had to do. "It was so... easy. To tip the scales towards our most vicious selves..." He's lost in thought, for a moment. Then he looks up. At you. His surroundings. Acutely aware. "It starts here. When I cross this great ocean called the Atlantic, bring all these men here in boats so they can find this land. Discover it, soon call it their own. Build it into something greater, through great sacrifice. "Across this continent, across this planet, this same story appears again and again." He smiles again. "You thought that coincidence? No. It's a message: this is who we are. Who we always were. Who we must always be. "So when we reach the precipice of true greatness, I wanted to ensure we would not hesitate. That there would be no question whether the cost was worth it when the stars finally came to our reach. And we didn't." There's such a perverse pleasure radiating through him. "We sent you to the stars. You, the first of... so many." [['"We'll go, but not like this."'->go arrow]] [['"I'm here. You failed."'->failed arrow]]"You... did this?" you ask. Looking at his boat, the fleet off the shore. Ezra laughs. "I did a lot more than this little charade. And a lot less, in a way. All they needed were... pushes, here and there." He looks down at his reflection in the frozen ocean water pooled about his feet. "Thought letting an arrow loose on the first white man to step foot on these shores would be enough, did you?" He squats down to inspect the arrow through his head. "Afraid it'll take more than that." There's a strange vibration about his outline that you only notice now, in the stillness of this frozen moment. "You don't get it, do you?" He looks at you with disappointment. Then speaks slowly. "I gave birth to the world. Ensured humanity will always survive. Through sacrifice and ferocity. That in the very fabric of who we are, we will always be capable of doing what must be done." He stands, facing you. "It all started with Issac, you know. And you. Not the human you, that was a... new development. I mean the other thing swimming about your brain. The first time we found their kind, no one would dare build Issac's engine. Even before they learned to talk to us, no one had the guts to push them to their full potential. "So I took it upon myself to break them. Issac helped, but only until a point. He just wanted to... understand." He's grimacing. "How can you understand a creature without breaking it open? Construct knowledge without deconstructing its subject? "I was right, of course. And without him unlocked the secrets of these beings. The fallibility of our... lines. I realized, like you have, that to go forward, one must go back. And so I did." He looks up at this blue sky, its clouds hovering in place. "I thought a few months, years at most, would be enough. Wrestle enough control over the circumstances of your discovery. But still... everyone was too soft. Content to wallow in our corner of the universe, when we'd fallen upon our chariot to the stars... "So I went further. Generations instead of years. Searching for inflection points, places where the world could turn. The creation of AI. The first colonies of Mars. And the further I went, the further it seemed I needed to go. I didn't-- want to do the things I did. But it became clear what I had to do. "It was so... easy. To tip the scales towards our most vicious selves..." He's lost in thought, for a moment. Then he looks up. At you. His surroundings. Acutely aware. "It starts here. When I cross this great ocean called the Atlantic, bring all these men here in boats so they can find this land. Discover it, soon call it their own. Build it into something greater, through great sacrifice. "Across this continent, across this planet, this same story appears again and again." He smiles again. "You thought that coincidence? No. It's a message: this is who we are. Who we always were. Who we must always be. "So when we reach the precipice of true greatness, I wanted to ensure we would not hesitate. That there would be no question whether the cost was worth it when the stars finally came to our reach. And we didn't." There's such a perverse pleasure radiating through him. "We sent you to the stars. You, the first of... so many." [['"We'll go, but not like this."'->go arrow]] [['"I'm here. You failed."'->failed arrow]]"We'll go to the stars," you say. "But not your way. Not like this." "You don't think I searched for another way? Greatness never comes with a clean conscious, $name. But I understand. Not all of us have the will to rebuild a universe," he says. "Go on, keep telling your grandmother's story. But try to change it again, I'll be there. I'll find you. And I'll stop you." He walks back to the spot where he stood before everything froze. His head leaning back only a bit, the arrow's momentum just beginning to knock his body back and then he's in place and he screams as he staggers back falling into the water and then he cannot scream. Only leaking blood into the sand and into the water and soon, the tide rises and the sea storms and his body is taken out. Past the thirteen ships past the tangled seaweed to slowly sink itself into the ocean. <<linkreplace "“E os Tupiniquim não aceitam os presentes trazidos pelos portugueses, nem neste dia nem nenhum outro,”">>"And the Tupiniquim do not let them bring their gifts to their land, on that day nor any other,"<</linkreplace>> Ana is told by her mother. <<linkreplace "“E quando eles apareceram novamente, os Tupis estavam preparados.”">>"The Portuguese, and others, return. And when they do, the Tupis are prepared, as are the others of this land."<</linkreplace>> The shoreline fades as the room returns, your grandmother's words falling on an engrossed child's ears. But the room seems different. The cross over the fireplace now gone. The cold less biting. But we're still here. The story continues. Which means our work is not done. As we sit in limbo in so many places at once, I'm surprised by what I feel from you. //I feel an... unexpected emotion. Ezra has seemingly foiled our attempt to change your history for the better, we are adrift in time, and there seems to be no solution to the perpetual cycles of violence Ezra has created. Why is it you seem to feel something akin to hope?// "He made this happen," you say. "Don't you see? None of this... not the arrival of the ships on these shores, the passage of slaves they dragged across this sea... none of it was here, before. None of it is an inevitability. They're all the concoctions of that madman. Who thinks the only way to see the stars is on your backs. Who thinks that all of this is worth it, to train us so when we see you, we see nothing more than a resource. "I have hope because if it was better before, it can be again." //There is no fear that this thing we aim to do cannot be done, for he has already done it... The chains ring louder. <<linkreplace "“Os portugueses foram os primeiros a comprar pessoas na costa de África Ocidental. Mas muitos outros seguiriam. Franceses, holandeses, praticmente todos os europeus. Foi pequeno, no começo. Ilhas pequenas, perto da costa. Até eles descobrirem lugares como aqui, lugares dos quais eles queriam tirar ouro, madeira e açúcar.”">>"The Portuguese were the first to steal people, from the coast of west Africa. But many more would follow. French, Dutch, all of the Europeans. It was small, at first. Small islands, near Africa's coast. Until they found places like here, places they wanted to strip for gold and wood and cane."<</linkreplace>> There's the stench of excrement and urine. The sounds of water beating against a wooden hull. Bodies chained to the floor, too close to breathe. You begin to gag as these smells pierce there way through your nose. Feet feel soiled on the hull's floor and unstable as there's a rocking from side to side. <<linkreplace "“Então, eles roubaram nossos antepassados. E colocaram eles em barcos, e levaram eles - através do mar para essas terras.”">>"So they stole our ancestors. And put them on boats, and took them across the sea. To these shores."<</linkreplace>> A boy no older than a decade gasps through air riddled with death. In the darkness in the cries of pain and the even worse pang of terror after a scream goes silent and the fear if the air will soon become so thick with death that there's no more oxygen to take in and is this what it feels like, to be a ghost? Already dead, walking above one's decaying body? Screaming into silence? An overwhelming fear overcomes all else, and he thrashes and thrashes against the cuffs about his ankles his wrists his neck. Thin meatless arms wriggling to escape the chains latching them to the hull's floor and they ring out drowned by the raging storm just outside. And then there's hope. A thumb, half way jammed through a shackle. Furiously he tugs and the fingers twist and squish and this is how the night is passed, fighting with metal as wood fights with wind and water and the twisted fingers are stuck, his muscles sore, his lungs close to empty. It's morning. A light burns through his closed eyelids as he hears the steps of a man coming down from the deck. <<linkreplace "“Através dessas águas, os mercadores de escravos leveram os resíduos de suas almas, rasgados em pedaços pelas garras das pessoas que morriam nessa passagem, alongando-se naquele oceano sangrento.”">>"Through those waters, the slave traders carried the dregs of their souls, torn to shreds by the clawing fingers of those who died along that passage, stretching up from that bloody ocean."<</linkreplace>> It's an officer. Inspecting his cargo after the storm. Flopping over bodies, to see if they still live. Or not. For most, it's difficult to tell. He finds one body, barely breathing. Hand halfway out of its shackle. He laughs. Leans down, and pokes the body. The boy opens his eyelids, finding this face inches from him. For a second, he sinks into a pair of beady blue eyes. A thick red beard protruding from a white face. He shifts his eyes, focusing in on some space between them. The boy's face has fear and rage all in the tightly controlled fluctuations of muscle that must be hidden. Constrained. The officer sees only dead eyes amid a black face that blends into the mass of flesh strapped to the floor. The officer's hands are thick and burly. Strong. With one of them, he grabs a handful of the boy's fingers. Squeezing. Yanking them up, through the shackle, which falls back around his arms. He smiles. Then he squeezes again. Frail fingers crunching. Tightening the shackle with the other hand. The boy feels the snapping of his bones. Sharp fires lit with each squeeze until nerves all fall quiet. The pain's gone. All feeling, gone. The sounds of each snap entering his ears as if they were from some other object, cleanly being broken into two. And then the officer lets go. The hand falling to the floor. The boy holding back his tears until he has returned back to the deck, then allowing his soft whimpers to add to the chorus of pain. It seems as if the boy catches your eye, as the darkness descends once more, hand securely shackled, lifeless and broken. As the air grows thick and the boy's mouth gapes, gagging on the stink of dead bodies. His eyes find you, grow wide. All he wants is fresh air, filling his lungs. There's... that feeling, again. A recognition and recalling. The glance feels like more than just coincidence. There's the rhythm of the boat's swaying. The breathing of the bodies it holds. And the water, lapping up against the hull and receding. As it will remain and as it has always been. <<linkreplace "“Quando eles chegaram nessas terras, não tinham mais consciência para parar de infligir horrores.”">>"When they arrived on these shores, they had no conscious left to stop them from inflicting their horrors."<</linkreplace>> Land arrives and you watch, as the boy is taken through a city called Salvador. A city called Savior. He stands besides many others on an auction block. His hand limp and contorted to the side. <<linkreplace "“Então, eles foram vendidos e usados para trabalhar nas usinas de açúcar e peneirar os rios para achar ouro. Para cozinhar e servir nas casas de luxo. Outros, para criar e cuidar de crianças que eles não queriam. Crianças que iriam ser forçadas a trabalhar nessas e em outras coisas.”">>"And so they were used and sold. To work at sugar mills and sift rivers for gold. To cook meals and serve in luxurious homes. Others, to bear and care for children they did not want. Children who would be forced to do these, and other things."<</linkreplace>> You watch the boy as the block melts around you and time as you know it seems to move with a swiftness. As he bears the unconscionable life of millions. Body broken from more labor than light in the day. Good hand sore from doing the work of two. Back scabbing over from the cost of working too slow. He drains the soil of its cane and turns it into white and sweet grains. Enough to replace a coast's sand and turn its beaches white. But there were moments of joy, too. Hidden from view. Feasts out of scraps. Defense out of dance. Messages hidden within music. Gods hidden within Saints. Life, folded into the seams of misery. Ana has let go of her blankets. There's the look on her face of puzzlement. Some horror, too. But more than that, she's confused. That people could do this to one another. A disbelief. She just wanted to hear the story of the hero she was named after. The only question she can muster is, <<linkreplace "“Mas o que isso tem a ver com Dandara?”">>"But what does this have to do with Dandara?"<</linkreplace>> <<linkreplace "“É o pecado que deu origem ao mundo dela.”">>[['"It is the sin that gave birth to her world."'->sin slave trade continue new]]<</linkreplace>> <<linkreplace "“É o pecado que destruiu ao mundo dela.”">>[['"It is the sin that destroyed her world."'->destroy slave trade continue new]]<</linkreplace>> Her mother looks into her eyes, trying to tell her it's okay, but also that all these things are true. <<linkreplace "“É o pecado que deu origem ao mundo dela. Esse… novo Oceano Atlântico, nascido de carcaças: transportando e deixando gente para lá, retornando com açúcar. Essas novas redes marítimas forjadas pela violência. Conectando-nos ao mundo ao transformar dor em lucro. Enquanto sorriem. Risos em cima de gritos. Ardor por horrores imensuráveis.”">>"It is the sin that gave birth to her world. This... new Atlantic, born from carcasses: ferried there and left, sugar sent back. These new networks forged from violence, born over the oceans. Connecting us and the world by turning pain into profit. All the while sealed in smiles. Laughter over screams. Zeal over the horrors that are unfathomable."<</linkreplace>> It's one day, when he's working at the cane press. A lumbering machine of three wood rollers. He's learned to operate it with both hands, using his good one to put the raw cane in, and . He does this, but on this day, his mind wanders. Thinks back to the night when his hand was broken, the night he saw a ghost. You. And as his mind slips, so does his hand and he doesn't feel it as it's nipped by the machine until there's blood spilling into the cane juice that will be taken and distilled and boiled and hardened and broken, bagged, delivered to ships to sail back across the sea back over bloody waters and find its way into tea into rum into scones and bread nearly everything, across Portugal across Europe across the world. He turns, and finds his fingers bloody and pulls them out. No screams because those nerves have been long dead. Only terror because this batch must go off to be distilled and boiled and baked and his back can't take much more. And so he looks at the cane juice still flowing out from the machine and it's not too read it's not too strange and so he leaves it. The blood in his veins now surging forward through this network already built on so much blood. He, too, feels like a part of this string you have found yourself a part of. Again, the same vibrations as before, though now you're at a different place to pluck. You're back on the ship. Standing over the boy, fingers freshly snapped. It seems as if the he catches your eye, as the darkness descends once more, hand securely shackled, lifeless and broken. As the air grows thick and the boy's mouth gapes, gagging on the stink of dead bodies. His eyes find you, grow wide. All he wants is fresh air, filling his lungs. //I can help him breathe. Please. Let me help him breathe.// You lean down, like the bearded man before you. The stench sits in again. You feel how it chokes you. But then... you breathe easy, the same strange alterations from your lung I made possible on an alien planet helping you here, across space and time. And knowing what you must do, you [[help him breathe.->help him breathe. new]] [[let him persevere.->let him persevere. new]]All it takes is a touch, against his heavy chest. And you feel me and my network reach out, your bacterial aura meshing into his. Finding its way through his orifices through his skin into his system and through the stench through the death he breathes easy, for a moment. And smiles. Looking into your phantom eyes. He breathes easy and smiles. Even as his hand sits crumbled. To his noes, the air now smells of flowers. Both of us are carried forward in his blood, now. As he reaches the shore the auction block the many years at the sugar mill and one day when he thinks back to that moment, when he thought the ancestors helped him survive suffocation his hand slips his blood spills and it spills into the veins of all this, and I'm in that blood and I'm in those veins that stretch out into the teacups of Kings and Lords and the rich and poor that buy and sell bodies for sweets and that blood touches all. You feel this, through me. All their fingers throughout the world. So you know it takes nothing for me to provide precise microscopic incisions into the lungs of all Europe. And then it's done. The mill fades, it all fades. The world is changed and it's not the one in which we exist to share it. Not like this. Not anymore. But only if this boy, infected by our touch, reaches the shore. "Took me awhile to find this one." You only see his outline, in the dark of the ship's belly. He approaches from the shadows. Stepping over the black bodies chained to the ground. "Sneaky of you. To turn this boy's future pain into a weapon." His eyes are bloodshot. There's something visceral behind them. "We're doing the same thing, you know. You're here, sticking your ghostly displaced self where it shouldn't. Both of us toying with history because we think we know what's best." [["Don't try and twist this."]] [["Anything to stop your horrors."]] <<set $slavetrade to "revise">>"Don't you dare try and twist this," you say. "You've caused entire continents generations of suffering just to condition humanity into thinking tools are all life can be." "And you're trying to condition them into a quick death on this lonely planet," he replies. "A couple centuries of pain are an easy price to pay for civilization everlasting." //The two of you are not the same, $name. All this pain is his doing, with the aim of making the genocide of my kind more palatable. Your undoing of it is the opposite.// "It's just trying to save itself, you know," says Ezra. "Don't let it twist its words around your ears too tightly." His voice seems to be closer. The outline growing. "Think you've beaten me, haven't you?" The boat's floor creaking with each step. "It's simple," he says. "I'll free him." Ezra lights a lantern in his hand, illuminating his figure. Now, he sports that same bristling orange beard. A sickly smile. From his other hand, he brings forth a set of keys. There's a knife at his belt. "All he needs is a rowboat, some food and water, and he'll make it to an island not too far from here," he says. "To live a safe and quiet life. You'd deny him that?" The boy, now breathing easy, looks up at you. [["This is a life, not a pawn."]] [["There are a million moments to end this."]]"Anything to stop the horrors you've unleashed," you say. "People unleashed these horrors on each other," he replies. "I only have them pushes where they needed them. Just as you are trying to." //The two of you are not the same, $name. All this pain is his doing, with the aim of making the genocide of my kind more palatable. Your undoing of it is the opposite.// "It's just trying to save itself, you know," says Ezra. "Don't let it twist its words around your ears too tightly." His voice seems to be closer. The outline growing. "Think you've beaten me, haven't you?" The boat's floor creaking with each step. "It's simple," he says. "I'll free him." Ezra lights a lantern in his hand, illuminating his figure. Now, he sports that same bristling orange beard. A sickly smile. From his other hand, he brings forth a set of keys. There's a knife at his belt. "All he needs is a rowboat, some food and water, and he'll make it to an island not too far from here," he says. "To live a safe and quiet life. You'd deny him that?" The boy, now breathing easy, looks up at you. [["This is a life, not a pawn."]] [["There are a million moments to end this."]]"This is a life, not a pawn," you say. "Then don't use him like one," Ezra replies. "Let him life his life in peace." The light from the lantern bounces off wooden beams and silver chains as Ezra leans down to the boy. "Let's get you out of here," he whispers. //This is a non-choice, $name. It is manipulative and cruel. Placing the onus on you for systems of violence he has created.// But you know you have to make it, that not making it is a choice as well. [[Let him free the boy.]] [[Try and stop Ezra.]] [[Try and kill Ezra.]]"This is only one of a million moments that could be turned to end all this," you say. "Go ahead, save him. And we'll find another place to push against." "And I'll always find a way to push back," Ezra replies. "I've been at this a lot longer than you have, $name. I've built this past, and lived the future it's made for me." The light from the lantern bounces off wooden beams and silver chains as Ezra leans down to the boy. "Let's get you out of here," he whispers. //This is a non-choice, $name. It is manipulative and cruel. Placing the onus on you for systems of violence he has created.// But you know you have to make it, that not making it is a choice as well. [[Let him free the boy.]] [[Try and stop Ezra.]] [[Try and kill Ezra.]]You do nothing, as the chains unlatch and the boy's wrists come free. His broken hand still hurting, but no longer in chains. Ezra helps his frail body to his feat. Others look on with confusion, jealousy, joy. But the boy only turns to look back at you. You think he might see the future he would have had. What it could have meant. But he sees all the pain that would bring him to that point. And he can't help but feel relief that his fate will now be different. //Any change we attempt to make, he'll be there to thwart. No matter how differently we render this story, Ezra will make sure it leads to the same place.// And the moment fades and you're back, again, with Ana and her mother. //He's correcting our changes, even as we make them. Going ahead, or behind us, undoing whatever modifications to the version of history he's created. We need a new approach.// <<linkreplace "“Não entendi,”">>"I don't understand,"<</linkreplace>> she says. Small and scared. <<linkreplace "“Fizeram isso ... uns contra os outros?”">>"People... did this to each other?"<</linkreplace>> <<linkreplace "“Eles não viam a si mesmos nas pessoas que fizeram escravos,”">>"They didn't see themselves in the people they made slaves,"<</linkreplace>> her mother responds. <<linkreplace "“Não há limite para a crueldade da humanidade quando se cria um ‘outro.’”">>"There's no limit to the cruelty of humankind when they create an 'other.'"<</linkreplace>> //Ezra cannot continue to undo our work. Upon our next encounter, we must find a way to stop him. Permanently. So our changes can stick. And with it rise the screams of all those trapped. "You will always loose, $name," he says as he begins to fade in the fire and smoke and screams. "This is how it has to be." Above them, the music grows sharper and clearer. <<linkreplace "“Palmares foi o que se chamou um quilombo, uma lugar para escravos fugidos. Camponeses esquecidos e soldados que desertaram. E membros das tribos que viviam aqui antes de nossa chegada. Todos construindo uma coisa nova, nascida do desse ajuntamento , uma coisa maior do que os papéis que todos tinham sido forçados a jogar até então.”">>"Palmares was what's called a quilomobo, a home for escaped slaves. Forgotten farmers and defecting soldiers. The tribe members here long before us. All building something new, out of being brought together. Something better than the roles all had been forced to play."<</linkreplace>> It's the sound of one string, notes in three sets. A thrum followed by two more. There's a back and forth and you start to see a circle of people. Two in the middle, dancing about each other in rhythm with the music. <<linkreplace "“Ainda que Dandara tenha nascido na escravidão, ela descobriu Palmares e chamou este lugar de sua casa.”">>"Though Dandara was born in slavery, she found Palmares and called that her home."<</linkreplace>> Legs circling above heads as each twirled around the other, a sharp energy passed back and forth. The woman and man in motion let each move propulse forward with energy. Designed for force as much as grace. <<linkreplace "“Ela foi guerreira e defensora. Líder e amante. Ela fez um marido de Zumbi, o Rei de Palmares.”">>"She was a warrior and defender. A leader and lover. She made a husband of Zumbi, the King of Palmares."<</linkreplace>> There's a small child, watching. Holding his father's white hand as he watches his mother, across the round thrumming at the instrument he remembers helping her make. Stretching the string across the wood, fastening the gourd at its base. Though its her fingers giving the rhythm that <<if $path is "an invitation">>invites<<elseif $path is "directions">>directs<<elseif $path is "a command">>commands<<endif>> Dandara and Zumbi into motion, he feels his part in this, too. She finds his gaze and smiles. Feeling a profound joy in the peace her child feels, on her land in this shared place they have all built. Once the flotsam of an engine never meant for them, now they had built a shelter that was more than a restoration of what once was. Better than that: the emergence of You feel your foot tapping on moist and bare soil. Lungs tighter by the hight in elevation. The music stops. There's a commotion as the round breaks and the moment is lost. <<linkreplace "“Palmares durou quase cem anos. Eles lutaram contra os portugueses, holandeses, e outros inúmeras vezes. Mas um dia foram derrotados.”">>"Palmares lasted for almost a hundred years. It fought off the Portuguese, the Dutch, and others again and again. But there was a day when they met defeat."<</linkreplace>> There's the sounds of fire and cannonballs. Of arrows and guns. Screams and grunts. You see little, as your father carries you in his arms away from the battle into the mountain's jungle. Over his shoulder, you see a boy in armor. His skin is light and brown, like yours. He looks scared, and sees you. Eyes meet, and you see his arm twitch towards his gun. Until a man in armor breaks his gaze, stubby white finger pointing back towards the blazing homes. And your father finds a corner in the forest for you to hide and he tells you he'll be back, to just stay to the ground in silence. It's morning and the child is woken up by the sounds of gunshots and boots and laughter. He's still in the bushes. Peering through the leaves, he sees her: Dandara. Defender of Palmares. Surrounded guns and metal hats to one side. A cliff on the other. The men smile and laugh as they inch forward and Dandara doesn't budge. She sees the child, on the other side of the men. Two small eyes under a tuft of curled hair. Hidden in the jungle's leaves. Trying to breathe quiet. The child keeps their body as still as they can. The cinders of Palmares still trickle up through the sky. But, there is no fear in Dandara's eyes as she finds him. The boy catches your eye, as he peers through the trees. The same feeling overcomes. That she has led to you and know you lead back to her. There is no coincidence. There's the rhythm of the child's stifled breathing. The calm and confidence of hers, standing tall amid the muskets and glares of the armored men. And the wind, whistling up from the valley below. Touching all who stand there. And the leaves and the dirt, putting all in slight motion. As it will remain and as it has always been. The child's eyes reveal his contained screams. A burning want to draw the men away from her, for them to take him instead. So Dandara can go free, rebuild what now was lost. But his tongue stays silent. Fear consuming him. She steps back, towards the oncoming wind, looking at the child. Without hesitation, without fear. Giving him peace for his silence. The men continue to encroach upon her, confused. But she pays them no mind. There's only her feet, moving one behind the other until the cliff is no more and they walk onto the air and then she falls. Another whistle in the wind leaving peace. And silence. The men leave and the moment fades and the boy finds the others, who survived. There are some. And they remain and resist, so one day their children also remain and resist. Surviving and changing as they must, as the worlds around them stay the same. Different, names, yes. Colony to Kingdom. Kingdom to Republic. Republic to Regime. Dictatorship to Democracy. And it circles again, sometimes forward, sometimes back. Always there are those that remain. Those who were here before, those who were brought here. Left to carve out their own worlds. No matter how small their borders are drawn, those worlds are infinite. A third part of this string, you think. Vibrating at this hum you now know well. Third finger tense against it. Now, you have enough to pluck a chord. You're back in the brush, with the boy, as his mouth begins to quiver and you can see he wishes to call out. You wonder, what could happen if he does. If that will only add his death to hers, or... if there's some possibility there. As Dandara looks to your little clove of the forest, you think she may catch your eye as well. And let a small smile curl up, as she begins to walk back. Slower, this time, you think. The boy looks up to you. Not asking for $path, but for connection: to make this choice together. With that, [[he screams.->he screams. new]] [[he stays silent.->he stays silent. new]]The boy stays silent and she falls as she always was meant to, in this particular world. In this telling of this story. And you think perhaps she sees in your eyes, the ghost in the brush, just before she falls, the story of your mother sitting and hearing this tale. The Dandara who, one day, will fall into death quietly. "You let my work stand," says Ezra, walking into the clearing. Dressed in the regalia of one of the Dutch soldiers, the rest of whom have left, as has the boy. It's over. "I'm surprised." //This is your last chance. Grab him, and I'll find a memory. Then we can end this.// "Does this mean you finally understand?" he asks, pacing about the cliffside. "Or is this just another trick?" [["No trick. "People... You say that as if that's still us." His eyes are frantic. "I'm like you, you know. Not even human. I've got them... coursing in my veins. Creatures that hate me more than... more than I knew was possible. But they're me, too." He leans in close. His breath condensing on your neck. You wonder, what bacteria is landing on your skin. What conflict is occurring at that microscopic level you're not even conscious of. "Do you feel that same loathing? For me, for them, for yourself? Being fucking torn apart from the inside?" You hear his heavy breathing, think he might be crying. But his face is over your shoulder, you can't tell for sure. "It's been lonely. But I did it all for you." He steps back. His face seems moist. "All of you. Every fucking human that ever lived. So we didn't spend all these centuries staring up at the stars for them to remain empty. But now you're here, you've seen all this, and haven't changed a thing." He fades and the cliff fades and you're back in your [[grandmothers house->End story repeat]], for the last time.He screams, bursting out of the brush. The men turn, and Dandara wastes no time in dancing away from the cliff, hands on the ground feet in the air feet against helmet and the closest soldier goes whistling down the cliff. It's a blur of motion, as she sifts through the convoy as wind connects body against metal, metal against dirt, dirt into air and the boy finds himself into her arms, running deep into the trees and vines and by the time the dust settles and the soldiers count their men, they're gone. "Thought it would be funny to just... let her go," says Ezra, walking into the clearing. Dressed in the regalia of one of the Dutch soldiers, the rest of whom have left, as has the boy. It's over. [[Ask him for a memory.->Ask mem scream]] [[Grab him to take a memory.->Grab mem scream]] [[Leave him, let the story end.->Leave scream]]"Share something with me," you say, softly. "A memory, to help me understand." Ezra looks at the ground, as he kneels and extends an arm to you. Timidly. "I'd like that. For you to... understand." You reach forward to hold the arm, and as you grab it, feel cool air washing over you. Together, you [[travel along one last strand of memory.->Ezra Memory]]You reach forward and grab his forearm, holding tightly. "What are you--" But then he feels it, as I work my way into him. Pieces of him work their way back. And you feel cool air washing over you and together, you [[travel along one last strand of memory.->Ezra Memory]]"I think you're wrong," you say. "I think I've already done it. I don't need to defeat you, all I need to do is finish this story." Ezra's smile falters, as he sees you slip away. "You're not-- no. Don't just leave!" But you're already gone. The memory melted away. "Dandara lived through defeat, on that day." The words are light, and fall softly on her daughter's ears. Ana's smile warms the room. "Palmares grew again, and remained. And resisted. Dandara led not only the Africans who escaped their chains, but the indigenous people too. Even the whites who had been cast aside. They all fought to liberate these shores. And in the end, they won. Not just for one day, but for all days." You see it. Less clearly now, but you feel something sweep across the string. Disjointing everything, but only for a moment, as the new music continues forward. "It wasn't easy, but it was always possible. That the evil could be undone. Dandara's story was only one of many, of those that pushed against the lives they were born into. And... created new worlds." No more clanking of chains. Instead, the strumming of music. The shuffling of leaves. Pain and conflict, yes. But of a different kind. "You wanted to know the story of Dandara, of your name. She was the warrior that made a Quilombo of Brazil for us all." <center>[[--->Resistance Epilogue]]</center>It's the breeze that hits you first. Quiet, its fingers lingering in your hair as it passes you by. Sweeping the tall grass, strumming each blade into a symphony. There's a young boy. His fingers stretched up to the sky. Spread wide. Lungs expanding and contracting slowly. Neck craned back so far it looks like it might break. The universe spills out across the sky. A trillion flames burning in remembrance of this moment. The Milky Way spooling out from the darkness. Sugar dusting the black fabric of the cosmos. Swirling together, a decadence of deserts. There's a burning hunger, to taste each and every one. It hangs on your lips, too, in the tips of your fingers as you glance up. As so many have. As so many more will. [[Look around.]] [[Approach the boy.]]You look round. The sky seems clearer than you can remember it. There's no hint of smog in the air. Behind you, there's light from the moon shining on the silhouettes of nearby buildings. Low, close to the ground. A wooden sign reading "Astro Camp" is lit by warm orange lights. Other than the sign, and the buildings, everything is dark. Everything is quiet. The boy's back shining in silvery beams. You [[approach.->Approach the boy.]]"Just a minute more," he says, arms still wide, eyes squinting up, as you stand beside him. "Promise I won't tell the other chaperons you let me stay out." He's dressed uncomfortably well for a boy that can't be older than eleven or twelve. [["Okay, just a minute."]] [["I'm not a chaperon."]] [[Don't say anything.]] [[Kill the boy.]]"Okay, just a minute," you say softly. He smiles and closes his eyes, still pointed up. You follow the gaze to the stars. Lose yourself, for a moment. //Don't forget why we're here, $name.// [[I haven't. I know what we need to do.]] [[To end cycles of violence, not repeat them.]]I haven't. I know what we need to do. //Good. He's showing us this for a reason, you know. To make it harder.// "You're not one of the chaperons," says the boy, turned to you. "You're... you look like a ghost." [["Something like that."]] [["I'm here from your future."]] [["Doesn't matter what I am."]] [[Kill him.->Kill the boy.]]To end cycles of violence, not repeat them. //His intent is to trick you into equating one act of violence with an eternity of them. He's showing us this for a reason, you know. To make it harder.// "You're not one of the chaperons," says the boy, turned to you. "You're... you look like a ghost." [["Something like that."]] [["I'm here from your future."]] [["Doesn't matter what I am."]] [[Kill him.->Kill the boy.]]You say nothing as he continues to smile and closes his eyes, still pointed up. You follow the gaze to the stars. Lose yourself, for a moment. //Don't forget why we're here, $name.// [[I haven't. I know what we need to do.]] [[To end cycles of violence, not repeat them.]]"I'm not a chaperon," you say softly. He turns to you. "No... you're not. You're... you look like a ghost." [["Something like that."]] [["I'm here from your future."]] [["Doesn't matter what I am."]] [[Kill him.->Kill the boy.]]"Something like that," you say. Looking down at your shimmering hands. "It's... good to meet you, ghost-thing." He stands so perfectly still in the silence. "You're here to kill me. Aren't you?" [["Yes. I am."]] [["No. I'm here to understand."]] [[Kill him.->Kill the boy.]]"I'm here from your future," you say. "And... your past, in a sense." He stands so perfectly still in the silence. "You're here to kill me. Aren't you?" [["Yes. I am."]] [["No. I'm here to understand."]] [[Kill him.->Kill the boy.]]"Doesn't matter what I am," you say. "Of course it matters. Does to me, at least." He stands so perfectly still in the silence. "You're here to kill me. Aren't you?" [["Yes. I am."]] [["No. I'm here to understand."]] [[Kill him.->Kill the boy.]]"Yes. I am," you say. "I did something, didn't I?" he says. "I look up so much because... it's like something is looking back. Inside all the wonder, there's a... shame I don't understand. But I can't look away." There's a burning curiosity in his eyes, as they trace the outline of your body. Fixate on your eyes. "You don't have to do this," he says. "You can just leave." [[Just leave.]] [[Kill him.->Kill the boy.]]"No, I'm here to understand," you say. "I did something, didn't I?" he says. "I look up so much because... it's like something is looking back. Inside all the wonder, there's a... shame I don't understand. But I can't look away." There's a burning curiosity in his eyes, as they trace the outline of your body. Fixate on your eyes. "You don't have to do this," he says. "You can just leave." [[Just leave.]] [[Kill him.->Kill the boy.]]"You're right," you say. "I'll just... go." It all melts away, as you return to your world. It's all as you've left it. As Ezra's left it. You hope that's enough. There's only what's left of your grandmother's story. And it's time for it to [[finish.->End story repeat]]His neck is soft, as you wrap your fingers about it and begin to tighten. The flesh squirming as his lungs try and suck in air that won't pass through your grasp. And his eyes are bursting in confusion and fear and his eyes look up, at the stars. And the thrashing subsides. The ground seems to sway as you feel your feet on wood instead of wheat. The stars reflected in the ocean water. Your hand still around Ezra's throat, but now on the open sea. The stench of salt and sweat. Still you squeeze, as you see the same hunger in Ezra's eyes looking out to the horizon. "You're killing yourself too, you know," he says without words. Without throat. "You were never there, before I changed everything. Not //this// you." [['"I know."'->I know ch8 end]] [["There'll be some better me."]]"I know," you say. Feeling even this ghostly form slipping. "Last change to let go," he whispers. [[Let go.]] [[Finish this.]]"There'll be some better me," you say. Feeling even this ghostly form slipping. "Last change to let go," he whispers. [[Let go.]] [[Finish this.]]You let go, and you're back in the field with the stars, with the boy falling back into the grass, coughing and wheezing as the air rushes back into your lungs. It all melts away, as you return to your world. It's all as you've left it. As Ezra's left it. You hope that's enough. There's only what's left of your grandmother's story. And it's time for it to [[finish.->End story repeat]]Your grip remains strong, and you're back in the field with the stars, with the boy and he grows limp. Falling off your hand and onto the floor. It all melts away. There's only what's left of your grandmother's story. The strands you can still tug on as some greater current pulls on you. But you [[hold on.->End story change]]Ana looks colder than when the story began. Her arms loose and lifeless. This was not the resounding story she had hoped for. <<linkreplace "“E... o que aconteceu com os Tupiniquim? E os quilombos? Os portugueses foram embora?”">>"And... what happened? To the Tupiniquim? And the quilombos? Did the Portuguese ever leave?"<</linkreplace>> <<linkreplace "“Você já sabe todas as respostas.”">>"You know all the answers."<</linkreplace>> Ana looks up, meeting her mother's gaze. <<linkreplace "“É... parte do porquê estamos aqui. Não somente a dor. Mas a força e resiliência também.”">>"It's... part of why we're here at all. Not just the pain. But the strength and resilience, too."<</linkreplace>> There's a heavy knock on the door, as the storm rages on. Ana's mother goes to open it, and Amarizio falls through. Hair dusted with snow, body cold. <<linkreplace "“Conseguiu?”">>"Did you...?"<</linkreplace>> He nods. Eyes closed. Small smile. He collapses inward to the floor, and his mother closes the door behind him. Ana stands to run and give him a hug, but stops as she sees him crying. Hands are shaking, but he pulls out a small screen from his pocket. Ana watches her mother leans down. <<linkreplace "“Consegui,”">>"I did it,"<</linkreplace>> he says. His fingers still tremble as he touches the screen. <<linkreplace "“Tenho as passagens.”">>"I have the tickets."<</linkreplace>> She grabs the screen, to see them with her own eyes, and she breaks into tears too. <<linkreplace "“Nós vamos ser mineradores,”">>"We're going to be miners,"<</linkreplace>> he says. <<linkreplace "“Em Marte.”">>"On Mars."<</linkreplace>> But she's barely listening. Only knowing that her son and daughter will be far away from the encroaching storm. And as the two of them cry hard enough they can convince themselves it's laughter, Ana can't shake the glint of fire and pain in a woman's eye on a beach, as a bumbling man crawls out of a boat and this time, the shore's made of red rocks and the man is her. And her brother. And mother and every other mother crying tears she convinces herself are of joy over a chance to live like a rat in a hole, digging out a home for someone else, to call that worthwhile because it is better than no life at all. She thinks again. And the soft sounds of song give her hope. The sensation there's someone here, watching over her, gives her hope. And so it begins again. <center>[[--->Transition to repeat history new]]</center> <<linkreplace "“Dandara sobreviveu ao dia da queda de Palmares.”">>"Dandara lived through defeat, on that day."<</linkreplace>> The words are light, and fall softly on her daughter's ears. Ana's smile warms the room. <<linkreplace "“Palmares cresceu de novo, e permaneceu. E resistiu. Dandara levou não só os africanos que escaparam de suas cadeias, mas os povos indígenas também. Até os brancos que foram deixadas de lado. Todos eles lutaram para libertar estas praias. E no final, eles venceram. Não apenas por um dia, mas por todos os dias.”">>"Palmares grew again, and remained. And resisted. Dandara led not only the Africans who escaped their chains, but the indigenous people too. Even the whites who had been cast aside. They all fought to liberate these shores. And in the end, they won. Not just for one day, but for all days."<</linkreplace>> You see it. Less clearly now, but you feel something sweep across the string. Disjointing everything, but only for a moment, as the new music continues forward. <<linkreplace "“Não foi fácil, mas sempre foi possível. Que o mal podusse ser desfeito. A estória de Dandara foi uma entre muitas, as estórias daqueles se opuseram às circunstâncias em que nasceram. E... criaram novos mundos.”">>"It wasn't easy, but it was always possible. That the evil could be undone. Dandara's story was only one of many, of those that pushed against the lives they were born into. And... created new worlds."<</linkreplace>> No more clanking of chains. Instead, the strumming of music. The shuffling of leaves. Pain and conflict, yes. But of a different kind. <<linkreplace "“Você queria conhecer a estória de Dandara, do seu nome. Ela era a guerreira que fez do Brasil um quilombo pra todos nós.”">>"You wanted to know the story of Dandara, of your name. She was the warrior that made a quilombo of Brazil for us all."<</linkreplace>> <<set $relDelta to $relDelta + 10>>\ <center>[[--->Resistance Epilogue]]</center> It's all gone, and you're back in the strange pool of water, surrounded by the sphere of glowing microbes. The pulsing has stopped. Teenesee's hand is gone, no outline of her<<if $Yusuf is "alive">> and Yusuf<<endif>> from the other side of the water's surface. They must already be on their way back to the ship. With the samples they've collected. //Ezra did so little to push your people into this endless repetition that brought you here... even now, you have left it intact. My people began this search to prove your time is like ours: round. Simultaneous and unchanging. I think their point has been made.// [["That these cycles of violence are inevitable."]] [["That there will always be resistance."]] <<set $relDelta to $relDelta - 10>>"That these cycles of violence are inevitable." //That it's the same, single cycle. On the shores of Brazil, the caves of Mars, and here. Occurring at once.// The sphere of microbes begins to dissipate. //Linearity is a lie to support the fiction of progress. It allows you to repeat your past barbarity but claim innocence by putting it under a different name.// "I have to stop her," says Sarah, also coming back to consciousness. "Stop Teenesee and the others from going back." She has seen these sights too. Not the same as yours, but her own echoes of history. "This doesn't have to repeat." She's pushing herself towards the water's surface. "I can't let them be right about that." The sphere of microbes opens up to let her go. //You know it's too late, $name. You've already arrived. Even if Sarah pulls them back, then what? You all die here, and Ezra sends more. You chose to repeat your past, and so, here we are again.// "If this exploitation is inevitable, as these beings seem to believe, you should go home," says CINDI. "There is no reason for you to die here." //I did not say it is inevitable. You had the chance to change the historical conditions that brought you to this point, and you didn't. To defeat Ezra, the man who created those conditions, and you didn't. Instead, you submitted to your limited imaginings of history.// [[Go back to the ship.->Escape peace repeat]] [[Stay with them.->Repeat History Epilogue]]"That there will always be resistance." //And that there will always be something to resist. On the shores of Brazil, the caves of Mars, and here. That it's all the same thing you're resisting.// The sphere of microbes begins to dissipate. //Linearity is a lie to support the fiction of progress. It allows you to repeat your past barbarity but claim innocence by putting it under a different name.// "I have to stop her," says Sarah, also coming back to consciousness.
