The dinner's over. <center>[[--->After Joshua Mem]]</center>It was the first thing Joana could remember. Laughter, at wildly varying pitches. The strange hum of low, warm light. Coming from what were usually emergency lights, some red and others yellow, hooked onto the weak stringy leaves of a tomato plant. Bulbous fruits hanging down. Packages underneath. A strange welling up of excitement in her stomach. It's Christmas, and she's never seen her uncle smile so much, mother laugh so much, father eat so much. "An old man would like his time to speak!" Uncle Amarizio bangs together a hard plastic cup and spoon to get everyone's attention. Ana Dandara points out he's not that old. There's laughter. "In that case, this middle-aged man, with wisdom beyond his years, would like to speak." He stretches his hands out to illustrate the lengthiness of the years. Joana wants to be part of the laughter too. Use the words she's just now beginning to grapple with. [["You're old, Uncle! Don't listen to Mom."]] [["Young people can give speeches too."]]"You're old, Uncle!" she says. "Don't listen to Mom." "See? Even she can recognize the sage and wise man before her," he says. "Give your speech, old man," says Issac with a smile to his brother-in-law, hugging Joana and holding Ana's hand. Amarizio nods to him, eyes soft. "I don't know if you remember, Ana. I barely do... One of my few memories from Earth was not that different from tonight. It was quieter... colder... But somehow, mom still found a voice with which to sing to us. To tell us about all the music, poetry, dance that had graced all her Christmas Eve's. Her songs held all of them, too... "The first Christmas after she passed away, I couldn't find that voice. It was just Ana and I, on this strange red rock... But now, I look out at all of you, our family in this new place, by blood or bond, young and old, and... I'm overwhelmed. I just want to thank you all for keeping this alive." Joana feels her father hold her closer. Her mother's warm and loving gaze. Issac claps and so do the others. Ana simply whispers a thank you toward her brother, grateful to know he'll be there for you, still in her womb. "I also wanted to announce something," continues Amarizio, differently than before. Not quite looking anywhere discernible. Holding something in his throat. "I-- I'm going back. To Earth." Silence falls over the room. "It's something I think I need to do. I just wanted to tell..." He mumbles something more as he stumbles away from the room, towards an open cavern under the Martian rock. Joana sees her mom go after him, and slips out from under Issac's grasp to [[follow.->follow Joana mem]]"Young people can give speeches too," she says. "Right you are! Do you want to give one first?" he asks. "No, I want to hear what you have to say." "Give your speech, old man," says Issac with a smile to his brother-in-law, hugging Joana and holding Ana's hand. Amarizio nods to him, eyes soft. "I don't know if you remember, Ana. I barely do... One of my few memories from Earth was not that different from tonight. It was quieter... colder... But somehow, mom still found a voice with which to sing to us. To tell us about all the music, poetry, dance that had graced all her Christmas Eve's. Her songs held all of them, too... "The first Christmas after she passed away, I couldn't find that voice. It was just Ana and I, on this strange red rock... But now, I look out at all of you, our family in this new place, by blood or bond, young and old, and... I'm overwhelmed. I just want to thank you all for keeping this alive." Joana feels her father hold her closer. Her mother's warm and loving gaze. Issac claps and so do the others. Ana simply whispers a thank you toward her brother, grateful to know he'll be there for you, still in her womb. "I also wanted to announce something," continues Amarizio, differently than before. Not quite looking anywhere discernible. Holding something in his throat. "I-- I'm going back. To Earth." Silence falls over the room. "It's something I think I need to do. I just wanted to tell..." He mumbles something more as he stumbles away from the room, towards an open cavern under the Martian rock. Joana sees her mom go after him, and slips out from under Issac's grasp to [[follow.->follow Joana mem]]Light cascades down from a hole far above them, covered by class. She sees dust being blown across it. "Zio, she didn't send us here just to go back." Joana would come to recognize this exasperated tone in her mother's voice, often directed at her, or later at you. Before you both left. "Earth is my home. Even as its dying... I feel the need to come back." That burning sincerity in Amarizio's voice, that sound still plays in Joana's mind when she is unsure of what step to take next. "It's not right, us being here. As one half of the world burns, the other freezes. I think about Bahia, buried in snow. Our home." "It's not my home." This is sharper. "Zio--" "That's not my name," he snaps. "That's my name for people who don't want to use my name." "-- I left Earth before I could do algebra. You had a childhood there, before it all changed. I didn't. There's nothing for me to go back to. And there's nothing for you to go back to." "There won't be if you and Issac follow Proxima to the end of the galaxy. But if you talked to him, convinced him to--" "Throwing money at a dead planet won't save it. No research can change the inevitable. Plus, we're spending more on the climate control technology than even on the Saturn project. This is--" "It's fucked. And you know it." Joana had only heard that word once before, but knows its bad. "Whose Issac to decide... any of this?" "You know it's not what he wants. His mother--" "-- is dead. And he has the company she forged out of her billions. I don't care what he wants. There's too much at stake for that to matter." They've stopped fidgeting the way they always do, Amarizio opening and closing his fists, Ana Dandara pacing. Now they stood still, staring at one another. "He's my husband. I //only// stakes that matter is our happiness. And that of our children." Her hand rests on her bulging stomach. "So. Let the old world burn, so you can gallivant through the stars, is that it? You, Issac, Joana, and whoever this unborn child becomes?" "The old world is what we carry with us. Forward." Mom had a fire that could come out, too. But it was different, hers more urgent. "Our job is to find a place for as many of us as we can to land. Earth only has to last long enough for us to leave it." "Please don't tell me you think you're saving the human race, by falling in love with the richest CEO humankind has ever known, and setting up resorts from Venus to Saturn." "It's Christmas, Amarizio. If someone ever did once die on a cross for our sins, then find it in yourself to forgive me for finding the happiness you never could. But I guess pretending to be a bitter old man in your early thirties has more immediate gratification, doesn't it?" "This family gives me all the love and joy I need. I'm sorry you can't see that. I'm sorry you always have felt a need for a purpose greater than that, than protecting what we already have." They've walked around a corner, and Joana tries to crane her neck to still see them, she stumbles. "What are you doing here, Jo?" Mom turns, strides over to Joana and kneels down to hold her hand. [["You're late for presents."]] [["I don't want you to be mad with Uncle."]]"You're late for presents." Joana says the words quietly, knowing it's not a good enough reason for snooping. "We'll be right there," she says. "I just needed to sort out all this talk of going back to Earth." [["I don't want you to leave."]] [["I want to go with you!"]]"I don't want you to be mad with Uncle." Joana says the words quietly, knowing people don't stop being mad at each other because you want them to. "Your Uncle is being stubborn, that's all," she says. "I wanted to sort out all this talk of going back to Earth." [["I don't want you to leave."]] [["I want to go with you!"]]"I want to go with you!" she says. "Can you take me?" The words jolt both Ana and Amarizio. He looks down at Joana, to his sister, at you still in her womb. "We can't go," he says. "I'm just saying the kinds of things that silly old men do, sometimes. When they miss home. But it's not safe, back on Earth. Not for me, certainly not for you. But it's alright, because we have each other. And that's a piece of Earth too. Really, we're already there." He gives a halfhearted smile, as he opens up his arms and Joana hesitantly accepts them. Holding him tight once he feels his warm grasp. "Let's go back to the party," he whispers. <center>[[--->After Joana Mem]]</center>"I don't want you to leave..." she says. "Please don't." Amarizio looks down at her, looks to his sister, at you still in her womb. "I won't go," he says. "I'm just saying the kinds of things that silly old men do, sometimes. When they miss home. But you, Joana, and your mom and dad, you'll always be more important to me than any of that." He opens up his arms and Joana rushes into them. Clasping at his warmth. "Let's go back to the party," he whispers. <center>[[--->After Joana Mem]]</center>"Where are you going, Mom?" The voice fell soft on Teenesee's ears as she stood in the doorway of her home, a full moon marking her silhouette. Its craters clear and pronounced in the night sky. There was a breeze, the soft rustling of trees in the wind mixing in with the hum of a small vehicle down the steps from the door. Teenesee turned. Moonlight glinting off a ring on her right hand, clasped around a small bag. She puts it down. "Go back to sleep. Please." The voice seems to come from nowhere. From a shadow draped down the open door's frame. <center>--</center> "Thank you for meeting with me, Doctor Jayplo." The man's handshake is gentle, his smile wide, as he walks across the door's threshold. His skin slightly singed from the sun. "Especially on such short notice." "How could I refuse?" she asks, ushering the man inside. "My home is still standing because of your organization." She leads him to a seat in her living room. Sleek, modern furniture. Ordained with warm maroons. He makes himself comfortable. "I'll cut to the chase. The Proxima Corporation would like you to be a part of a new initiative. We call it Exodus." <center>--</center> The child walks over to Teenesee in the darkness. A blanket littered with stars pulled along in her wake. "I can't sleep. There's something, making a noise outside." She leans past Teenesee, and sees someone closing a door. The man stands by the vehicle. Silent. "That is a shuttle for... a small trip," she says. "By sunrise, everything will be fine." <center>--</center> "This... Exodus, as you call it... would require me to relocate to Saturn?" Teenesee would be lying if she denied her excitement at the prospect. "To Enceladus, a moon of Saturn to be specific," the man replies. "We'll take care of transportation for you and one other family member. It'll take two years, but you won't age a day." "The engine you wish for me to assist in designing. How far along is its development?" "It's less than an idea. But as soon as this... warping, I guess you could say, was discovered, we knew we needed some theoretical physicists. And... that's why I'm here." <center>--</center> "Can you stay with me? Until then?" she asks. "No, I-- have to go on this trip first." This was too much for her. She didn't anticipate having to confront this decision so forcefully. "Are you taking Dwe?" The question she had been dreading. "Your brother is asleep in his bed, like you should be," she lies. "Now go. Rest." Her voice is sharp and forceful, startling her daughter. She sees something in her mother's eyes that has never been there before. <center>--</center> "What do you say?" asks the man, a large smile on his face. "Do you want to help us save the human race?" Teenesee smiles back. She does like the sound of that. "I have to think it over," she says. "Talk to my husband." "Unfortunately, I need your answer now." He leans forward, doing her the courtesy of keeping his eyes directly focused on her. "There's no one else here, right?" "No, my son is at school," says Teenesee. "My husband on a trip." He nods, looking around. Listening. Satisfied. "The Afro-European Climate Control Circle will constrict in size once again in the early hours of tomorrow's morning, no longer encompassing northern Africa, including Liberia." Her eyes grow blank. "Including here." The audacity to think she didn't understand snaps her sight into focus. "Constrict. Leaving us to the whims of the hateful storms... This means it will be renamed the European Circle, then. Yes?" The sarcasm felt too small a cut for the moment, but it was what she had. "After we drown." "That's, uh, above my pay grade." He laughs, attempting to use the comment to alleviate some tension. "You, of course, would be fairly above my pay grade. If you take the offer. And, alive." "I have a second child." It blurts out before she can contain it. "A daughter we've kept hidden." <center>--</center> She pulls her starry blanket close. Her eyes wide and confused by her mother's anger as she begins to move back up the stairs in silence. Teenesee stands and watches as she disappears through the hallway to her room. She's startled by the man with the shuttle, now standing in her doorway. "You can still change your mind," he says. <center>--</center> "I will accept if you allow me to bring both my children." She sits tall. Knowing this would be her only chance to bargain. He laughs. "A ticket to the outer solar system costs more wealth than you can fathom. It's the most desired commodity on the planet. Be grateful you can have one guest." "Then take the second child somewhere safe." How quickly the unthinkable seems like a solution. "Please." Her desperation was leaking through. "And what? Drop her off on the street?" He looks down. "No one's looking to adopt a kid these days, Dr. Jayplo." "My name is Teenese." "Teenesee, then. My job is to bring you an offer. It's one I suggest you take. My job is not to take care of your extra child. An illegal child, I might add. You knew the risks." <center>--</center> "You mean if I ask, you will take my son back here, fly off, and leave us to die?" asks Teenesee. "I meant you can still change your mind about whether you want to do it yourself or not," he replies. "I know you won't stay here. But I can make it easier." His eyes are soft. Glinting in the moonlight. He thinks this is big of himself, offering to put her to sleep himself. [[Nod.->Teenesee nod]] [[Shake her head no.->Teenesee shake]] <center>--</center>"Why did you wait to ask me now?" she asks, knowing the answer. "To make sure you had no other choice, of course." He softens his voice. "I know this all seems unnecessarily cruel. But that's not by design. We didn't even know you had two children." He leans back in his chair. "This isn't about us being friends. You can hate me, hate Proxima, all you want. But think this through. You can either get off this planet with you and one of your children still breathing, or... not." "That is not a choice." "It isn't. It was never meant to be." <center>--</center> He walks upstairs, taking a small pocket-sized euthonizer from his pocket. After he disappears around the same hallway her daughter did moments ago, there's an odd silence. Filled only by the moon and the breeze. A sharp scream. Cry for help. Then silence. <center>--</center> "You don't have to leave her for the flood," he says. "Tonight, she can go to sleep in peace. And remain that way. A painless death is more than most of us still on Earth will get." There's a strange distance in the way he speaks. "I can take care of it, if you want." Teenesee is unable to process her body's movements. The words coming out of her mouth. "No. I must do it. If I go through with this, I must do it." <center>--</center> The man returns. Without a word, he walks past her, through the doorway to the shuttle. There's a spray of water in the air as she follows. It's not morning yet, but it's coming soon. And with it, the flood. That image, of her daughter's body caught in the current amongst the broken floorboards and furniture of her home, lingers as the shuttle lifts from the ground. It will grate away at Teenesee's soul. Leaving it tattered, left in dregs. Only sustained by the promise of Exodus. That she was a sacrifice for a New World of the future. For any future. That must be worth it. That must be worth anything. <<center>>[[--->After Teenesee Mem]]<</center>>"Why did you wait to ask me now?" she asks, knowing the answer. "To make sure you had no other choice, of course." He softens his voice. "I know this all seems unnecessarily cruel. But that's not by design. We didn't even know you had two children." He leans back in his chair. "This isn't about us being friends. You can hate me, hate Proxima, all you want. But think this through. You can either get off this planet with you and one of your children still breathing, or... not." "That is not a choice." "It isn't. It was never meant to be." <center>--</center> The man offers her a small pocket-sized euthenizer. She takes it, before she walks up the stairs. Each step heavy. The pat of her shoes on each stair echoing, it seems. The man watches as she disappears around the same hallway her daughter did moments ago. There's an odd silence. Filled only by the moon and the breeze. A sharp scream. Cry for help. Then silence. <center>--</center> "You don't have to leave her for the flood," he says. "Tonight, she can go to sleep in peace. And remain that way. A painless death is more than most of us still on Earth will get." There's a strange distance in the way he speaks. "I can take care of it, if you want." Teenesee is unable to process her body's movements. The words coming out of her mouth. "No. I must do it. If I go through with this, I must do it." <center>--</center> Teenesee returns. Without a word, she walks past him, through the doorway to the shuttle. There's a spray of water in the air as he follows. It's not morning yet, but it's coming soon. And with it, the flood. That image, of her daughter's body caught in the current amongst the broken floorboards and furniture of her home, lingers as the shuttle lifts from the ground. It will grate away at Teenesee's soul. Leaving it tattered, left in dregs. Only sustained by the promise of Exodus. That she was a sacrifice for a New World of the future. For any future. That must be worth it. That must be worth anything. <<center>>[[--->After Teenesee Mem]]<</center>>“I’m sorry.” “It is strange, mourning not only for his death, but that I have forgotten all of his life. Mourning the fact that I have mourned before, and must again. Beginning to discover the depths of love I had for him, without any memories to tell me why.” [["You'll know him again."]] [["We're all going through that same pain."]] <<set $relTeenesee to $relTeenesee + 1>>"Then don’t." "I will. But only because I can’t stop it." He looks down. "Blinding. It’s all so blinding. They give hands to build, don’t tell you they’re fists. Give you machines, don’t tell you they’re slaves. Give you… toys, don’t tell you they’re…" It’s as if he hit a snag in his thoughts. "Is anyone coming? Anyone else?" Now, panic in his eyes. Wider than you’d ever seen them. [['"Yes."'->Yes ana coming]] [['"No."'->No ana coming]]Double-click this passage to edit it."You're… just a ghost," you say. "You can’t be here." "Oh, I'm here," laughs the water shadow. "Don’t have to be alive to be with you. This is all just… the backwash from the pieces of me in you, the pieces of me left in the dirt of this place. "But there’s enough of me left to come back and tell you not to leave and fuck this up. Or half-ass your way out of this. The longer you’re here, with them, the deeper they can help you dig. The farther back into our pasts we can touch. The larger the butterfly we can squash. Or... save." //The further back your memories go, the more dangerous making choices becomes. You could wipe yourselves out of existence. Regardless, I am not convinced you understand what your captivity would mean. They intend to do to you what you did to us: shatter your worldview. Reconstruct it in their image. Tie together all of your vast concept of time and compress it into a single moment. Perhaps before, I would have supported this wholeheartedly. But, now... I cannot help but see pieces of how your world operates that I think would be a loss to erase. This duality, that we hold, $name, I do not think it is something they wish to take into account.// "$name. You cannot remain here." CINDI's voice is soft. The closest you've heard her come to a whisper. It's not that, it's not the volume. She's attempting to use neural paths where I'm not as present. But, I hear her anyway. "Rejoin the others and return to the ship. Go home. There's nothing more that can be done. They have even said: this violence, they have already felt it, experienced it, from our future. The choice has been made, there's nothing more to be done." From the cracks between the lights making up the sphere surrounding you, there's the silhouette of <<if $Yusuf is "alive">>two figures. Teenesee and Yusuf<<else>>a figure. Teenesee<<endif>> must have finished collecting the samples. All they need to return is for you to join them, and escape this place. <<if $Joana is "alive">>\ "$name, please… We have to stay.” Joana’s roots spread like tentacles in the water. There’s a peace in her body as it and all the things that are a part of it are reflected in the water’s caustics. A peace in her words as they reach you. "The only way to leave is to stay." <<elseif $Joana is "dead">>\ "$name, please… We have to stay.” The shimmers in the water spread and surround. There’s a peace in those movements and in Joana’s words as they ripple over you among the water’s caustics. "The only way to leave is to stay." <<endif>>\ [[Escape.]] [[Fix what you've done.]] [[Remain captive.->Remain captive. new]] "You're… alive?" you say. "Oh, fuck no," laughs the water shadow. "I'm most certainly dead. This is all just… the backwash from the pieces of me in you, and the pieces of me left in the dirt of this place. "But there’s enough of me left to come back and tell you not to leave and fuck this up. Or half-ass your way out of this. The longer you're here, with them, the deeper they can help you dig. The farther back into our pasts we can touch. The larger the butterfly we can squash. Or... save." //The further back your memories go, the more dangerous making choices becomes. You could wipe yourselves out of existence. Regardless, I am not convinced you understand what your captivity would mean. They intend to do to you what you did to us: shatter your worldview. Reconstruct it in their image. Tie together all of your vast concept of time and compress it into a single moment. Perhaps before, I would have supported this wholeheartedly. But, now... I cannot help but see pieces of how your world operates that I think would be a loss to erase. This duality, that we hold, $name, I do not think it is something they wish to take into account.// "$name. You cannot remain here." CINDI's voice is soft. The closest you've heard her come to a whisper. It's not that, it's not the volume. She's attempting to use neural paths where I'm not as present. But, I hear her anyway. "Rejoin the others and return to the ship. Go home. There's nothing more that can be done. They have even said: this violence, they have already felt it, experienced it, from our future. The choice has been made, there's nothing more to be done." From the cracks between the lights making up the sphere surrounding you, there's the silhouette of <<if $Yusuf is "alive">>two figures. Teenesee and Yusuf<<else>>a figure. Teenesee<<endif>> must have finished collecting the samples. All they need to return is for you to join them, and escape this place. <<if $Joana is "alive">>\ "$name, please… We have to stay.” Joana’s roots spread like tentacles in the water. There’s a peace in her body as it and all the things that are a part of it are reflected in the water’s caustics. A peace in her words as they reach you. "The only way to leave is to stay." <<elseif $Joana is "dead">>\ "$name, please… We have to stay.” The shimmers in the water spread and surround. There’s a peace in those movements and in Joana’s words as they ripple over you among the water’s caustics. "The only way to leave is to stay." <<endif>>\ [[Escape.]] [[Fix what you've done.]] [[Remain captive.->Remain captive. new]]<<silently>> <<if not $choices>> <<set $choicesCount to -1>> <<set $choices to ["an invitation", "directions", "a command"]>> <</if>> <<set $choicesCount to $choicesCount + 1>> <<if $choicesCount >= $choices.length>> <<set $choicesCount to 0>> <</if>> <<set $path to $choices[$choicesCount]>> <</silently>> \<<linkreplace $choices[$choicesCount]>><<include "Cycling_ch8">><</linkreplace>>You say nothing, unsure of what voice would come out even if you tried to speak. But the frantic searching of your eyes speak volumes. "You are awake. Good." The voice is even. "Decompression is in process. Please remain still. Decompression is in process." [[Pull at your constraints.->Pull 2]] [[Stay still.->Still 2]] [[Ask the voice some questions.]] <<set $speak to 0>>You remain still, as instructed. The mantra continues. "Please remain still. Decompression is in process. Please remain still." Warm air blows through the container. The remaining frost on your fingertips and toes melts away. The tight jumpsuit you feel hugging your body turns from damp to dry. The frost covering the glass is gone, leaving you to stare at a blindingly white ceiling, smoothly rounded. "Decompression complete." [["Now let me out."]] [[Stay silent.->Silent 1.2]] <<set $relCINDI to $relCINDI + 1>><<set $speak to $speak + 1>>\ "Who are you?" you ask, sitting still. "Where am I?" <<if $speak is 1>>Your voice surprises you, and cracks half way through the sentence.<<endif>> There’s no response. "Answer me!" You croak out a yell. There is a pain in your throat from pushing air through it. "Please remain still. Decompression is in process. Please remain still." Warm air blows through the container. The remaining frost on your fingertips and toes melts away. The tight jumpsuit you feel hugging your body turns from damp to dry. The frost covering the glass is gone, leaving you to stare at a blindingly white ceiling, smoothly rounded. "Decompression complete." [["Now let me out."]] [["Answer my questions."]] [[Say nothing.->Silent 1.2]] <<set $question_ch1 to "asked">>Silence lingers, as the hiss of the warm air subsides. "Please verify your credentials to exit the cryo chamber." You only now notice that the voice is coming from all around you, from the container itself. "To specify: please give me your name, rank, and designation number." You can't remember. There is a sinking in the pit of your stomach. "Please give me your name, rank, and designation number." Your gut swirls. You feel sick. You make a retching sound. "Give me at least your name. You must remember your name." The voice breaks its monotony. [["Why can't I remember my name?"]] [["I don't want to tell you my name."]] [[Stay silent.->Silent 1.3]]"Answer my questions." You speak steadily this time. "I can only do that after I have verified your credentials." You only now notice that the voice is coming from all around you, from the container itself. "Please give me your name, rank, and designation number." "I can't remember." There is a sinking in the pit of your stomach. "I can't remember-- I--" "Please give me your name, rank, and designation number." Your gut swirls. You feel sick. You make a retching sound. "Give me at least your name. You must remember your name." The voice breaks its monotony. [["Why can't I remember my name?"]] [["I don't want to tell you my name."]] [[Say nothing.->Silent 1.3]]Your eyes grow blank and your lower lip quivers. "You really don't know, don't you?" The voice pauses. "There is no protocol for this." <<if $question_ch1 is "asked">>\ [['"Answer my questions."'->Answers for Who]] <<endif>>\ [["Let me out."]] [[Stay silent.->Silent 1.4]]Your chest heaves up and down as focus on your breathing, saying nothing. "There is no protocol for this." The repetition is rhythmic. Until it stops, its silence meeting yours. All you do is breathe and wait. You can't say how long the silence lasts. Soon, you hear a hiss, as the glass top of the container lifts and slides down. The straps around your body loosen. [[Sit up slowly.]] [[Sit up quickly.]]"Where is this vessel, CINDI?" Your voice is raised as you feel tears just beneath your eyes. "I cannot tell you. You have not provided rank or designation number." The voice is beginning to pause in odd places. "Please try and understand." [["There's nothing I understand right now."]] [["Please let me out."]] [[Say nothing.->Silent 1.6]]You hold your tongue as you feel tears just beneath your eyes. "I cannot say more. You have not provided rank or designation number." The voice is beginning to pause in odd places. "Please try and understand." [["There's nothing I understand right now."]] [["Please let me out."]] [[Stay silent.->Silent 1.6]]The tears leak through the corners of your eyelids. The voice says nothing. Instead, you hear a hiss, as the glass top of the container lifts and slides down. The straps around your body loosen. [[Sit up slowly.]] [[Sit up quickly.]]You feel sensations of life trickling all across your body.. Muscles are sore, from the long sleep. But it's nothing compared to the numbness of your empty mind, grasping at any sense of familiarity. You begin to [[get out of your container.->Get out of your container.]]
